TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we, as Australians, have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Beahan (from 159 citizens) and Knowles (from 60 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador: Military Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia humbly pray that:
1. The Parliament heeds our profound concern regarding the Penal Code Reforms of the ARENA Government in El Salvador.

2. We request that as these reforms breach the International Covenant on Civil and Political rights, and in consideration of the escalation of human rights violations by El Salvadoran Armed forces, the Australian Government convey to the United States that all forms of military aid to the Salvadoran Government should be suspended.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Solar Energy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is widespread community concern regarding:
1. the almost total dependence in Australia on fossil fuels and their deleterious effects in producing the greenhouse phenomenon in the environment;
2. the proposal to spend millions of dollars on research into nuclear power, the production of which has in other countries proven expensive and dangerous; and
3. the lack of adequate funding for research into, and promotion of alternative renewable sources of energy, in particular, solar power.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. fund adequate research into production of large scale solar energy for industry; and
2. encourage the use of known technology for hot water and space heating by tax incentives on solar heating equipment for houses and commercial buildings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Yugoslavia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth.

Based on Australia's record and influence in the international arena in reference to human rights. We hereby PLEAD with the Australian Parliament to take into consideration the following points, which are vital for democracy, freedom, equality and justice.

(i) That the Australian Parliament forms a Committee and in co-operation with other Western Democracies and international human rights groups creates an International Committee which will urgently visit the Albanian political prisoners in Yugoslavia and evaluate their physical, psychological and medical state and conditions in which they live in prisons.

(ii) That the Australian Parliament and the Government request from the Yugoslav and the Serbian Governments; that all military and special police units be withdrawn from Kosova and the persecution and killing be stopped immediately of Albanians in Yugoslavia.
(iii) That the Australian Parliament and the Government request from the Serbian Government the release of all political prisoners and declares their imprisonment illegal and unconstitutional.

(iv) That the Australian Parliament and the Government request the Yugoslav rather Serbian Government to bring to an end the trial of Azem Vllasi, the former President of Kosova and the other 14 members of the Parliament of Kosova who opposed the changes to the 1974 Constitution.

(v) That the Australian Government raise the question of Kosova through the Australian United Nation representation and request a popular referendum under the Auspice of the U.N. be held in that province to determine its future status.
And your petitioners shall as in duty bound forever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
THERAPEUTIC GOODS BILL 1989

The purpose of the Bill is to provide, so far as the Constitution permits, for the establishment and maintenance of a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods that are supplied in Australia, whether those goods are produced in Australia or elsewhere, or are exported from Australia.

This Bill will bring together and strengthen various pieces of Commonwealth legislation to provide protection to consumers of therapeutic goods and to assist Australian industry both locally and internationally.

Therapeutic goods are those goods for use for the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of diseases and other bodily conditions or which can be taken to be for such a use through advertising and other means. These goods cover a vast array of products ranging from those that have become essential to maintain the standards of health and well being which we have come to expect to those that are merely for our convenience.

The range includes substances extracted from biological sources such as vaccines and antibiotics, the large range of chemically made pharmaceutical products which we see in pharmacies, test kits for the diagnosis of diseases such as dip sticks to monitor urinary sugar, and a diversity of other therapeutic devices ranging from cyclotrons to contact lenses to bedpans.

At the present time it is estimated that on the Australian market there are over 14,000 medicinal drug products and perhaps 25,000 therapeutic devices. This is an estimate because currently many products can enter our marketplace without prior recording or scrutiny.

Several factors have influenced the average life expectancy at birth of the Australian population, which has increased by 15 years over the past 65 years. Improved sanitation, improved education about health issues leading to changes in personal habits and improved nutrition have all contributed to this increase. What is clear, however, is that the availability of modern therapeutic goods has played a major beneficial role in modifying the impacts and outcomes of illnesses and contributed greatly to the quality of the life which individuals now enjoy.

Many therapeutic goods are, in effect, man made supplements to the body's own mechanics to maintain its health status. However this manipulation of the still poorly understood and immensely complex checks and balances that occur in the body involves a substantial risk factor. One has only to consider the personal catastrophies caused by thalidomide, when it was given to pregnant women, to realise that there is a narrow margin for many therapeutic goods between benefit and risk or, put another way, for a drug to be either a medicine or a poison. In the same way a poorly made or designed device may be a hazard rather than a help. The potential damage is compounded by the huge international scale of mass production and distribution of therapeutic goods.
Three parameters are used to define the acceptability of a product for therapeutic use.
The first is its quality which refers to aspects such as its proper manufacture, the trueness of the contents to the label and its compliance with any relevant product standards.

The second parameter is its safety, that is its lack of toxicity or hazard or at least that the product has an acceptable level of risk compared to the expected benefits when it is used as directed. This aspect is often demonstrated from animal experiments and the information must be assessed in relation to how and why the product will be used. Surveillance for unwanted effects must also continue after a product has been marketed.
The third parameter is the product's efficacy, or its effectiveness in fulfilling its intended purpose.

Of course other social and economic considerations follow from these product specific aspects, considerations such as the need for the product and its cost. These are not covered in this legislation but for drug products are matters dealt with by the Department of Community Services and Health primarily through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and the National Health Act. Together, consideration of these factors make the major contribution toward the rational use of therapeutic goods.

While Therapeutic Goods are used in both humans and animals, the Bill deals primarily with those Therapeutic Goods for human use. It complements the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act that deals with products for veterinary use and which comes within the jurisdiction of my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

Many Therapeutic Goods are used on or in humans, with the individual patient often having little choice about whether or not to use the product, or being able, by themselves, to assess the benefits of its use against the risks. The complexity of Therapeutic Goods, the diversity and size of the industry and the real risks represented by many products are such that self regulation by the industry is not sufficient.
In recognition of these circumstances Therapeutic Goods are, worldwide, subject to a relatively high level of control.

The Bill provides a standard of regulation that is recognised internationally as being necessary to control Therapeutic Goods and which will bring Australia into line with the levels of product assurances exercised and required by its major trading partners.

The Bill includes the three major elements recommended by the World Health Organisation as being necessary for effective regulation and which are utilized by several European Countries, Britain, USA, Japan and Canada.

First is premarket assessment of products for human use, this being an independent assessment of the manufacturer's data on the product. The Bill permits the assessment of new products prior to inclusion of the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods.

Secondly is the assurance that good manufacturing practices are followed in the manufacture of the Therapeutic products for human use. Although a product may be judged to be of an acceptable standard and would appear safe and efficacious on the basis of the premarket evaluation, the standard of manufacture may be so inadequate that there can be no assurance of its quality or consistency on a batch to batch basis once it has entered the marketplace.

The Bill requires that most Australian manufacturers are regularly inspected by authorised inspectors for compliance with codes of good manufacturing practice as a prerequisite for holding a licence to manufacture Therapeutic Goods.

Thirdly is compliance with set standards for Therapeutic Goods for human and animal use. The Bill contains provisions for setting standards and provide for regulations for the independent sampling and analysis of goods on the market.
All parties (Government, Industry, Professional Organisations and Consumer Groups), agree on the validity of these means of protecting the public from unacceptable products.

The Bill is designed to replace the current potpourri of State, Territory and Commonwealth Legislation which has evolved in a largely unco-ordinated manner over the years, resulting in both disturbing overlaps in controls and unacceptable gaps. The current situation neither adequately protects the public nor benefits the industry. The Bill does not in general greatly increase the current levels of Legislation but will remedy identified unacceptable gaps.

An example of the gaps is the lack of comprehensive licensing of manufacturers. In the 1960's it was agreed that the Commonwealth would provide a pool of expert factory inspectors and that the States would licence manufacturers of Therapeutic Goods on the basis of the inspections.

To date only one State has a comprehensive licensing system and recent evidence that the Department of Community Services and Health gave to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts revealed that many manufacturers do not have an acceptable standard of manufacture. The fragmented licensing controls have meant that Australia has been refused membership of international inspection agreements through which we could gain information on the standard of manufacture of imported products and which would assist reputable Australian exporters to enter overseas markets.

Another example of the current inadequate situation, is the lack of scrutiny of locally made products. This is because the Commonwealth powers to carry out comprehensive premarket evaluations of products currently rely on the provisions of the Customs Act 1901 which apply only to imported products.

The Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 will rectify these deficiencies. It utilises the Commonwealth heads of power over corporations, interstate trade, and imports and exports. It will change the focus of control from the point of import to the point of supply and will provide a substantially uniform, national system of controls.
Industry and consumers alike will benefit from the legislation.
For the industry the controls will protect the good reputation of reputable Australian manufacturers by weeding out unacceptable manufacturers and products.

The Bill will apply similar requirements to locally manufactured and imported goods and many of the costly and frustrating differences in requirements that currently exist within Australia should disappear. The standing of, and confidence in, Australian exports will, I am sure, increase and we will be able to enter cooperative arrangements with other governments and regulatory authorities. This is essential, so that we can compete in overseas markets, for instance, in the environment of the 1992 proposed European Community's trade agreements.

Consumers will have the protection and peace of mind of knowing that new therapeutic goods, both locally made and imported, can be subject to scrutiny before approval for supply and that the products will have been manufactured to acceptable standards.
I will now give more detail on the major aspects of the Bill.

The Bill contains provisions to establish standards for quality for therapeutic goods and it will provide for the uniform application of those standards to imported, exported and locally produced products both for human and animal use.

The British Pharmacopoeia and the British Pharmacopoeia (Veterinary) will automatically be adopted as the primary sources of standards. These represent sets of standards, mainly for medicinal drugs, which are recognised internationally. Uniformity of standards between countries is desirable to facilitate international trade and assists the Australian industry.

The Bill also has provision for establishing national standards by ministerial determinations which are called therapeutic goods orders. Therapeutic goods orders are developed by a committee established by the regulations, the Therapeutic Goods Committee, which has industry and consumer representation. The Committee must advise the Minister on any proposed standard or changes to standards.

National standards are required where there is an identified and proven need and where a suitable international standard does not exist. These can be created by adopting standards from other sources such as other pharmacopoeias or, in the case of therapeutic devices, standards developed by the Standards Association of Australia.
The Bill contains provision to establish the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Inclusion in the Register will represent approval for supply.

It will be an offence to supply therapeutic goods in Australia or to export therapeutic goods from Australia unless the goods are included on the register or have been specifically exempted from this requirement by the regulations to the bill.

The register will be divided into two parts, one part for registered goods and the other part for listed goods. Registered goods will require evaluation by my department prior to approval for supply, the degree of evaluation being related to the perceived risks of that class of goods. This will include products such as prescription drugs, new medicinal chemicals and those therapeutic devices regarded as presenting significant risks to the patient.

Where possible existing expertise in the states will be utilised in the national system. For example, negotiations are well advanced to contract the Victorian Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee to carry out evaluations of many non-prescription drugs.

The other part of the register will be for listed goods. Listed goods will be those which by their nature and history of use represent a low risk, and which will be included in the register subject to compliance with standards and some other requirements relating to quality and batch related safety, rather than a full evaluation.
Included in this group will be most of the herbal products, the more concentrated homoeopathic products, vitamin and mineral products and most therapeutic devices.

The regulations will exempt certain products from the requirement for prior approval for supply. These products include simple pharmaceutical formulations for external application and therapeutic devices which are seen as presenting no greater risk than consumer goods in every day use. Also exempted are personal imports, that is, products for a person's own use or use by the immediate family, which are produced overseas and not available in Australia, provided the products are not injections or are not specifically prohibited. However, the current conditions for a personal import will be tightened to include a limit on the quantity imported of three months supply at the maximum dose of a medicinal drug recommended by the manufacturer. If it becomes evident that this exemption is being abused it may be necessary at a later stage to amend this exemption.
Special provisions will also apply to goods not on the register which are for use in treatment of specific individuals where other treatments have failed and to products for use in clinical trials.
Although these goods will be exempt from inclusion in the register, the bill contains specific requirements for their supply.

Products legally on the market at the time of commencement of the legislation will be entitled to immediate entry into the register following application by the sponsor. Many of those will not have been evaluated and it is proposed to evaluate relevant products in this ``grandfathered'' category if the need arises, or selectively as resources in my department permit.

It is possible that some products which have previously been rejected by the Victorian Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee yet which are legally sold on the Australian market will be grandfathered. It is intended that these products will be reviewed as quickly as possible to decide whether each should remain on the register.
The regulations will continue the existing expert committees which will advise the Secretary and the Minister on matters primarily dealing with the premarket evaluation of products.
These committees are the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee and the Therapeutic Device Evaluation Committee.

The other major part of the bill is the provision to license Australian manufacturers. The issue of a licence will depend upon compliance with the Australian codes of good manufacturing practice which are of an equivalent standard to the codes of other major countries. A manufacturer's licence will be issued to cover a range of products which the manufacturer has sufficient expertise to produce.
Manufacturers of certain imported goods will be required to provide evidence of their compliance with acceptable codes of GMP in the country of origin.
The appeal provisions within the legislation allow for internal review of decisions with ultimate appeal to the administrative appeals tribunal.

The details of the bill have been the subject of wide consultation with industry, industry associations, consumer groups, professional and practitioner groups and State and Territory governments. The original proposal for the legislation has been substantially modified to take into account the comments my department has received.

With the passage of the Bill, many of those provisions in the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations which are currently used to control the import and distribution of therapeutic goods will be revoked. Similarly the act and its regulations will replace the current Therapeutic Goods Act 1966 and its regulations.

It is expected that the States and Territories will implement complementary legislation to cover products and the few manufacturers which are not encompassed by the Commonwealth controls, for example, unincorporated manufacturers who do not trade interstate. Model legislation will be presented to the States and Territories which would effect this.

The Department of Community Services and Health has the expertise and infrastructure to implement the provisions of the bill. In fact Australia has gained international respect for its performance in this area. The department employs product evaluators, factory inspectors for good manufacturing practice, and incorporates laboratories which carry out post marketing testing of therapeutic goods. Some increases in staff resources will be required and these have been agreed to by Cabinet.
Cabinet has approved a fee structure that will recover from the industry half of the costs of the therapeutics program. The cost of the program was about $30 million in 1988.

The most substantial fees will be for the evaluation of products for registration and for the inspection and licensing of manufacturers. Fees will be associated with defined standards of service and the utilisation of the revenue from fees will be reviewed by a joint industry-government committee.

The legislation will not only provide the means to protect the Australian public from substandard, unsafe and ineffective products but will assist the Australian industry in maintaining a local and international reputation for quality products.

For the first time, this legislation will provide Australia with uniform, national and comprehensive controls for therapeutic goods. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its recent investigation of the Therapeutic Goods Program expressed particular concern about the present lack of such controls.
I commend this legislation to the Senate.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989
This Bill forms part of the package dealing with therapeutic goods and the background is set out in the second reading speech to the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989.

Details of the scale of charges will be finalised and established in regulations after further consultation with the therapeutic goods industry through a joint industry-government committee that has been approved by Cabinet.

I commend this legislation to the Senate.

A number of notices of motion condemning the Government's actions were given today in the Senate by the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats. The decision to introduce a 23 per cent cut in pharmacists' income is beyond belief. It is acknowledged that every other industry and every other professional in Australia has received minimum fee rises of 6 per cent. Yet today, 1 November 1989, the Government is reducing pharmacists' incomes across Australia by 23 per cent. This is the most irrational decision that this Government has ever brought before the Parliament. It is irrational because it tells the pharmacists of Australia that they must maintain their businesses but receive no mark-up.

No-one on the Labor side has ever produced any evidence on how a business can be run successfully with absolutely no profit margin. Today we have come the final track, after months of fighting by the chemists, where the decision has been taken. I say to those chemists who are listening that in two or three or four months this Government will be swept out of office. The writing is on the wall. The polls are indicating that the Government is on the nose. The headlines in the press are stating that the Government is in disarray. There are conflicting statements between various Ministers commenting on tax cuts and other issues. Ministers are making statements across their portfolios which is a sign of a government in disarray.

Many chemists today will be thinking of what they will do to sustain their business, what business decision they will have to make: whether they will have to improve the merchandising section of their shops; whether that will be sufficient to maintain their profitability; whether they will have to put staff off; whether they will have to reduce overheads or whether they just simply will have to close down. SPEECH.PARA: The single most important challenge facing Australia in the next decade is our foreign debt. It must seem incredible to the rest of the world that this lucky country that has such great potential and such great wealth is now placed in such a vulnerable position. Unless Australia can stabilise its foreign debt, we will continue to be a country in permanent decline. It is said by many that the foreign debt problem does not affect them as they have taken out no foreign loans. However, it has to be understood that when looking at the foreign debt we are not singling out the single debt taker or any one of a thousand transactions; rather, we are taking Australia as one and calculating the state of the whole nation's debt. The state of the nation in the medium to long term affects the individual.

The most potent indicator of the effect of foreign debt upon the individual is interest rates. Any borrower whose debt increases will find that the risk of repayment is built into the interest rate factor by the lender. No-one should doubt, therefore, that the world financial markets view Australia as an economy in decline, a country that is badly managed and which is a high risk. It is precisely because of the speed, size and growth of that foreign debt, coupled with the growing balance of payments problem, that the international credit rating agencies such as Moody's Investors Service and Standard and Poor's have downgraded our rating.

Moody's first downgraded Australia's credit rating in 1986 from AAA to AA1. The response of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to that downgrading was simply to say that he did not believe that the second rating agency, Standard and Poor's, would follow. On 3 December 1986, it did follow Moody's and downgraded our rating from AAA to AA+. The second downgrading by both these agencies occurred recently. Although the Treasurer refused to give the Moody's credit agency access to Reserve Bank officials and other government officials during the course of its review, it was still able to judge that Australia's credit rating was at risk. The Treasurer declared again that he did not believe that the Standard and Poor's credit rating agency would follow Moody's second downgrading. He believed it was a far more professional organisation and a far more knowledgeable one. On 25 October, that professional and knowledgeable organisation downgraded Australia's rating from AA+ to AA. This embarrassing saga of a very desperate Treasurer signals not only to the world markets but to the Australian people that the big misrepresentation is no longer working. The truth of Australia's economic situation is apparent to all except the Treasurer. After all, he is practising the great misrepresentation.

When Labor came to office in 1983, Australia's net foreign debt totalled $23.3 billion or 13 per cent of the gross domestic product (GDP). Yet, by the end of June 1989, that figure had exploded to $108 billion or 32 per cent of GDP. Nearly 20 per cent of our export income is required to meet that debt. Yet, 10 years ago only 5 per cent of our export income was required.

Another significant factor about foreign debt is that the maturity rate of the debt has been decreasing. Seventy-five per cent of new debt has a maturity rate of less than three months. Thirty per cent of the total debt has a maturity rate of less than 12 months. Australia has the third highest external debt to overseas private banks behind only Brazil and Mexico. However, in aligning Australia with those Third World countries it should be said that Australia is a far different country from Brazil, Mexico, Argentina or any other South American country. Australia has a far greater wealth base and a far more stable political system. In many respects Australia cannot be compared with those unstable Third World countries and their disastrous economic state. Unless we lift ourselves from the debt trap into which we have locked ourselves, unquestionably we will drift towards their particular state. Sadly, one of the most prominent features of those Third World countries is their great extremes of wealth-the ghetto living. To this point in Australia to a great degree we have been able to avoid those extremes.

Because Australia has a strong political system and a firm foundation of wealth, it is possible very quickly to turn around the economic malaise in which we find ourselves. That is why Australia is the lucky country. We are able to turn things around very quickly before they get too bad. But time is running out. We need a government that will face up to the truth of our economic problems. This Government is incapable of doing so. In contrast, the coalition parties have learned from the past. They have the will, the courage and the dynamic policies to take on Australia's daunting economic problems.

One of the most immediate causes of our foreign debt problem has been the escalation of the current account deficit, which is now running at an annual rate of $23 billion. The Budget forecast was $18 billion. Four major factors have contributed to our current account crisis: low productivity; a shortage of domestic savings in relation to investment; high inflation; and excessive interest rates. I wish to address the subject of productivity as it links with micro-economic reform.

If Australia is to trade its way out of its current account crisis it is essential to ensure a much closer link with wages and productivity. If Australia is to compete successfully with its trading partners on the world markets, we have no choice other than to improve the productivity of our work places, ports, transport, and commodity handling facilities. The first place that we should start is the waterfront.

Tackling the waterfront is not a new problem. Since World War II, as many as 12 inquiries have been conducted into the waterfront practices. The latest inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission estimates that a 20 per cent improvement in labour productivity in the water transport industry as a whole, combined with a faster turnaround of ships in port, would produce an initial cost saving of $860m. This would lead to an increase of over $1 billion in gross domestic product in the long run. Even armed with those statistics, the Government has failed to address this area of badly needed micro-economic reform. Its solution on the one hand just happens to be to accept the dictates of the waterside workers boss, Tas Bull, and undertake more negotiations and more waffle while, on the other hand, it is to pay out $150m to waterside workers. The Government's program of reform in the waterside industry is nothing but a farce. Quite frankly, and quite simply, we need to smash the monopoly union power that the waterside workers hold over Australian docks.

The deal with the waterside workers is part of the Government's new policy in tackling our current account deficit. That policy simply is, `Let's make a deal until the next election and hang the costs to taxpayers'. The Government has made a deal with the banks at a cost to taxpayers of $200m; the Government has made a deal with Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd which will cost taxpayers a now trimmed amount of $36m; the Government has made a deal with the airlines at a cost to taxpayers which we estimate to be $100m-but who knows as the dispute goes on, and I am willing to call it a dispute-and the Government has made a deal with the green movement, costing this country $600m, not to go ahead with the mining of Coronation Hill. Under any economic analysis every one of those deals is wrong in principle and economically unsound. Under any economic analysis they are nothing but short-term political measures that do no more than plug the holes in the Government's leaking policy agenda.

The Government has also failed to tackle another form of micro-economic reform; that is, privatisation. The privatisation of public enterprises is a very important area of economic reform. The Government has no policy on privatisation; there is a split Cabinet and a split party. This contrasts with the coalition parties which have a very extensive policy on the privatisation of public enterprises. We believe that the privatisation program is well overdue, a decade overdue, in this country. The coalition has targeted several bodies for privatisation: Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, Aussat Pty Ltd, Australian National Line and Medibank Private, to name a few.

Another important area that the Government must get down to tackling in any sort of program for micro-economic reform is Australia's road transport system. A high standard road system is important for the efficient transporting of our export commodities as well as the maintaining of safety standards for the general public. The Government has failed to meet both of these criteria.
