In 1974 the same Prime Minister led the push for Qantas Airways Ltd pilots to receive a salary increase of 29 per cent. The same Prime Minister as President of the ACTU sought an 18 per cent increase in the total national wage.

In 1974 Trans Australia Airlines (TAA), as it was then called, agreed to give its 600 pilots a 24 per cent pay increase to bring them in line with the Ansett pilots, who had already received that increase. The increase given by TAA followed the Australian Council of Trade Unions threat to ground both TAA and Ansett. Mr Hawke threatened to ground both airlines if the 24 per cent increase was not granted. When the Government of the time had the audacity to interfere-when Charlie Jones stood up and said `Hey, this is not on'-the ACTU President, Mr Hawke, phoned the then Prime Minister and warned him about interfering. He said it was not the role of the Government. Things have been very different, have they not?
When the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Cameron, interceded and said that he was totally opposed to the excess demands of the Qantas pilots, Mr Hawke, the present Prime Minister, said he:
. . . found it difficult to understand how a Minister on $30,000 a year could be so strongly opposed to wage increases for pilots.
A Boeing 707 pilot then was receiving $28,000 a year. The newspaper report continues:
`It is slightly grotesque' Mr. Hawke said. `If a comparable work value case was done on Cabinet Ministers and pilots there would be some interesting results'.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be today, I can tell you.

—There would be today, Senator Ray; I agree. Let us put it this way: the Ministers of the Crown and the Prime Minister receive more than airline pilots. I accept-and I always have-that Ministers of the Crown work enormously long hours-prodigious hours-and earn every penny they get. They probably deserve a great deal more. But here we had the present Prime Minister saying in 1974 that pilots on $28,000 a year were worth a great deal more than a Minister of the Crown who was earning $2,000 extra. At that stage the pilots were seeking a 27 per cent increase. Mr Hawke thought that was a jolly good idea. He rang up the then Prime Minister and told him to butt out and that it was not the Government's responsibility to interfere in industrial relations disputations. Another newspaper article says:

SPEECH.PARA: The president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Hawke, said that he disapproved entirely of the action taken by the Minister for Transport, Mr Jones in rejecting wage increases approved by Qantas for the pilots and cabin staff.
That was an increase of 29.4 per cent. Then, of course, we had the across the board increase--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have made this speech before.

—No, I have not made this speech before. Senator Foreman has probably read it somewhere else. In fact, he probably just knows about it. In 1974 across the board demands of $20 were being made. They were given the absolute blessing of the present Prime Minister. He used a very cute expression when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If our people started to say we will forgo a wage and salary increase they should be putting their name to the orthodoxy of conservative economics which is that wage and salary increases cause inflation.
At that time he said that that was absolutely absurd. He said:
It would be bloody absurd to the bloody extreme to do that.
To suggest that wage and salary increases in any way are related to inflation would be `bloody absurd', said the Prime Minister. What a change we have now.

TALK.START.PARA: —The scales have dropped from his eyes.
—Yes. When the metal unions, as we have heard so much about, demanded $20 a week despite indexation, what did Mr Hawke say? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Some people will say `hooray' and some will say `boo' but I think the majority will give it a form of welcome.

This is the Prime Minister concerned about wage restraint, ensuring that wage increases are within the accord and that there is no wages blow-out. What did he say in 1975 about the coalminers of Utah Development Co. in Queensland? They received a $95 a week increase in 1975 dollar terms. The then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, and the Cabinet opposed it. A newspaper article says:
The Australian Council of Trade Unions president (Mr Hawke), said in Melbourne yesterday Federal Cabinet criticism of the Utah settlement was `cheap political hypocrisy'.
He also said:
. . . the Federal Government was well aware that a substantial pay rise was needed to settle a seven-week Utah dispute.

In other words, the duration of the strike was a measure of the wage increase that was justified. When the then Prime Minister of Australia said that it was absolutely outrageous the present Prime Minister said that it was thoroughly justified. Part of his justification for the rise concerned the profitability of a company. He said:
And you have a company that is earning very large profits-around $160 million-of which $130 million is going to the US.
The miners who are helping to make these huge profits have every right to share in them.

What a change we have seen. Profitability does not matter now for Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, Ansett or any other corporation. That is not the measure of sharing in productivity and wealth. It is quite different now. In 1975, because Utah was a wealthy company with profits going overseas, there was justification for the employees to receive the indulgence of the increased wages I have referred to.

When Don Chipp interviewed his long lost mate, the present Prime Minister, on his radio program on 3AK he said by way of a rhetorical question that the 30 per cent demand was outside the guidelines, that it would be the end of the accord and that there would be a wage breakout the like of which has not been seen since 1974. He was audacious enough to say 1974. The Prime Minister said:
That's right, although 1981 . . .
He was interrupted by Chipp who said:
That was the last one, but the '74 breakout was caused by a pilot . . .
The present Prime Minister, stuttering and stammering and falling over his microphone, said:
Well it was '74, . . . but you had the breakout in '81.

And away he went. He did not want to remember 1974 because he was the architect, the engineer, the powerhouse, the designer who was responsible for the 1974 wage breakout because he supported a 29.4 per cent increase by the pilots. He wanted to forget all that and remember 1981, when Malcolm Fraser was the Prime Minister.
What do we see? We see gross hypocrisy. It depends what constituency he is playing to. When talking to John Jost the Prime Minister said:
All of us John are the product of our history.

We certainly are; the pilots certainly are. They have got used to the idea of getting 29 per cent, ringing up a President of the ACTU and saying, `This looks like a pretty good deal to me; I think we are worth 29.4 per cent', and the President of the ACTU saying, `You are absolutely right; it is disgraceful that people should call you avaricious, greedy, self-serving and single minded. You are absolutely right'. Of course, they are creatures of their own history. Who was the genius that led the fight that guaranteed in the arbitration court that the pilots got the 29.4 per cent? It was the knight in shining armour-Robert Hawke. He went on to say:

Now these people are the product of a history where in the past where they've gone in and had a fight, pretty soon either Ansett or TAA . . . have caved in. Now that's their history and that's the sort of fight they think they will go into if they go on with this. Well let me tell them it's a different fight they're going into.

Of course, the reason that Hawke intervened in the last disputation with the pilots was that his mate at Ansett, Abeles, who could just ring up the Government and say, `Stick up the air fares, will you, I have just given an increase in salaries', caved in. TAA did not want to cave in. The Government Minister, Charlie Jones, did not want to cave in. The Prime Minister did not want to cave in. Hawke said that it was wrong for the Government to interfere in an agreement and a negotiation that had been entered into, told the Government to butt out and said that the pilots were entitled to the same flow-on award that had been given by his mate Peter Abeles, who is now receiving in his own pocket the benefit of tens of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

He is the single largest shareholder on the board of directors of TNT, which owns 50 per cent of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. Bob Hawke's mate is getting taxes from the Treasury courtesy of the Prime Minister as a result of an agreement negotiated and entered into between the two in the Prime Minister's office: `Now, listen, Bob, I will stick with you, your politics, your agreement and your arrangements, provided you allow me to reorganise, restructure and re-arrange my organisation and operation to make myself more efficient in preparation for deregulation and provided you just slip me a few million of taxpayers' money--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tens of millions.

—Tens of millions, perhaps up to $100m, to keep my operation from losing too much money while this is all going on'. That was the arrangement-an agreement between the Prime Minister and his best mate, the largest single shareholder on the board of directors of TNT, the largest beneficiary of taxpayers' money; and that is why the strike is where it is now.

SPEECH.PARA: We talk about John Elliott-for goodness sake!-being an obscure and indirect beneficiary of some sort of tax arrangement. There is no apology with this lot. The Government just pulls out the cheque book, signs the cheque and hands it over; and then suggests that it is in the national interest and for Australia's good that Pete, the guy into whose arms the Prime Minister burst in tears in depression and alcoholic remorse on one occasion when he was looking for a friend, receive the cheque. He has been pretty well rewarded for his friendship, has he not? So this strike rolls on. That is not to mention the $4.745m that he receives in salary.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Senator Crichton-Browne made a reference to the Prime Minister being in alcoholic remorse. I forget what the rest of the words were. I think they are unparliamentary in the context in which they were used and should be withdrawn.

—On the point of order: it was a historic reference and I am sure it was quite accurate at the time. It was not a present day reference to the Prime Minister in any way at all and, therefore, would not fall within that standing order.
—Senator Crichton-Browne, you might make a statement to the effect that you are not making the imputation at the moment.

—Of course I will. I was referring to the authorised biography written in collusion and collaboration with the Prime Minister. I am certainly not suggesting that he is capable now of having alcoholic remorse; certainly not. The truth is that, at a time when there has to be wage restraint, when we are told that the pilots are demanding a salary increase greater than the wage of the ordinary average John Citizen Australian, as if that is some sin, Sir Peter Abeles, the largest single individual beneficial recipient on the board of directors of TNT, pulls down a salary of $4.74m. That buys a lot of groceries, does it not? We have the Prime Minister saying how audacious and outrageous it is that a pilot ought to be claiming the amount that he is-and, quite frankly, I agree with him. I think it is outrageous to suggest that they should be getting a 30 per cent salary increase without increased productivity. But lined up against a salary of $4.74m, part of which Sir Peter Abeles is being paid to look after his own shareholding, his own stake, the pilots' claim pales into insignificance.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have seen the strike go on day after day after day. What contributions were made by the great conciliator? Because the Prime Minister thought he was going to get cheap political points, because he thought the strike was going to be over earlier, and because he wanted his options left open for an early election, he lashed into the pilots with his vitriol, his abuse, his crude attacks and his unrestrained indulgence in bad language and bad taste when he described the pilots as being able to learn to fly in seven hours. I have to tell the Senate that nine weeks later we have not got enough pilots to fly 20 per cent of Western Australians from Melbourne and Sydney across to Perth and back. If one can learn to fly in seven hours, the sky should be black with aircraft by now. Where are they if one can learn to fly in seven hours? The Prime Minister might have had a bit of a frolic with life and limb up in the air somewhere in the cockpit of a Chipmunk, but I would like to see him after seven hours of training at the controls of a 747, a 767, a 757 or a 737. One would not sell a lot of tickets.

The Prime Minister compared that training with that of a bus driver. I can see no comparison. I would jump in a bus driven by an airline pilot who had spent seven hours learning to drive a bus, but I would certainly not get in the back, front or middle of an aircraft that had up front a bus driver who had had seven hours practice. Yet the Prime Minister used that sort of colourful language to try to draw an analogy between a bus driver's skills, his learning curve and the demands upon him in terms of his responsibility, and the skills of a pilot. I think it is absolutely absurd.

To add insult to injury, for those who do not know these little pieces of trivia tucked away in the backwaters of the machinations of politics, let me tell honourable senators that for the first two or three weeks of this strike the Prime Minister used to go down to the non-members' bar every Thursday night-drinking soda water, of course; I am not seeking to imply anything else-which is unheard of in recent times, to chat up all the press in an attempt to sell his story. One of the Prime Minister's favourite stories was that the hardest thing to get out of the pilots when they resigned was their uniforms because they loved the glory of the peak caps, the braiding, the embroidery and the smart uniforms. What poor taste language! What a pretty rotten sort of warped sense of humour does one have to have to suggest that that is the most important thing in the life of a pilot?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is funny after he has been to the hairdressers.

—That is right. I do not suppose that there is a pilot flying in Australia that has to get somebody in to teach him how to dress or show his wife what the colour contrast ought to be when he is meeting the Queen. Yet the Prime Minister has the audacity to attack the pilots. And one wonders why the pilots are in the trenches.

SPEECH.PARA: When that all failed, of course, he attacked the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. We have seen the result of that. The pilots understand that an attack upon the Federation is an attack upon them. The Federation has the full and unqualified support of the pilots, because the Federation is the pilots. It is a reflection, a manifestation, of their wishes and ambitions and what they want for themselves and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have the same view of any other union?

—If a strike goes on for nine weeks without any significant deterioration in the determination and the will of employees, one would have to say that the leadership of the union has the full and unqualified support of the rank and file. I say that without qualification. Certainly, that is so in this case. And so the strike continues. As I say, it is not about to be resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that the strike could have been resolved. The Prime Minister could have swallowed his pride and been prepared to step back and accept that he had made a hell of a botch of the matter from the beginning. He should have said to Australian Airlines, `Talk to the pilots and see what their best and worst offer is. See whether you can find something in the agreement which is tied to productivity that does not in any way undermine the basic level of awards being granted in Australia at present'. The Government could actually have found, not a wages breakout, but a productivity breakout. But that is not what has occurred. We have had a propaganda war, a series of disinformation campaigns. We have been told that the number of pilots being signed up was 10, then 20, then 30, then 40, and then it was 50. According to the press, so far 1,280 pilots should have been signed up. I do not know where they are, but they are certainly not in the cockpits of the aircraft.

We were told that the pilots would break next week, and then it was the week after. We were told that the airlines had 20 per cent capacity, then 40 per cent capacity and then 60 per cent capacity. We were told that by Christmas they would have 80 per cent capacity. Yet when I rang up the other day to try to book a seat for my daughter, I found that so far there are no aeroplanes flying in December. So much for their capacity!

The Prime Minister has indulged himself, in collusion with big Pete, in a disinformation program. As a result, we are living with the worst industrial disputation that this nation has seen. One party has been given compensation, but what about the little old ladies who clean out the units on the Gold Coast, in Coolangatta, north of Sydney or in one of the Perth suburbs, who have been retrenched? What about the single mothers who rely on that salary in order to live? What benefit, what reparation, have they received? What financial support have they received to keep themselves in jobs? None. What about the kiosk owners, the T-shirt shop proprietors, the taxi drivers? Thousands of those people are going broke. They have received no help from the Government.

One cannot imagine those people being able to pick up the phone, as Pete did, and say, `Hey, Bob, it's Pete here. Can you increase the compensation by a couple of million more because I am hurting a bit?' One cannot imagine Bob saying, `You're dead right, Johnny, sorry to hear that you're in trouble in Coolangatta. I will hold a Cabinet meeting tonight and that will be fixed'. The little people in Australia are not known by the Labor Party. Labor has a corporate mentality-big unions, big corporations, big government. The ordinary, average citizens in this country who want a fair go get trodden on by the jackboots of this socialist Government which cares nothing for little people. It has no regard for the small person, no care, no respect, no understanding. It is about political expediency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that we cave in and have a massive wages breakout?

—In the 60 seconds remaining to me I want to say that I do not expect a cave-in. I am suggesting appropriate, reasonable, rational, commonsense negotiation. All that has to be done is to get the two airlines to sit down with the Federation and a Government Minister-just to make sure that there is somebody there to screw it up-and, among them, see whether they cannot sort out some sort of an agreement, an arrangement, that gets the aeroplanes back in the air. That is the last thing that this mob opposite wants. They want cruel, vital, final victory so that in some obscure, perverted way it helps them politically. That is the history of this Government. It cares nothing for the economy, nothing for the voters, nothing for the people. All it wants is a succession of victories to continue in government.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I will address the continued high level of government spending on defence, which currently represents 9.6 per cent of Budget expenditure. The Budget figures indicate that defence spending is being increased by 7 per cent this year, or $547m, of which 41 per cent will be spent on personnel and retirement benefits and 35 per cent on equipment and stores. As the Defence Manufacturers Council newsletter for September 1989 noted with satisfaction:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence outlays for 1989-90 will be maintained in real terms at the level of 1988-89. In money terms Defence outlays will increase by 6.5 per cent from $7,782 million to $8,327 million in 1989-90. Expenditure under the Defence function will actually increase in real terms by $54 million which Defence will retain from the proceeds of property sales in 1989-90. This sum, equivalent to 0.5 per cent real growth in the Defence budget overall, will be included in the base for determining next year's outlays. In the general circumstances of Government expenditure restraint, this is seen as a satisfactory outcome. Defence continues to account for about 9.6 per cent of Commonwealth budget outlays but will consume only 2.3 per cent of GDP in the coming year.

In citing the current Budget figures and referring to the satisfaction of the Defence Manufacturers Council, I am acutely aware of the fact that the one policy that the Opposition has not yet produced for public inspection concerns defence, although I believe it will be released tomorrow, and I look forward to it with great interest. It is apparently the source of some dispute within the Liberal Party, so I do not hold out hope that it will offer a better alternative than the present Government policy. Indeed, if the resolution passed by the Liberal Party's Federal Council in Sydney in June this year is anything to go by, the Opposition will have to cut back on government expenditure by far more than Mr Peacock's $2.7 billion, because somehow it will have to come up with the money to increase defence spending to a level of no less than 3.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), or an increase of about 50 per cent on current defence expenditure. The Opposition never says how it will pay for these increases. Maybe tomorrow all will be revealed.

According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 June, the increases amount to a sum of $11.2 billion, compared to the $8 billion which is the current level of expenditure. I gather that this is the amount of money necessary to restore the Navy's air wing and to acquire two aircraft carriers. As Senator Newman spoke to this resolution in place of Mr Jim Carlton, perhaps she could explain how a coalition government will pay for this. When she was asked at the Council meeting how the coalition could justify increasing defence spending when the Government's Budget was so tight, she apparently said that the Opposition would need to be courageous in government and seek to show leadership. This would be done by pointing out that the most important thing a government could do was to keep the country free. It will be interesting to see what is contained in the Opposition's defence policy when it is released tomorrow.

In the meantime I want to address the continued high level of defence expenditure in light of this remark by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, to an American journalist in 1985, `I've got $6.3 billion in search of a threat'. He has been looking for a threat ever since. The Minister has countered critics of Australia's new militarism on a number of occasions in the last few weeks by saying that 2.3 per cent of GDP spent on defence is hardly evidence of a threat or a big build-up in defence expenditure, and that since he has been in office this figure has actually dropped as a percentage of GDP from 2.9 per cent in 1984 to 2.3 per cent today. What he does not point out is that, on the one hand, real defence expenditure has increased by 9.3 per cent since 1983, while at the same time tertiary education funding has increased by only 6.9 per cent and housing and community amenities by only 7.4 per cent. On the other hand, industry assistance has been cut by 16.2 per cent, overseas aid by 14.3 per cent, and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has had its research grants cut by a massive 29.9 per cent.

I think it is also worth pointing out that these figures were quoted by a Labor member in the House of Representatives on 17 August this year. It is further worth adding that defence funding, as a proportion of total outlays, rose from 8.8 per cent in 1978-79 to 9.4 per cent in 1987-88 and is now 9.6 per cent. Just referring to GDP figures is deliberately misleading if not placed in this overall context of the cuts that have been suffered by other Government departments. What then is the justification for this increasingly high level of expenditure on the military? I gather that the military does not feel that it is getting enough funding because in a joint letter to the Minister for Defence published in this year's annual report of the Department of Defence, the Chief of the Defence Force and the head of the Department warned the Government that the defence organisation cannot sustain further Budget cuts indefinitely.

I believe this is typical of the misreading of the situation. Many government departments have suffered cuts. Defence has not suffered cuts. In real terms the defence outlay has been maintained and in dollar and percentage terms it has been increased. Defence cuts are seemingly sacrosanct when compared with the cuts that have been made in other ministerial portfolios. It is worth pointing out that even in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and in the United States there are now moves to reduce military expenditure as it has such a crippling effect on the economies and on the debt problems of those two massively militarised countries. In the United States the defence budget almost doubled under the Reagan Administration. The rest of the world is still feeling the impact of United States borrowing to raise the extra $1 trillion that this involved. Likewise, President Gorbachev also has realised what military expenditure has done to the Soviet economy and he is now trying to cut back drastically on the military budget.

To bring this matter back home, Paul Malone had an excellent feature article under the title `It's time to pare military spending' which appeared in the Canberra Times on 2 June this year before he was unfortunately edged out of his role as political correspondent by the paper's management. I commend his article to the Senate. Obviously, if substantial cuts are to be made, we must question the whole direction of Australia's military expenditure. I am glad not to be alone in raising these questions. Some of the basic issues are to be covered in a new book to be published early next year entitled Australia's New Militarism: undermining our future security which is a project of the Secure Australia Project.

The Minister for Defence may claim, as he did in the 1989 T. J. Ryan memorial lecture this month, that we actually spend less on defence as a proportion of GDP than comparable nations in Europe such as Belgium, the Netherlands and Norway. But this ignores the fact that in terms of per capita defence expenditure we come eighteenth in the world, or did according to the latest figures from Ruth Leger Sivard's publication World Military and Social Expenditures for 1987-88. All of the countries which came ahead of us in the table were in Europe or in the Middle East, areas with a history of tension, where immediate threats are perceived by the military. Contrast this with Australia where, as Mr Beazley has admitted, there is no perceivable threat and, furthermore, where we actually had to invent a threat for the Kangaroo 89 exercise: that is Kamaria. As both the 1981 Katter report on Threats to Australia's Security: Their Nature and Probability and the 1986 Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities conceded, there is no threat to Australia and only the US could logistically mount one. Any other country would take five to 10 years to develop a logistic capability to attack Australia. It would be fairly obvious what was going on.

I also point out that, if the threat must come from the north as we are told, virtually all those countries to the north are being armed by countries which form part of the Western alliance or are friendly to it. Indeed, they are the very countries that we are targeting in our own export sales drive of military equipment in order to offset the high cost of importing so much military equipment for the Australian Defence Force (ADF). How the import of very expensive defence items adds to our balance of payments problems is something that is very rarely mentioned. The first military export sales mission went to South-East Asia last December. Now the Department of Defence is to use HMAS Tobruk as a floating arms bazaar after the Gallipoli trip next year in order to promote our military exports in south and south-west Asia. I consider that a great insult to the memories of those diggers who died so tragically at Gallipoli. The ship that is to go to the place where they died to commemorate their sacrifice will, on the way back to Australia, turn into a sales bazaar for the weapons of death.

This arms export push is what I have described on other occasions as dual rhetoric. Australia, instead of Europe and North America, is commendably promoting non-military exports in the Asia-Pacific area and is talking about increasing our regional interdependence. This is a growing world characteristic. As we were reminded after the Black Friday crash on Wall Street earlier this month, the world is indeed becoming a much smaller place. Yet, we are constantly being told that a threat will materialise from the north and that we must be ready for it. The scenario is one of low level attacks on our far north but we are never told who might mount such an attack or why they would do so.

Of the 130 or so wars fought since 1945 only 15 per cent have involved one country invading or attacking its neighbour. These wars are mostly conflicts with a long history, many being a legacy from the colonial period. Fortunately, Australia is not in the position of having any longstanding enemies. It is hard to envisage why any country should pick a fight with Australia that would actually involve attacks on our territory. All the scenarios drawn up recently by the more gung ho press in the Northern Territory and Western Australia seem to focus on Indonesia. These warriors forget that Indonesia depends on countries such as Britain and the United States for its more sophisticated military supplies.

Australia's primary exports-oil, gas and timber-go to countries such as Japan. If Indonesia decided to pick a fight with Australia it would face the most horrendous economic and political consequences. It is worth recalling that, the last time Indonesia engaged its neighbours to the north, the Government was overthrown. We would be far better off trying to promote a greater understanding of Indonesia, encouraging the learning of their language and understanding Islamic culture, than having to read silly scenarios about Indonesian commandos riding around the Northern Territory on trail bikes with shoulder launched missiles, which is what we had to put up with from the West Australian on 29 April this year.

I gather that the Territorians are subject to similar lurid scenarios which I suspect are more likely geared to encouraging the militarisation of the north as a way of saving and boosting the local economy. As Hugh Smith, Director of the Australian Defence Studies Centre at the Australian Defence Force Academy, said in a paper last year:
But who is going to invade or seek a lodgment in country that is difficult for Australia's own forces to operate in?

His paper on the decline of the military profession, presented to a conference organised by the Australian Defence Studies Centre and the Australian Study Group on Armed Forces and Society, raises some interesting questions which this chamber might do well to consider. His paper focused on the problem faced by a number of countries other than Australia of what to do with the military in a period of extended peacetime which is likely to continue. He observed at one point, `Everyone is a `chocolate soldier' now'. He went on to make the interesting observation that the present high rate of attrition from the ADF serves as a functional equivalent of war although he has yet to hear of any politician openly arguing along these lines. He also points to the value of engaging the military in what Morris Janowitz refers to as constabulary tasks. I was pleased to read that Senator Gareth Evans suggested, when he spoke at the United Nations General Assembly this month, that United Nations members should establish emergency peacekeeping teams that could be summoned at short notice.

I suggest that we contribute towards his suggestion of an international training centre for peacekeeping troops rather than building the six submarines or eight frigates, or playing war games such as the next Kangaroo exercise. I gather that this proposal is already under consideration. At a personal level I would much rather develop the idea of non-violent peacekeeping initiatives along the lines of the Peace Brigades International in Central America. In the meantime I feel that the ADF could usefully participate in more places such as Namibia when the need arises, provided that we train personnel for peacekeeping rather than for interventionism.

Given the cost of current military items such as the FA18s, the submarines and the Anzac class frigates, it would seem far more sensible to invest in these and other preventative mechanisms rather than purchasing military hardware. We could strengthen regional and international forums for conflict resolution such as the International Court of Justice or could follow up Senator Evans's suggestion to the United Nations General Assembly about creating an international training centre for peacekeeping troops. I notice from the estimates that we contributed $7,000 to the Bureau of the Permanent Court of Arbitration, $125,000 to the UN Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus, $3m to the UN Interim Force in Lebanon, $2.5m to the UN Iran-Iraq military observer group and $213,000 to the UN Angola Verification of Cuban Troop Withdrawal. If we add those amounts, the total is a fraction of what we spend on the military, but I suggest it is money that is far better spent.

At the national level it would also be cheaper to train our diplomats more effectively in negotiating and language skills than to train FA18 pilots who then join Qantas Airways Ltd or get stuck behind a desk on Russell Hill. We spent a great deal of money on the Australian Defence Force Academy not far from here. Again, I note from the Estimates that we are planning to allocate only $535 to the Peace Research Centre at the Australian National University-a tiny fraction of what we spend on war games and planning for the military. I firmly believe that we should be funding peace and conflict research centres in every State in Australia, just as we have finally recognised the value of conflict resolution at the community level. Even then it would cost a mere fraction of what we allocate to military hardware or to some of the 118 major capital equipment projects under way-`major capital equipment projects' being a term used to refer to a project costing in excess of $10m.

The Minister for Defence proudly proclaims that Australia is spending $25 billion on capital military equipment over 15 years, in the biggest peacetime capital equipment program that Australia has ever known. Yet, the Minister also argues that there has been a reduction in defence expenditure-if he is talking to a more critical audience. He boasts about the high figures when he is amongst his supporters and complains about cuts when he is addressing his critics. His rhetoric changes quite remarkably depending on who he is talking to. I do not think he can have it both ways. This $25 billion figure will probably increase as the costs of the submarines and the frigates blow out, as defence contracts are wont to do.

Unlike our neighbours across the Tasman, we have never really asked what the FA18s are for, what the new submarines are for, what the frigates are for, or what the Seahawk and Black Hawk helicopters are for. We can assume that bigger and more sophisticated toys are more fun than the old ones. Certainly, these items are of little relevance to the kind of scenario that we dealt with in the Kangaroo 89 exercise. They are not much use in dealing with threats to our immediate north, as my constituents in Western Australia have often reminded me. There, in the north, people are concerned about illegal fishing and attendant quarantine dangers, illegal immigration and, perhaps above all at the moment, drug smuggling. They are the real threats to Australia's security at the moment and they are not being adequately addressed by the defence expenditure that we see coming from this present Government. Three submarines at Garden Island may make some Western Australians feel more secure against the unidentifiable threat from the north, but they are not much use for detecting or apprehending drug runners.

David Jenkins in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 August this year referred to the current projected level of armaments on the Anzac class frigates as `a frigate with knobs on'. We are told by the Minister for Defence that these eight frigates are to guard maritime choke points `1,000 miles from our shores'. But even when the Royal Australian Air Force gets an aerial refuelling capability it will not be able to be on station at all times in all places. Captain R. A. Christie, director of surface warfare, command and control, is quoted as saying:
There are areas within Australia's zone of military interest over which you can't have continual air support so any ship must have good air defences.

The Anzac frigates do not have that capability, nor do the three destroyers in the Royal Australian Navy Fleet. According to David Jenkins, it would cost about $4m to $6m to equip each Anzac frigate with an adequate anti-missile system-which, I might add, would also mean a further drain on our balance of payments.

So it is not even the lack of a threat that is at stake. It is the question of why we are getting eight frigates and what they are for, particularly with their apparent inadequate level of armament. The frigates we are getting are well over 50 per cent bigger than those originally recommended in the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and include a far greater emphasis on anti-submarine warfare than Paul Dibb considered necessary. The Minister for Defence states, quite correctly, that other countries in our region are acquiring submarines, but I would submit that they are far more for naval prestige than to combat any external threat.

Indeed, those European countries which were interested in winning the submarine contract in Australia were primarily interested in getting a foothold in a part of the world where they could sell even more submarines. South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and Indonesia were all referred to as potential markets for submarine sales in an article by the editor of the Pacific Defence Reporter this month, while the Australia Submarine Corporation has been chatting with Thailand about the idea of an Australian deal, and regards India and Canada as other possibilities.

Mr Beazley himself referred to this potential for submarine sales in the region in a speech to the Premier's Business Forum in Adelaide on 27 October this year when he spoke of the interest that other countries were showing in the Type 471 submarine, stating:
There may also be good prospects for exporting our submarine technology and expertise to navies in our own region.

Given that all these countries are on our side, so to speak, and that we are hoping actually to build some of their submarines, the question remains: Where does the submarine threat to Australia come from? I would submit that we are involved in creating the very threat itself, that the emphasis on anti-submarine warfare is to detect submarines that we are seeking to build for our neighbours. Furthermore, even with six or 12 submarines, how can we possibly patrol all the choke points in the area of the world that Mr Beazley refers to as our area of interest? On top of that, the volume of Australian shipping is too large to be safely escorted through those choke points by the eight expensive new frigates or our other surface combatants.

Another angle that seems to have been overlooked is the easy access that many countries, including Australia, now have to cheap sea-skimming missiles such as the Harpoon and the Exocet. These can be launched from very small craft and make the frigates extremely vulnerable. That is why I have argued that Australia would be better off served by smaller ships, with the emphasis on non-offensive defence rather than coming up with the Anzac class frigates which do not seem to fit anywhere.

Then there is the $700m being spent on the Seahawk helicopters. Paul Dibb favoured only a light observation helicopter for the frigates rather than these expensive anti-submarine aircraft which are costing us $40m apiece. The Seahawk, like the FA18, comes from the United States. It is worth pointing out that, with our annual balance of payments deficit running at $16 billion, over $1 billion each year is directly attributable to the purchase of military hardware. Why do we never hear about that when we are apportioning blame for this country's excess import bill? The Opposition, too, seems to be very silent on this topic, though quick to allocate blame everywhere else.

This leads me to the Government's reprehensible decision to offset this huge import bill by trying to double our military exports, in line with the recommendations of the 1986 Cooksey report which was never tabled or debated in this Parliament. I remind the Senate of the words of the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Bill Hayden, when he was addressing the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in New York in June 1988. He said:
It is also clear that the arms exports should not be turned to as a way of solving domestic economic problems. Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop.

Then there are the words of the Director of the World Bank, who said on 26 September this year that developing countries should now try to reduce military expenditure, one of the main contributing factors to their enormous debt burden-as well as to ours and that of the United States. Yet this Government chooses to ignore both those statements and instead reinforces the latest Arms Control and Disarmament Agency report from the United States, which tells us that in 1987 the world's national military expenditure surpassed $US1 trillion and that world arms international transfers topped $US56 billion, an increase of about 6.5 per cent over the previous year.

The Middle East remains the world's principal arms market, accounting for 38 per cent of global imports, while the most promising market is East and South Asia where the size and importance of the markets are increasing. At the United Nations we deplore world arms transfers while at the same time we are urged to get into South East Asia quickly and sell before the British tie up the region for many years to come. This is why the Department of Defence wants to use HMAS Tobruk to peddle our wares in South Asia on the way home from Gallipoli-a reprehensible intention.

Australia is a member of the World Bank and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is a governor of the World Bank. It is significant that the Director of the World Bank, Barber Conable, stated in a speech to the Board of Governors of the World Bank Group in Washington on 26 September this year:

As we think about the tasks of development in the coming years, we can no longer neglect a sensitive component of the fiscal problem: military spending. All countries have the sovereign right and responsibility to defend themselves. But let us hope that, in the changing political climate of the 1990s, resources are increasingly allocated to more productive purposes, in industrial countries as well as developing countries.

While there is much variation among developing countries, as a group low-income countries currently allocate around 20 per cent of central government budgets to defence. In the mid-1980s military spending in developing countries exceeded spending on health and education combined. While many components of national budgets have been cut, the $200 billion which the developed world spends annually on the military has largely been protected. And arms are often a prime source of external debt: military debts account for a third or more of total debt service in several large developing countries.

Developing countries on one side, and their arms suppliers and creditors on the other, must adapt to a world where budgets are tight. It is important to place military spending decisions on the same footing as other fiscal decisions, to examine possible trade-offs more systematically, and to explore ways to bring military spending into better balance with development priorities. In evaluating their military expenditures, Governments should be realistic, but they should also remember the human consequences of these choices.

So there we have it from the Governor of the World Bank. Yet Australia chooses to slash its overseas aid budget even further and then seeks to double the military exports instead. It is an amazing sense of priorities. Next month we have the spectacle of our national capital hosting the biggest arms bazaar ever held in the Southern Hemisphere-AIDEX 89-as the merchants of death from 15 countries come to the National Exhibition Centre to peddle their wares. To remind us of our wider responsibilities, Community Aid Abroad and Canberra Christians for Peace will be holding a `Swords into Ploughshares Exhibition' at the same time, and I invite those members of parliament who intend to visit AIDEX 89 to make sure that they visit the Community Aid Abroad's exhibition as well.

That leads me to my final point, the reduction in the Budget allocation for overseas aid, while defence continues to hold its own. As I pointed out on World Food Day, 770 million people in the world do not get enough food for an active working life while 14 million children die of hunger-related causes every year. To get it into perspective, Australia is choosing to spend $2.2 billion a year on new military equipment and capabilities, and half that sum on overseas aid. If we were to aim for the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of GDP, that would be roughly the same amount as the military is getting for its new military equipment. On 16 October, aid groups presented petitions bearing more than 35,000 signatures to Federal parliamentarians calling for an increase in aid to 0.5 per cent of GDP by 1992. This call echoes the recommendations of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its review of Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and Australia's overseas aid program which was delivered in February this year.

As the Australian Council for Overseas Aid reminded us last year, our overseas aid is now at the lowest point for more than 25 years, and after this year's Budget it is lower still. Aid now stands at 0.33 per cent of GDP compared to 0.51 per cent when the Hawke Government came to power and our highest level of 0.59 per cent in 1968. Again I must make the point that under a coalition government it would be even worse as its recently released tax policy indicated that overseas aid would be reduced by another $100m, putting us down among the really mean nations of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development group like the United States and Switzerland. I would commend to the Opposition the suggestion that it could have saved more than $2.7 billion by simply scrapping the eight Anzac class frigates or the six new submarines, a proposal which at least puts into perspective the enormous cost of military equipment and which other programs have to suffer to make way for new military capital equipment programs.

Behind my criticism of Budget expenditure on the military lies the question of where our real security lies. Does security mean being armed with the latest sophisticated military technology and allocating research funds for even more sophisticated projects or does it mean adequate housing, jobs, health care, care for the poor and less well-off in our society, justice for Aboriginal people, access to education for all, and preservation of the environment? When these problems in our society are so self-evident and crying out for research and support, why do we persist in allocating 9.6 per cent of Budget expenditure on looking for a non-existent threat? I believe that our external security could be better guaranteed in other ways than by building up the military, for example, through working for common security in the region rather than participating in a new arms race; by putting more emphasis on conflict resolution through non-military means; and by spending defence dollars on non-offensive defence rather than continuing to participate in an offensive nuclear alliance with a country on the other side of the world, and trying to act as a regional policeman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90, and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90. These Bills constitute the Government's Budget for the 1989-90 financial year. They, in fact, constitute the Hawke Government's seventh Budget in office. As a Government member I support these Bills. The Budget is a responsible and gimmick-free document. It is a document designed to advance Labor's long term vision of a more prosperous yet fairer Australia. In that way it is unlike the past Budgets of Liberal governments and the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Budget tackles Australia's problems with vision, consistency and compassion. It concentrates on getting the economic fundamentals right in the Australian economy, but it offers to the needy at the same time ongoing support and relief. It is in direct contrast to the desperation, division and despair offered by the Opposition and its so-called economic policies. This Budget will, as a result of the economic policies in it, slow down total spending in the economy and bring the economy to a soft landing and not a crash landing. Importantly, the Budget will develop economic conditions to bring about lower interest rates and not fuel even higher rates. Most importantly, the Budget will implement important social justice measures to assist all Australians without ignoring those most in need in our community.

Last year was characterised by exceptionally strong economic growth in the economy and exceptionally strong growth in the private sector. In fact, it was the strongest growth in private sector spending in two decades, the strongest growth since the 1960s. For example, Australia's gross national spending grew by 7.7 per cent. That is a measure of the total demand in the economy. At the same time, owing to supply constraints, our economy could only produce 3.3 per cent more. So with production growing at only 3.3 per cent we had a spillover of that higher demand in the Australian economy into imports and as a result an overseas deficit which grew in size directly as a result of that rapid growth in Australia.

The Government has taken the course of calling upon interest rates to slow down the economy but, of course, that has not been done in isolation. The Government itself has accepted unprecedented fiscal restraint in Australia. We have taken the step of restraining government spending to reduce demand, to reduce total spending in the community and, therefore, to tackle Australia's external imbalances by cutting import growth. It is worth noting that for the fourth year in succession real government outlays have been cut. They have been cut by the Hawke Labor Government. Four years in a row we have had real cuts in government spending. In fact, the ratio of government spending in real terms to Australia's gross domestic product-that is a broad measure of our national income-is now, under the Hawke Labor Government, at its lowest level in 16 years.

So much for the rhetoric from the other side that we have had to endure over the last five years in this place about high spending Labor governments. That rhetoric has totally been exposed by the fact that government spending, as a proportion of Australia's gross domestic product, is now at its lowest level in 16 years. It is expected that this financial year government spending will total some 23.7 per cent of gross domestic product compared with a much higher figure of around 30 per cent in 1984-85. So over five financial years we have seen a reduction of around 6 to 7 percentage points. In other words, it is a dramatic reduction in the share of government spending in gross domestic product.

As shown in this Government's Forward Estimates, we will maintain social security spending at compassionate levels: I am pleased to note that the existing fiscal policy, without any further changes and without any further cuts in programs, will ensure that total government spending as a proportion of gross domestic product will fall further and within three years should fall to around 22 per cent of gross domestic product. That means that the figures will be back to those of around the 1950s. Again, it exposes the rhetoric from the other side for what it is. Liberal and National Party senators time and time again, day after day, month after month, claimed in this place that the Labor Government was the highest spending government. That claim has been exposed as pure rhetoric. This year we are expecting a Budget surplus of $9.1 billion-that is, $9,100m-more in government receipts than government expenditure through the Commonwealth Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't talked much about your extra tax receipts.
—Senator Brownhill talks about extra tax receipts. One of the reasons we have had extra tax receipts in the Federal Budget is the sheer growth in the real economy that we are operating at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tate, my economic adviser, points out, more workers are now paying tax in the Australian economy than ever before. The reason is that more people have jobs. It is a great contrast to the early 1980s when 186,000 Australians were thrown on the scrap heap in one year while the policies of Senator Stone and Mr Howard were in place. In addition, tax receipts in that period were very dismal because of the number of people thrown out of work who were not earning any incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: The surplus of $9,100m this year is a very large figure. It compares with a surplus last financial year of $5,900m. This year's Commonwealth Budget surplus is only the third in 37 years, a remarkable achievement. That is a massive turnaround of the position we inherited on coming to government in March 1983 when the prospective deficit for 1983-84 under the Liberals was to have been $9,600m. The $9,100m surplus for the current financial year has to be compared with a prospective deficit, not a surplus, of $9,600m under the Liberals. Under the Hawke Government, the Budget surpluses have funded the largest single package of income tax cuts and family assistance ever provided by an Australian government. That is the reality. The Hawke Government has provided for a significant boost to family income, especially for low to middle income earners. The Government has also used its last three Budget surpluses to pay off government debt. Using just the last two Budget surpluses to pay off debt has already saved Australia $2,000m in interest payments, a remarkable figure. As a result of these measures, the Federal Government will now owe no overseas debt on a net basis.

Sixty-one per cent of Australia's overseas debt is private sector debt and we have witnessed the unscrambling of some of the takeovers in recent times which have been funded by that debt. Thirty-nine per cent of the debt belongs to State governments and instrumentalities in government hands. In six years, the Hawke Labor Government has turned around the Commonwealth Budget from borrowing around 6.2 per cent of gross domestic product in 1983-84-that is, our borrowings were equivalent to around 6.2 per cent of GDP-to a net repayment this financial year of 2.5 per cent of GDP, a very big improvement in the circumstances.

The accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions on incomes policy has played a vital role in the Government's overall Budget strategy. In the past, whenever the economy was overheated with excess demand, wage breakouts broke the back of the economy and led to massive unemployment. Despite the overheating of the economy in the last year or so, wage increases have been contained, a remarkable achievement. It is a remarkable commitment by the working people of Australia that, despite the fact that the circumstances for very large wage rises were there, wages growth has been contained despite a very rapidly growing economy.

Our record is that 1.6 million new jobs have been created under the Hawke Government. I well remember that in 1983 when Mr Hawke promised 500,000 new jobs over the first three years of his Government, Opposition members scoffed. They said it was not possible to create half a million new jobs over three years. They scoffed repeatedly; they tried to ridicule the claim; but they had to eat their words because not only were the 500,000 new jobs created in the first three years of office, they were also created way ahead of the appointed time. It is a reality now that the annual rate of employment growth under the Government is six times what the Liberals were able to achieve in office. One of the reasons we have had rapid employment growth is that we have had an investment boom in Australia. For example, private sector spending on investment last year grew by 16 per cent; in other words, the total amount of investment went up by one-sixth in one financial year under a Labor government.

These are tangible achievements and clearly they are not gimmicks. They are in stark contrast to the Liberal Party's economic document which was published recently. That document fails to address the long term issues facing the Australian economy. It looks only at the next election and it is very clearly a blatant and naked grab for votes. The Opposition's so-called economic plan offers no alternative policy to the economic problems facing Australia. In their document, the Liberals boast about tightening fiscal policy, but when one analyses the policy document one sees that it proposes nothing that would reduce total net spending. I would like Opposition members to come forward and show me how it does. Certainly it then proposes to obtain additional revenue by dumping the people in our community most in need, the poor. The poorest members of our community would be dumped by the policies of the Liberal Party if ever it got into power. There is a very self-seeking assumption behind all that and that is that the poor and the needy in our community do not vote for the Liberal Party. I think that is the assumption behind the policy document at that point.

The Liberals boast that they will lower interest rates. That is the claim they are making on the hustings around Australia, but their so-called economic plan offers no scope to ease monetary policy. I again challenge members of the Opposition to come forward and show me and other members of the Government how their policy would reduce interest rates by easing monetary policy. Most interestingly in the policy document, the Liberals promise to give back the proceeds of what they call bracket creep. I suppose that is defined as the effect of inflation on tax brackets, the fact that due to price rises employees are pushed into higher tax brackets and that there are therefore some artificial elements in the tax that they pay due to an inflationary process. Therefore, the Liberals have promised in their policy document to give back the proceeds of bracket creep. However, the July tax cuts given by the Hawke Government this year, funded by the Budget, more than offset the effect of bracket creep since 1983 when the Government was elected. The tax cuts that have already been given this year and are in the pay packets of Australian wage and salary earners have already more than offset any effect of inflation on tax brackets since 1983.

As a candidate for the House of Representatives in the 1975 Federal election, I well remember Liberal Party spokespersons going around Australia promising to remove bracket creep. They gave a very categorical undertaking during the 1975 election campaign to index tax brackets for inflation and to remove bracket creep. In fact, Mr Fraser in his 1975 policy speech promised to end taxation by stealth due to inflation. It is an interesting history and it is worth examining what the Liberal Party did in government because it is now going to the Australian people saying that it will end bracket creep, the inflationary effect on tax brackets. It is always a good test of conservative politicians to see what they do in government, because so often the reality is at odds with the rhetoric.

It is fascinating to see what the Liberal Party did in government in the 1970s in regard to tax indexation. It brought it in for the 1976-77 financial year and maintained it for the 1977-78 financial year. But the story basically ends there because Mr Howard, who became the Treasurer in 1978, halved the indexation factor in the 1978-79 financial year. He said that indexation of tax brackets was too expensive. The Liberal Government would not protect people against bracket creep. He therefore halved the indexation factor. He had only half indexation again in 1980-81 and eventually the Liberal Party threw out the window the whole idea of adjusting for bracket creep, of indexing tax brackets to inflation. The line taken by the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the then Treasurer, Mr Howard-and no doubt by Senator Stone in his previous incarnation as Secretary to the Treasury jealously protecting the nation's revenues-was that it was a crazy idea and that if they really wanted a political effect with tax cuts it was better to have discretionary tax cuts. During the late 1970s and early 1980s senior Liberals were on the public record as saying that tax indexation does not win votes. They said that it was better to have discretionary tax cuts from time to time. The Liberals believe that votes can be bought more effectively in that way. Again they are talking about tax cuts. However, the reality is that, in the late 1970s and early 1980s, they had the chance to do something about tax brackets; but they squibbed that idea, they scrapped it and they returned to the previous system.

To fulfil the claim that senior Liberals make, namely, that they would index the tax brackets, would require an additional $2,000m of government revenue in the first year and another $4,000m by 1992, which would make it a very expensive measure indeed. One can only speculate about where the money would come from to replace the revenue that would be lost because of the removal of bracket creep-if ever the Liberals honoured that promise. One can only conclude, and rest assured, that the Liberals would soon be introducing a consumption tax to find the revenue needed to cover the loss caused by that change in income tax brackets.

In the past decade, Mr Peacock has been on record calling for a consumption tax on more occasions than he has said that he does not want one. I invite honourable senators to consult the parliamentary database that is available to all of them. If they key in the words `tax indexation' and `consumption tax' and consider Mr Peacock's role, they will find that time and time again Mr Peacock has called for the introduction of a consumption tax. On very few occasions has he called for no consumption tax.

By going down that path the Liberals are pursuing Thatcherite policies. I believe that that is the best way of describing the Liberal Party's policies. It is Thatcherism at its worst. The Liberals model much of what they say they would do on the Thatcher model in Britain. The Liberals worship Mrs Thatcher and her policies. That is clear from the repeated pilgrimages that have been made by conservative politicians from Canberra to No. 10 Downing Street to worship at the feet of Mrs Thatcher. Clearly, the Liberals are Thatcherite politicians. Like us, they believe in redistribution but, unlike us, they believe in the redistribution of resources from low and middle income people to the well off in the community. That is the way that the Liberals would behave in government. They would also carry out bargain basement sales of Australia's vital public assets. In doing so, they would somehow claim in a Thatcherite way that that would boost the economy and economic growth.

Mrs Thatcher has created two Britains-a divided country: an affluent south and a depressed north. I am sure that, in government, the Liberals would create two Australias. They would give to the already privileged and would take away from the needy and the deserving. It is very interesting to note that, this year, despite the so-called Thatcher economic miracle in Britain, Italy's gross domestic product has overtaken that of Britain. It is an interesting sign of the times that one of the relatively poorer members of the European Community around the Mediterranean region has overtaken Britain's gross domestic product at the same time as Mrs Thatcher is proclaiming an economic miracle in her country.

In the time that is available to me I wish to speak briefly about the effect of the policies of the Hawke Government on the State of South Australia. At the regional level, it is very interesting to note how the budgetary policies of the Hawke Government have impacted and how, at the same time as there has been a national expansion of the economy, important benefits have been enjoyed at the local level. The reality is that the economic recovery that has occurred in South Australia under the Hawke and Bannon Labor governments has been remarkable.

In 1982, the South Australian economy under the Liberals was in tatters. During the three years of Liberal government from 1979 to 1982, the unemployment rate in South Australia soared to become the highest in mainland Australia. Business confidence and employment slumped. It is interesting to note that, since 1983, under the joint policies of the Hawke Federal Labor Government and the Bannon South Australian Labor Government, 120,000 extra jobs have been created in South Australia and 11,000 persons have been removed from the unemployment tally in that State. It is a tremendous achievement that, because of the expansion of the economy, 11,000 fewer people are unemployed. Cost of living increases have been cut enormously and, in particular, industry has returned to South Australia.

I should like to discuss how a region is affected by sensible and sound economic policies at the national level. In the three months to March 1983, that is, in the period spilling over from the Liberal Government in South Australia and the Fraser, Howard and Stone Federal Government in Canberra, the average unemployment rate in South Australia had reached double digits. In fact, under those misguided policies the unemployment rate had reached 10.6 per cent. Indeed, in one month at the beginning of 1983, the South Australian jobless rate rose to over 11 per cent. In other words, one person in nine who was seeking work in that State was unable to obtain employment because of the misguided policies of Liberal State and Federal governments. That shameful legacy could be compared very starkly with the reality in 1989. While there was 10.6 per cent unemployment in 1983, in the three months to March 1989 the unemployment rate had been reduced to 7.7 per cent. Although that is a major improvement, the figure is still too high and more has to be done. However, it shows what can be achieved when Federal and State Labor governments work together.

The position in regard to unemployment among teenagers is demonstrated even more clearly. For example, in the three months to March 1983, South Australia's unemployment rate among teenagers was absolutely horrendous. Under Liberal governments in Canberra and in Adelaide, very few employment opportunities existed for teenagers in South Australia. Because of Liberal Party policies, 27 per cent of young people in South Australia were unemployed. This year, that figure has been cut by 10 percentage points to 17 per cent, which is still far too high although it is certainly well down on the reality under Liberal governments in 1983. Clearly, under Labor governments, more opportunities exist for teenagers in South Australia.

One of the acid tests used by economists to examine the position in the labour market is to relate the number of unemployed persons to each job vacancy. That gives them an idea of how tight the labour market is and how conditions are generally in the labour market at a particular time. It is interesting to note that, in May 1983, just after the election of the Federal Labor Government and, therefore, basically still under the economic conditions that were laid down by the Liberals, 69 persons were unemployed for every job vacancy in South Australia. In May 1989, under a Federal Labor government and a State Labor government, that figure was reduced from 69 to 16, which was a tremendous reduction in the unemployed to job vacancy ratio. That demonstrates what can be achieved when consistent economic policies are adopted by the Federal Government and the State Government working in cooperation.

I turn now to inflation and price rises. Once again the Liberals are making a lot of noise about inflation and about how they would somehow decrease the rate of growth of price rises in the Australian community. Let me cite some figures. In the 12 months to March 1983-again as a result of Liberal Party policies being in operation at the Federal level and at the State level-the consumer price index for Adelaide showed an increase of 12.1 per cent. In the 12 months to March 1983, which was the very month when the Fraser Government was thrown out, consumer prices in Adelaide increased by almost one-eighth. That was the reality under the Liberals; despite their rhetoric, there was a massive increase in consumer prices. By contrast, in the 12 months to March 1989, consumer prices in Adelaide did not increase by 12 per cent, 11 per cent, 10 per cent, 9 per cent or even 8 per cent; they rose by only 7.5 per cent. I personally regard that figure as being too high, but surely even members of the Liberal Party can see a remarkable transformation in the inflation index. The reality is that there was double-digit inflation, in South Australia and nationally, under the Liberals just as there was double-digit unemployment under their policies. They had the great double-double-digit unemployment and double-digit inflation. We have slashed the inflation rate, to a March figure of 7.5 per cent in my capital city. So clearly Labor does better in managing the inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh? Input costs are rising at over 10 per cent.

—Senator Brownhill is carping over there, but let us look at the housing industry. We have heard rhetoric and crocodile tears for the last six months from members of the Opposition about interest rates. Time and time again members of the Opposition make claims about how they will get interest rates down, but let us have a look at the reality. Let us look at how interest rates really influence the economy. Let us look at their impact on new dwelling commencements, because that clearly shows the difference between Liberal Party claims and Labor Party achievements. In the 12 months to March 1983, under a Liberal Government in Canberra and a Liberal Government in Adelaide, 7,600 dwellings were commenced in South Australia. That is the reality. I did not make the figures up; they come from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. But to March this year, under a Labor government in Canberra and a Labor government in Adelaide, and despite high interest rates, the real bricks and mortar figures show that 9,800 dwellings were commenced in South Australia. So there is the Liberal record-7,600 new dwellings started, compared to 9,800 new dwellings started in South Australia this year despite high interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: This really exposes the hollowness of the Liberal Party analysis of the economy. The Liberals think everything is affected by interest rates. They think everything political is affected by interest rates. But they have forgotten-and I hope they learn this lesson-that more people have the ability to service a loan because under Labor at least they have jobs. That is the reality-there have been 1.6 million new jobs under this Labor Government. So the Liberals are focusing on one part of the equation, interest rates, but the reality is that despite the level of interest rates 2,200 more dwellings were commenced in South Australia in the year up to March than in the whole of the 12 months to March 1983 under the Liberals.

So the Federal Budget this year consolidates progress since 1983. It is a sensible, economic and rational Budget. It recognises that if we are to develop Australia and improve our living standards, we have to stabilise our debt, we have to solve our balance of payments difficulties, and continue to restructure. This Budget does more than that. A Labor government will continue to create jobs, give greater hope to our young and to our elderly, and provide real benefits to those who depend on a sense of fairness and justice for support.
