SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -In the debate today on the Appropriation Bills, I wish to direct my remarks to the higher education sector in Australia and to the budgetary decisions made with regard to that sector. The Australian Democrats believe that the main influence on the balancing of higher education should be student demand. We believe that our community has a responsibility to give all those qualified and motivated to study the opportunity to study what they wish, and the necessary corollary of that is that students need to be taught what experts within various discipline areas believe the various subjects demand. It should be noted that neither of these fundamental propositions includes what bureaucrats or politicians in Canberra think. We believe that the current attempt to base present educational plans on what bureaucrats or politicians perceive future needs to be is very risky indeed, given a dynamic society, a rapidly changing knowledge base in most discipline areas, and different perceptions of vocational needs based on societal change.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of manpower needs embraced by this Government in a fervour to do at last some long-range planning is an extremely tenuous one and susceptible to enormous shifts, often, unfortunately, recognised only in hindsight-which of course by definition is too late for forward planning. While we may think tentative forecasts can be made-for example in the public sector professions which are under the control of planned policies, such as teaching and nursing-the experience in this country has shown that even these predictions are dodgy in the extreme and are in fact a poor substitute for the sum of half a million individual decisions made each year about courses taken in our higher education institutions.

At the end of the day, if people do not want to do the courses that politicians want them to do there is not much that can be done about it. In any event, decisions about course preference at universities are made well prior to entrance to such universities. It follows that in order to develop an interest in science or engineering, or whatever discipline area the Government is currently attempting to promote, strong support must be given in the pre-university education system. We are not talking about university policy when we talk about first-year choice of careers at universities. We are talking about schools which of course are already under impossible pressures to fix up all the other ills in society. Of course in considering career choice we should not neglect the other area of obvious pressure, and that is career incentives. Encouraging students to take up maths teaching, for example, is likely to fall mainly on deaf ears if the present remuneration and conditions of employment offered by our State governments continue as they are at present.

I turn to the vexed problem of funding and the use to date of funds expended. A reasonable starting point for discussion could be 1975, since that was the year that expenditure on higher education as a proportion of gross domestic product peaked, at 1.36 per cent. Between 1975 and now general recurrent grants for higher education as a whole increased by 20 per cent. However, in the same period higher education enrolments increased by 42 per cent-double the increase in the general recurrent grant. It is obvious from this that the only reason that university doors are still open, although universities are bursting at the seams, is that the university sector has shown the strongest growth in productivity of any sector in the Australian economy. The universities have done more with less and at the same time have achieved a significant quality increment as well. Oh that other sectors of our economy could have done likewise!

Unfortunately, this efficiency increase has been submerged under political rhetoric from the Government and a concerted attempt has been made to convince the general population that universities had been asleep until the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) decided to wake them up. The obvious silliness of that campaign is evident every time one goes into a doctor's surgery or a lawyer's office, or drives on freeways designed by our Australian engineers or seeks the services of any of the large number of professionals educated in our own higher education institutions.

A recent development that has been greatly accentuated by government criticisms is that the job satisfaction for academics is rapidly deteriorating. Falling salaries in comparative terms, dramatic increases in student loads, the loss of tenure and the heavy decrease in study leave have meant that academic positions have lost a lot of their attractiveness. Many disciplines are now finding that the availability of top quality lecturers and professors cannot be guaranteed on the current conditions. The cavalier attacks for political gain have been at enormous cost to scholarship, and at even greater cost to the ongoing health of many of our professions. Ill-informed comments have had their effects in the real world. Ill-judged removal of academic support such as tenure can only be rectified at great expense.

The benefits of a university education and research accrue to the whole of the society and thus support from public sources is eminently justifiable. However, the society needs to be careful that higher education institutions do not have their independence eroded by that reliance on public funding. Although Professor Veliz's comment that we now have `a single Australian university with 20 campuses following policies emanating from the bureaucratic heart of the country' is a slight overstatement, the new educational profiles that institutions have to submit have the potential to achieve such a result. As other commentators have noted, it may not be so much a unified national system as a uniform national system lacking the diversity and character that our higher education sector both desires and needs.

However, the present Federal Government has gone much further than any previous government in seeing universities as a tool with which to reshape the economy. Universities are international institutions, and to impose a tight national direction on them will, of necessity, negate their very purpose. A university must consider and present many points of view, not just those of the party in power. Unfortunately, although universities have always been receptive to external trends and needs, they have been slow to pick up on the game of populace politics and have let the community know that its needs were being responded to by higher education institutions. Unfortunately, until recently most universities were seen as being detached from the society, whereas the reality was quite different.

I wish to turn now to the current fad of amalgamations. Educational benefits said to result from the amalgamation of institutions include a greater choice of subject, better library resources, better computer services and better research facilities. Indeed, the list of benefits attributed to amalgamation is only exceeded by those proposed for other snake oil remedies from earlier this century. The truth of the matter is that most of these claimed advantages will only be available to students where the amalgamating institutions are on adjoining campuses, and even in such circumstances there is absolutely no evidence to show that such advantages could not be gained through different managerial practices. Indeed, if one looks around the world, the size of institutions seems to be an independent variable not linked to any predictable outcome-educational or otherwise.

However, the problems associated with amalgamations are clear. For a number of years, the operation of the amalgamated institution will be impaired owing to the differing natures and government profile of the partners involved. The difficulty in forming an educational profile and administration which are acceptable to all partners is plain. The extremely large costs involved in combining institutions are already becoming evident. For example, the cost of merging the University of Western Australia with Murdoch University looks like reaching about $50m. This is $50m which will not be available for teaching, research and scholarship.

It is odd that our management schools throughout Australia are going to be teaching their students the organisational advantages in accountability and flexibility that small, autonomous units have compared to large hierarchies while this teaching is to take place in institutions which have just got lumbered with more levels of management and less transparent channels of communication. Unfortunately, I believe many of the amalgamations currently under way are motivated more by the fear of funding cuts to small institutions than by a belief that such amalgamations will be of direct benefit to students. One can only wonder at how the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) arrived at his magical figure of 8,000 students to ensure full funding.

It is interesting to recall some well known and highly regarded institutions which, in the Australian context, would be required to amalgamate. They include Princeton University, which has a little over 6,000 students; Brown University, with a little over 7,000; Dartmouth College, Radcliffe College and Tufts University, all in the United States and all with international reputations. In Great Britain, the University of St Andrews has 3,800 students; the University of Bath has 3,600 and the University of Aberdeen has 7,200. All of those universities would get the chop. To become a member of the Government's unified national system institutions will be submitting both an educational profile and an estimate of funds required-with the Government funding only the approved activities. The profile process allows the Minister to negotiate directly with institutions, in the absence of any detailed guidelines, on the most basic things which universities do-yet to date not one shred of evidence has been produced by the Government to show that previous measures of public accountability were deficient. Indeed, I have already demonstrated that the university sector has been the most productive sector in our economy.

Membership of the unified national system will entail commitment to `more managerial modes of operation', greater delegation of policy implementation to chief executive officers so that vice-chancellors will be able to negotiate agreements with the Minister or his Department without delay, commitment to the Government's equity policy and plans for credit transfers, acceptance of the need for more staff incentives and arrangements for further training and to a common academic year. Although it remains to be seen how the educational profiles will finally be administered, there is no doubt that the new policy gives the Minister enormous powers if he chooses to use them.

As government control of higher education increases, there is the risk of uniformity across institutions if a government stays in power for a long enough time, or for an unstable situation to develop if governments at this level are changed rapidly. Further, any dissent from the institutions will easily be able to be stifled under threat of funding cuts. In the past the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission provided a valuable buffer between government and the institutions having the statutory powers to both monitor and publicly report on interactions between the two bodies. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's successor, the new National Board of Employment, Education and Training, is not as well equipped to carry out this task. While the power of the new Board was significantly increased by the 35 amendments which I successfully introduced to the Bill, the Minister has severely limited its ability to conduct independent analysis and reporting by providing it with only a minimal staff.

The White Paper claims that university administrations should look to private industry as a guide to appropriate administrative structures. At the same time, however, the paper suggests a composition of governing bodies which is vastly different to that of the private sector. In the large conglomerate universities the greater spread of course levels and of staff and student abilities and the additional spatial problems are likely to make them more bureaucratic organisations unless they are able to give their constituent bodies independence of a kind, at least, ironically, on a campus basis as a geographical starting point.

The notion of deregulating the system and turning it over to market forces, while attractive to a government which is under massive economic pressures, nevertheless fails to account for the role of tertiary education in preserving or modifying socioeconomic inequalities. One cannot expect private universities to undertake non-profit community development. They are not in the business of helping to right wrongs. That is not a criticism of them; it is merely a statement of fact. As has been discovered at the secondary level, the state cannot opt out completely since some coordination is necessary to prevent increases in inequality because of accidents, history or location.

The Government has not had all its own way in the wider debate. Oddly enough, a best seller in the United States of America has attacked the very parts of the American system which this Government aspires to implement in this country. Alan Bloom's best seller, The Closing of the American Mind, argues strongly that universities should stand for the highest and the best, should pose an alternative to whatever is popular or trendy, and should nourish imagination and creativity and a love for knowledge. He says that universities should not succumb to the idea that more is better and, above all, should oppose market measures of success, including cost-benefit analysis modelled on the banks. I think that at least these parts of Bloom's book should find a great deal of resonance in the breasts of many Australians seeking to preserve what is good in our own historical tradition of higher education.

Unfortunately, one senses a certain anti-intellectual strand creeping into the Government, coupled with an irritation that universities do not embrace wholeheartedly the entrepreneurial and materialistic culture, and a distrust of institutions whose job it is to question policies and ideas. The Government's debate has taken methods of financing and overall control and defined them as the dominant concerns of a university. This is a university defined in its balance sheet, not in its mission statement. I am indebted to Professor Manderson for her inaugural address at the University of Queensland in September this year when she reminded me of that marvellous play by Brecht, The Life of Galileo. I cite passages she referred to in her inaugural address. At this particular part of the play the curator or registrar of the University of Padua responds to Galileo's requests for more funds thus:

I cannot recommend this to the University. You know that at the present time the mathematical faculty is no attraction at a university. Mathematics is a profitless art, so to speak. Not that the Republic does not esteem it most highly. It is not as necessary as philosophy, nor as useful as theology, but it affords its devotees endless pleasures.

It is interesting how times change. One can hear Mr Dawkins acknowledging the relevance of all disciplines as he has done time and again at various universities: it is just that some are more relevant than others and in times of economic restraint we must all tighten our belts and put the shoulder to the wheel. We have heard that ad nauseam from the people who write his speeches. I want to quote directly from Professor Manderson's lecture because I think she got it exactly right when she said:

. . . the agenda that determines `relevance' is plastic, malleable and deeply political. There is no assurance that today's priorities will be those of tomorrow, that the ground might not shift so dramatically as to render current programs inconsequential. We have few skills to anticipate the intellectual and technical demands of, say the year 2020. To meet these unforseen future needs we have a basic responsibility to maintain our intellectual as well as our natural resources. Some of these resources are as elusive or as intangible as the value of an untouched rainforest or the beauty of a sunset. If the purpose of the university is to provide a home to these intellectual resources, its role is to sustain and to nurture them.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. At the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Conference on 25 October Mr Ross Adler, Managing Director of Santos Ltd, commented that the Government's partial deregulation of the liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) industry was as cumbersome and inequitable as the fully regulated market. Does the Minister agree with Mr Adler?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I perhaps should congratulate Santos on achieving for this quarter a profit of $145m, up from a profit of $117m for the same quarter last year. Going to the question, the Government took earlier this year a major step forward in its micro-economic reform strategy by introducing the partial deregulation of the LPG market.
—You are really stretching things.

—Well, it was a reform from the regulated market that obtained under Senator Stone's period of government, and one that we inherited. As I say, we did move to partially deregulate that market earlier in the year. Prior to that, the maximum wholesale price for LPG in Australia was set by a formula applied by the Government every six months. Earlier this year, we asked the Prices Surveillance Authority to set the maximum wholesale rate and maintained our export control powers in order not to interfere in the market but to ensure that the supply of gas to the local market rather than overseas was maintained. Those steps followed a long period of consultation with the industry, based on a discussion paper that we had issued for an orderly discussion.

ANSWER.PARA: It is fair to say that in that discussion period producers of LPG, Santos being one of them, argued for an immediate and total deregulation of the market and smaller consumers and a number of regional and local government authorities asked for the retention of full regulation. In asking for the retention of full regulation, members of the House of Representatives-Peter McGauran, Ian Sinclair, Charles Blunt, Noel Hicks, John Sharp, Ian Robinson, Tim Fischer and Wal Fife-supported regulation by regional local government authorities. In this chamber Senator Brownhill supported a claim for regulation by some of the local government authorities as well.

Weighing all the factors, the Government moved to partial deregulation on the basis that it wanted to provide a period to phase in change and to enable a number of infrastructural alterations to occur. I think our steps have been found to be justified. Major infrastructure improvement has occurred. There has been an upgrading of the LPG pipeline to the Dandenong truck loading facility, and a new truck loading facility is now being built at Hastings, Victoria, which will be completed in June. They will overcome supply blockages for LPG around Australia or, at least, in that area of Australia.

This year has been a difficult year for the local LPG market, but we have not exercised our export control powers to prevent the export of LPG either. So Mr Adler's complaint of further regulation or more difficulty is, at least according to the record, not a justified complaint because we have not held up or stopped any exports overseas. Rather, we have preferred that the situation be one of phasing to fuller deregulation.

The Prices Surveillance Authority has considered the question of the wholesale price and has awarded wholesale price increases in LPG which are above the formula that the old government regulation approach would have provided. So the producers have in fact got a better return than would have been provided for under the old formula. Despite the National Party of Australia in the House and one of its representatives in this chamber being against the putting aside of much of this regulation, the Government intends to move to full deregulation, but in a phased way so that the market can accommodate the changes as we go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications that on Monday of this week he tried to explain conflicting figures quoted by Government Ministers by saying that, whatever measures are used, the airlines have restored `a substantial amount of capacity-much larger than that suggested by independent observers and, of course, by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots'. Has the Minister noted the report in today's Australian that air traffic control records show that landings and departures are currently running at about one-third of the normal level? Even allowing for the fact that some of the imported planes have slightly larger capacity than the normal domestic aircraft, does the Minister not agree that the claimed capacity in excess of 50 or 60 per cent-the figures that the Government has been using-significantly overstate the true position? Is it a fact that neither the Civil Aviation Authority nor the Department of Transport and Communications is making an independent assessment and that the figures that the Government keeps quoting are supplied by the airlines? Finally, with this dispute very much alive and now in its twelfth week, does the Government accept Sir Peter Abeles's prediction that Ansett Airlines of Australia will be meeting 83 per cent of capacity next month and 100 per cent in January?

—Once again, the Pilots Federation is proving to be a very poor adviser to the Opposition. The situation is that the air traffic records of daily flight movements supplied to the Civil Aviation Authority on a regular basis provide information on the number of aircraft movements through various airports in Australia; but they take several weeks to flow through the system before being compiled by the Civil Aviation Authority and, as a timely measure of capacity, are simply not reliable. They also fail, as Senator Newman in effect acknowledged in passing in her question, to measure seating capacity; rather, they relate just to the numbers of aircraft. What we are talking about here is the question of capacity. I did a pretty good job of answering Senator Newman's question on Monday, and I have nothing further to add today.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether there is any connection between his announcement of an agreement with Indonesia on a Zone of Cooperation Agreement between Australia and Indonesia on the Timor Gap and reports of new Australian aid to East Timor. Also, in view of Portugal's reported criticism of our negotiations with Indonesia on a Timor Gap treaty last year, what is the Government's attitude to Portugal's concern in all this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich has added a few embellishments to the question that I had in mind in this respect. The only connection between the two developments to which he referred is the Australian Government's clear-cut policy of recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor-a policy that was first adopted by the then Government in 1979 and which was reaffirmed by the present Government by prime ministerial statement on 22 August 1985. The Prime Minister, in making the point in 1985, made it clear that recognition of Indonesian sovereignty had permitted us to pursue human rights and aid issues in the province and that negotiations over the Timor Gap sea bed could in reality only take place with Indonesia. Certainly, successive Australian governments-not just ourselves but our predecessors-have taken the view that the only practical way to assist the people of East Timor is to work through the Indonesian authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of bilateral aid, I took the initiative during the visit of Foreign Minister Ali Alatas in March to ask him about the Indonesian Government's opening of East Timor-the adoption of moves by the Government to open East Timor by putting it on the same civilian administration footing as other provinces, and the permitting of significantly freer movement to and from the province from elsewhere in Indonesia, while at the same time more readily granting access to foreigners, including Australian journalists. Against the background of that very significant policy development during the year, I asked my counterpart whether we might extend our bilateral aid effort in Indonesia to this province in addition to the quite substantial financial contributions Australia has been making for many years to the aid programs of international agencies operating in East Timor.

Subsequent consultations with the Indonesian planning authorities identified the agricultural sector as a top priority for Australian bilateral aid in East Timor. Our Ambassador in Jakarta, Mr Phil Flood, took the opportunity during his first visit to the province last week to announce a grant of $100,000 under the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau's small activities scheme to assist farmers there through the demonstration of improved but simple technologies relevant to their needs. I hope that in future we will be able to upgrade the amount of direct bilateral aid to that province.

In relation to the second part of the question, concerning the Portuguese reaction to the announced conclusion of the Timor Gap negotiations, the Portuguese Ambassador did call on me yesterday on instructions from his Government to reiterate earlier Portuguese statements that Australia's signature to and ratification, in due course, of the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation Treaty would, in the view of the Portuguese, constitute a breach of international law. The Ambassador also stated again that Portugal would take due action after the signing of the Treaty in what he described as appropriate international forums and organisations. Similar representations were made a day earlier to our Ambassador in Lisbon.

I made it clear, in reply to the Portuguese Ambassador, that should Portugal seek to initiate any action in any forum, Australia would defend its position with vigour and determination. We are quite confident of our legal position on this matter. I have already indicated this in the Senate in more detail than it is necessary to go into now-in the adjournment debate of 20 March 1986 and in Question Time on 18 October last year. I should add, though, that we have taken the view since 1979 that whatever the unhappy circumstances and indeed, possible illegality, surrounding Indonesia's acquisition of East Timor in the mid-1970s, Indonesian sovereignty over that territory should be accepted not only on a de facto basis but on a de jure basis. There is no binding legal obligation not to recognise the acquisition of territory that was acquired by force. Such a recognition does not, of course, imply approval of the circumstances of the acquisition. In international law the legality of the original acquisition of territory by a state has to be distinguished in subsequent dealings between the state acquiring that new territory and other states-in this instance, Australia.

The last point I want to make is that Australia has consistently supported discussions between Portugal and Indonesia under the auspices of the United Nations Secretary-General to resolve the lingering East Timor issue as it exists between those two countries. That is a matter that relates to the dispute between Portugal and Indonesia, to which Australia is not a party, and is quite separate from the Timor Gap negotiations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a statement made by Mr Blunt on the 25th of last month. The statement raises two major points. ANSWER.PARA: In another part of the question I am asked whether this matter was discussed when I was doing the initial planning of the Government's policy, which was ultimately completed when Senator Evans was the responsible Minister, the framework for which was established when I was the responsible Minister. —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I draw the Minister's attention to a publication entitled Investment Monitor written by the economics consulting firm, Access Economics. Is it the case that if most of the investment projects listed in this publication come on stream there will be a substantial boost to Australia's export and import replacement capacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question raised by Senator Childs has been very much in the public debate.
—I have not heard it mentioned.

—Then Senator Stone will be listening avidly to my response. —Senator Stone knows this well as he has been forecasting recessions for years now and they have never come. I think there is much greater evidence of credibility in terms of the Investment Monitor forecast. It says that investment is going into a broad range of industries. That is correct.

ANSWER.PARA: Business investment increased by 15.5 per cent in 1988-89 and expectations for investment in this financial year remain high. I must make the point that it is taking place over a wide range of industries, including tourism and a wide spread of the manufacturing sector such as transport equipment, paper and printing, food processing and ferrous metals. In that sense it is in sharp contrast to the so-called investment boom of the early 1980s which was peddled around the country by the Opposition when it was in government. The earlier boom was dominated by mining and mineral processing, particularly aluminium. Some critics have said that this current investment phase merely involves modernising current productive capacity rather than greenfield projects. That is not necessarily true. It is inevitable that the nature of industry and investment patterns change.

If the Opposition cared to speak to the industry I think it would find out a great deal about new capacity being installed. For example, I took out a list today which showed investment already under way in basic metals in excess of $2 billion, in chemicals $420m, in pulp and paper $200m and in food processing $270m. I think the criticism also misses the point that modernising existing outmoded capacity also contributes to our export and import competing performance. The Government is justified in being pleased with this new investment surge which followed many years of poor investment performance in Australia, particularly through the 1970s. Substantial improvement in profits over recent years as a result of a variety of factors has been the major influence behind the strength in business investment. This influence has been reinforced by reductions in the size of the public sector in its borrowing requirements.

Dr Ed Shann, the author of the Investment Monitor, described this investment phase as a recipe for an export boom. The publication identifies six major investment projects close to completion that will generate nearly $5 billion extra export revenue per year. Other projects identified also have the potential for earning an additional $5 billion from exports within a few years. The essential point is that investment will certainly be a large and welcome boost to the supply side capacity of the Australian economy for many years to come. Although any projections, such as those contained in the Investment Monitor, must be treated with some caution, there is a lot of evidence in the pipeline already that many of the projections will be fulfilled.

DEBATE.TITLE: REFORM OF THE AUSTRALIAN AUDIT OFFICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) on the reform of the Australian Audit Office (AAO). It is government policy to respond within six months of such a report being presented. That response is about three weeks overdue. If anybody is to blame for that, either I or the Government or both are to blame. The Department of Finance did have its response prepared in time. I seek leave to make a statement on the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry by the JCPA into the reform of the Australian Audit Office is one of the most significant inquiries undertaken by the Committee. The Government welcomes the Committee's report on the reform of the Australian Audit Office-the first major external review of the AAO since Federation-and the debate which has ensued as a result of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office has a special place in our institutional structures: it is rightly regarded as one of the major instruments that can contribute to efficient and accountable public administration. The Office was established by the Audit Act 1901-the fourth Act of the Australian Parliament following Federation. Similarly it was no accident that that Act, and subsequent amendments to it, have provided for the independence of the Auditor-General from both the Executive and the Parliament. It is common ground in this chamber that the independence of the Auditor-General is fundamental to his or her role and it cannot be compromised.

Since this Government came to power in 1983 we have introduced significant and wide-ranging reforms in the Commonwealth public sector. They include major budgetary and financial management initiatives and fundamental changes to the machinery of government. We are also in the process of reshaping Government business enterprises. All these reforms have been directed to improving the performance of the public sector in recognition of the fact that, not only will we get a better public sector, but also improvements in efficiency and effectiveness will translate into lower costs to the private sector. The performance orientation of the reforms has added a new dimension to the traditional notion of accountability-and that is accountability for results. It is through a greater focus on results that the most significant gains in efficiency and effectiveness will be achieved.

It is in this climate of reform that the Auditor-General has a key role. The Auditor-General is uniquely placed to facilitate improvements in public sector administration through the specialist skills of his Office, his broad powers of examination and the authority he has to report directly to Ministers and to the Parliament.

It is clearly in the interests of the Parliament and the Executive for the Australian Audit Office to be a viable and effective organisation keeping pace with changes that affect its operations and those of its auditees. The terms of reference of the inquiry were to investigate:
whether the Australian Audit Office had kept pace with developments in regard to the public audit function in the States and Territories and in comparable countries;
the Committee answered this question with a conditional `no'; and
whether current arrangements guaranteed the independence and resources necessary of the Australian Audit Office to fulfil its role as determined by the Audit Act 1901.
the Committee concluded that the answer to this question was `no'.
The Committee pointed out that it sees the reasons for those negative answers as largely outside the control of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office.
The Committee made some 78 recommendations arising from its inquiry. The Government agrees with the majority of the recommendations which require government decision, including those concerning:
the replacement of the existing Audit Act by a Financial Administration Act and an Audit Act;
revised arrangements concerning the appointment and term of the Auditor-General with a fixed seven year non-extendable term and the provision of an advisory input by Parliament; and
revised arrangements to provide Parliamentary input into the appointment of the Independent Auditor of the AAO.

The Government does not agree, however, with some of the Committee's recommendations dealing with the issues of independence, the resources for the AAO, and the Auditor-General's mandate. I will comment further on these more contentious issues. More detailed responses are set out in the document which I have tabled.

The Committee has made a number of recommendations directed to providing the Auditor-General with what is perceived to be greater independence from the Executive. They include making the Auditor-General an officer of the Parliament, establishing the AAO as a statutory authority, having the AAO's funding requirements reviewed by a new Parliamentary Audit Committee and including the AAO's appropriations in the Appropriations (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. As I have indicated, the Government fully accepts the fundamental principle that the Auditor-General should be functionally independent from the Executive. Just as importantly, however, the Auditor-General should also be functionally independent from the Parliament.

Both the Executive and the Parliament have a legitimate interest in the maintenance of strong and effective audit machinery to review both the financial as well as efficiency aspects of departments' and agencies' activities. They both have a legitimate interest in the outcome of the Auditor-General's audits and recommendations for improvement and in the information on the operations of government agencies which is provided by the Auditor-General's reports. After all, good government demands good administration. Moreover, both the Parliament-and its committees-and Ministers have a legitimate role to request the Auditor-General to undertake particular audits. But in each case it is for the Auditor-General alone to decide at the end of the day, whether he will accede to such requests.

The current provisions of the Audit Act provide for the statutory independence of the Auditor-General. Nothing put forward by the Committee has in any way suggested that these statutory provisions have been ineffective. Further, with the independence of the Auditor-General not at issue, the Government sees no particular advantage to the Parliament, the Executive, or the Auditor-General in establishing the Auditor-General as an officer of the Parliament.

Whether the Parliament wishes to establish an Audit Committee to advise the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priorities and to consider the AAO's finances is really a question for the Parliament. I would point out, however, that care would need to be exercised so that such a committee was not seen to put pressure on the Auditor-General to pursue particular topics, thus compromising his ability to determine priorities. As for any committee role in reviewing the Audit Office's finances, the Government would be prepared to consider any comments the committee might make but would reserve the right to accept or reject any such comments.

Against this background the Government has not accepted the Committee's recommendation that the Audit Office's appropriations be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. There appears to be no real advantage to the AAO in taking that course of action. In analysing AAO resource needs, the Government will continue to apply the same rigorous methodology, criteria, tests of value for money, et cetera as it applies for other agencies-taxpayers expect and deserve no more and no less. Indeed, consistent with that, let me reiterate a point I have made on other occasions-it is an established principle of our system of government, reflected by provisions in the Constitution, that every publicly funded agency, including the AAO and the Parliament, must have its appropriations set by the Executive Government.

The Government has decided to give further consideration to the recommendation that the AAO be established as a statutory authority when it receives the report of an independent review which is to be conducted of the AAO's capacity to make better use of resources, to which I will refer shortly.
Resourcing Levels

The issue of whether the current arrangements ensure sufficient resources for the AAO to fulfil its charter was central to the Committee's inquiry. As I indicated earlier, the Committee concluded the answer to this question was no. The Committee has proposed that an additional $15.7m per annum-be provided to the AAO with the increase to be phased in over five years to allow the AAO to adopt regular cycles of efficiency audits of Government bodies.

I have to say that the Committee's analysis of the resource issues presented in the report leaves something to be desired. It has merely made a very simplistic comparison between the number of Government bodies audited by the Auditor-General and the level of AAO staffing. The Government is disappointed that the Committee did not examine the resource question in the context of:
the steps already taken by the Auditor-General to improve the effectiveness of the AAO;
the significant investment in computing facilities for the Audit Office agreed by the Government in the 1987-88 Budget;

the more risk based approach to auditing being promoted by the Auditor-General which could be expected to generate internal efficiencies within the Audit Office thus freeing up resources which could be directed to efficiency auditing; and
the flexibility the Office has to vary the existing allocation of its total resources in favour of efficiency auditing by reassessing priorities.

It is also noteworthy that evidence given to the Committee by the then Auditor-General of Victoria and the Auditor-General for South Australia indicated they had increased their activity in efficiency auditing without increased resources, in the South Australian case in a situation where total resources employed by the Auditor-General had actually decreased.

The recent report of the independent auditor on an efficiency audit of the AAO indicates that there are opportunities for efficiencies arising from a reduction in testing transactions during the year, through computerisation of audit programs, a reduction in documentation and the selection of more cost-effective audit techniques such as risk based audit sampling and analytical reviews.

Against this background, the Government is not convinced that a sufficient case has been made to warrant the increase proposed by the Committee which is equivalent to an almost 60 per cent increase in resources for the AAO. It has however decided that additional funding be provided for efficiency audits of $2m per annum on an ongoing basis with $1.33m to be provided on pro rata basis for the balance of this financial year in the Additional Estimates pending a more systematic review of the resourcing question than the Committee undertook.

The Government, with the agreement of the Auditor-General, has decided to commission an independent review by the Auditor-General of South Australia, Mr T. A. Sheridan, to work with the AAO to advise the Auditor-General and the Government on the AAO's capacity to improve further the use of existing resources. This review will build on the initiatives taken by the Auditor-General to date in improving the effectiveness of the AAO and will also take account of recommendations in the efficiency audit report on the AAO by the AAO's independent auditor and of changes which may be recommended to the Auditor-General as a consequence of this review. The formal terms of reference for this review are included in the document which I have tabled. There is no suggestion that the resources of the Audit Office will be reduced as a result of this review. Any proposals for further resources for the AAO will be considered in the 1990 Budget context.

Mr Sheridan's background and standing will ensure that this review is both independent and professional. I should like to acknowledge the South Australian Government's assistance in making this arrangement. Mr Sheridan has been asked to report to the Auditor-General and to the Government by 31 March 1990.
Auditor-General's Mandate

The Committee has recommended the Auditor-General be reinstated as the external auditor of statutory marketing authorities (SMAs) and government business enterprises (GBEs). The Government has carefully considered this issue and, while disposed to accept the Committee's recommendations, has decided to give further consideration to the matter when it receives the report of the independent review of the AAO that I have announced, which is due to report in March 1990.

The Committee also recommended that the Auditor-General's mandate to conduct efficiency audits at his discretion be increased to allow the Auditor-General to undertake efficiency audits of companies. The Government has reviewed this recommendation in conjunction with a review of the efficiency audit provisions pertaining to GBEs. The Government considers that in the ordinary course of events there is little to be gained by subjecting GBEs, whether they are companies or statutory authorities, to efficiency audits as they are now being made subject to commercial disciplines through the focus of the reforms on targets and related performance measurement. The Government proposes, however, that a Minister of the Parliament may request the Auditor-General to carry out an efficiency audit of a GBE or GBE subsidiary.

GBEs and their subsidiaries aside, the Government agrees the Auditor-General should have the discretion to undertake efficiency audits of other Government controlled companies which are not subject to the discipline of the marketplace to be efficient.
Conclusion

The Chairman of the Committee, Mr Robert Tickner, MP, and the Committee members are to be commended for undertaking this inquiry. The Committee's report has been a catalyst for debate, and for change. Where the Government has agreed to the Committee's recommendations it will seek to implement the changes as soon as practicable. Where legislative changes are required these will be taken up in the drafting of the new legislation to replace the existing Audit Act.

As a final comment I want to stress that there can be no question but that this Government will defend and preserve the Auditor-General's functional independence. The Government takes good public administration and effective accountability to taxpayers very seriously and it is precisely for these reasons that, even while recognising the special place of the AAO in our institutional structures, this Government considers that the Office should be subject to the same financial disciplines and resources scrutiny that apply to other budget funded agencies. I do not believe the Auditor-General would disagree.
I am confident that as a result of the Committee's report and the efforts of the current Auditor-General, we will have a stronger and more effective Audit Office as we move into the next decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The office of Auditor-General was one of the first posts created after Federation. I think, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said, the Act establishing that office was the fourth Act of the Federal Parliament. The position was established under the Audit Act 1901, and that Act created a legislative basis for the financial management of Commonwealth moneys and for the audit of related accounts. In 1911 the Auditor-General's Office was included under the Prime Minister's portfolio for administrative and budgetary purposes, and that arrangement continued for 75 years until 1985-86 when the Office came under the control of the Finance portfolio.

The report of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts-report No. 296-is a very important one. I mention in passing that two of my colleagues, Senator John Watson, who is the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, and Senator Bronwyn Bishop, who is a member, will be seeking to supplement my remarks on this very important statement that the Minister has just put down. That report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts presented the first comprehensive inquiry into the Audit Office since its establishment. That in itself is a rather remarkable tribute to the quality of the work performed by the Office, but it perhaps raises a question as to whether we may have been a little too complacent about the work of the Office over time. After all, 88 years is quite a long time to go unreported upon.

As the Minister has said, there were a great number of recommendations-78 in all, I think-in the report. But, in responding to the Minister's statement, I want to focus on two areas-firstly, the question of independence of the Auditor's office and, secondly, the much lesser but nevertheless significant question of the role of the Auditor's office in auditing accounts of public corporations.

Since 1901, the role and responsibilities of the Australian Audit Office have expanded very greatly. In report No. 296, the Committee reported that the Office is straining under the pressure. For example, only 10 years ago, in 1979, the Audit Act was amended to permit the Auditor-General to undertake efficiency audits which, I may say, go well beyond mere bookkeeping and involve review of the dynamics of the management and financial practice of the body being audited. However, owing to lack of resources, it is estimated, as the Committee reported, that large programs with income and expenditure greater than $10m can be expected to be subject to an efficiency audit, given the present resources of the Auditor-General's Office, only once every 40 years. That clearly raises some questions about the adequacy of the resources available to the Auditor-General. Report No. 296 argued, I think quite properly, that this scenario was not consistent with a maximum effort to improve the public sector's efficiency.

The report criticised the tendency in recent years towards allowing certain kinds of instrumentalities the right to appoint their own auditors. It found that the effect of that tendency was to reduce the flow of financial information on government owned companies available to Ministers and the Parliament. In turn, it suggested that this development led, and is continuing to lead, to a lessening in Parliament's ability to make and oversee sound laws, and to a weakening of the accountability of executive government to the Parliament.

A particular weakness highlighted by report No. 296 was that the Department of Finance was now the principal adviser of executive government on the resources that should be allocated to the Australian Audit Office. Not to put too fine a point on it, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has suggested that in this situation there is the potential for a significant conflict of interest.

On the principal issue of independence, the Committee came to the view that the major inadequacies identified in the report would be best overcome by promoting a closer relationship between the Auditor-General and the Parliament as distinct from the Executive. A specific recommendation in that respect was that the Auditor-General should in fact formally become an officer of the Parliament, and that an audit committee of Parliament be established to become Parliament's principal source of advice on the resources of the Audit Office, the objective of this being to reduce the influence of executive government over the audit of public accounts and thereby to improve the accountability of the public sector to the Parliament as distinct from the Executive.

Almost all submissions to the Public Accounts Committee's inquiry acknowledged that the question of independence or, more specifically, the acknowledgment of the independence of the Auditor-General for executive government interference, was a paramount matter for consideration. The Joint Committee report revealed some alarm that the Executive Government's control of the budgetary resources being made available to the Auditor-General through the Department of Finance had raised questions about the actual independence of his Office.

I remind the Senate of the particularly significant parting words of the immediate past Auditor-General, Mr John Monaghan, with whom I am personally acquainted. He worked for me at one stage, and I have a very high regard for him. I am sure he did not utter these words lightly, although I have not discussed his opinion with him. When he retired in 1987, he fired what I think can only be termed a broadside at the constraining role of the Department of Finance and raised the question whether no Audit Office at all would be better than the existing system. They were strong words coming from a retiring-and, indeed, Mr Monaghan is a retiring person in a different sense of that word-Auditor-General.

In contrast to the present system in Australia, the Committee considered an alternative model from Canada which, without going into detail, it declined to follow, and considered in particular the model now obtaining in the United Kingdom. I want to say a little about that before concluding these remarks.

In 1983, the present Government of the United Kingdom moved positively away from an audit model which was in fact broadly similar to that which we have at present. Since that time, the Comptroller and Auditor-General, as he is called in the United Kingdom, has been wholly independent of the Executive. He is now appointed by the Queen on an address from the House of Commons which is moved by the Prime Minister after agreement with the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee. He can be removed from office only by the Queen on an address by both Houses of Parliament, rather like our procedures for the removal of a High Court judge. His salary is paid directly from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, without requiring annual approval of the Executive or the Parliament once appointed. He appoints his own staff and determines their numbers, grades, salaries and conditions of service within, of course, the totality of funds allocated to the running of his office.

It is very important to note that the Comptroller and Auditor-General is an officer of the House of Commons. His main duties are carried out on behalf of the Parliament, in which context he works in very close association with the all-party Public Accounts Committee, the equivalent of our Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Each year he-it is `he' at the moment, at any rate-submits proposed Budget estimates to a different committee of the Westminster Parliament, the Public Accounts Commission, which considers the proposal and submits it, with any modifications it thinks fit, to the House of Commons. That commission, which determines, as I say, the budget of what we would call the Audit Office, consists of the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, the Leader of the House of Commons and seven other members appointed by the House, none of whom shall be a Minister.

Report No. 296 from our Joint Committee recommends for Australia a similar model to that of the United Kingdom. It recommends setting up an audit committee of Parliament similar to the Public Accounts Commission to which I was referring a moment ago. The membership as proposed by our Committee would be an all-party one but would in this case also include the Minister for Finance, thereby taking account at least of the strong views expressed by or on behalf of the Minister about the need for the Executive to continue to be involved-the Minister puts it much more strongly than that-in the determination of the resources available to the Audit Office. Report No. 296 notes that, since the Minister would be a member, the funding bids from the Audit Office would be subject to the same level of analysis and evaluation as normal departmental appropriations. Finally, the Joint Committee proposed that the estimates for the AAO would be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bills.

In his response today the Minister said that he does not accept those views. Without labouring the point at this time, I have to say that the Minister has given a rather slender justification for that view. He has simply indicated that basically the Government does not agree. Apart from that, the only argument, if one could call it that, that the Minister has put forward is that the Committee analysis of this matter was-in what I think were the words he used-simplistic or over-simplistic. I do not think very much of that form of reasoning. The Minister is proposing that we should leave the status quo. I remind the Senate that the United Kingdom Public Accounts Committee in its 1981 report, which led up to the 1983 changes which I have just described, said of their then system, which was virtually identical with our present system:
The best that can be said for the present administrative arrangements is that they work. But there might well be dangers for parliamentary accountability-
I emphasise the words `parliamentary accountability'-
in the present very close relationship between the Exchequer-
in our case, read `Department of Finance'-
and Audit Department.

In his statement today the Minister has also stressed the need for the Australian Audit Office to be subject to the same requirements of budgetary control and the same resource review as what one might call normal departments of state. There is a proper distinction to be drawn; nevertheless, as report No. 296 of the Joint Public Accounts Committee stated, the principle that the Executive takes expenditure proposals to Parliament-which I think was the principle that Senator Walsh was seeking to insist upon-would not be infringed by the Committee's proposal because the estimates for the Australian Audit Office would be included in Appropriation Bills just as they are now. They would be in a different area of those Bills, but they would still be subject to review and scrutiny by the Parliament.

The important difference would be that the process by which estimates, including forward estimates, for the Audit Office would be arrived at would be very different indeed. The procedure would no longer be solely under the control of the Minister for Finance and his Department and would be consistent with the principle that the entire Parliament has a special interest in maintaining an independent and able Audit Office. I express considerable disappointment with the position which has just been stated by the Minister on behalf of the Government. It is not necessarily a position which the Opposition will want to adopt in due course when we have the power to do so-which I think will not be far distant.

Finally, I want to say something very briefly about the second matter I mentioned-namely, the role of private sector auditors in this area. Recommendations 19 to 24 of report No. 296 stated, inter alia, that the Auditor-General should be reinstated as the external auditor of all Commonwealth government business enterprises and statutory marketing authorities and their subsidiaries. However, it qualified this to some degree by stating that the Auditor-General should maintain the power and ability to contract out to private sector auditors the undertaking of audits on his behalf and, importantly, subject to his control.

Those recommendations were prompted, I think, by the recent trend in the Federal government arena to allow various Commonwealth authorities to choose their own auditors. I suppose one could say that that trend has been rationalised by the Government on the grounds that it is consistent with encouraging the further commercialisation of these bodies. Under some circumstances that argument would appeal to me. However, in line with the coalition's view on privatisation, authorities of this kind cannot become truly commercial while they still retain government ownership. Obviously if they were to be privatised they would have the same right as any other body to choose their own auditors. But it seems to us that they cannot have it both ways. They cannot remain within the public sector and seek to behave in that sense just as though they were in the private sector-to choose those parts of privatisation which they prefer, if I can put it that way.

Given that taxpayers' money is involved, we believe that a higher degree of accountability is required and, indeed, demanded by the public than is the case for privately owned commercial ventures. The Australian Audit Office is cognisant of this extra duty, the extra level of auditing concern, in its audit tasks. We have found recommendations 19 to 24 of the report-namely, that the Auditor-General remain in control of all external audits-appealing. I conclude my remarks by noting that my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Bishop will be supplementing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Joint Committee of Public Accounts report No. 296 is the result of the first comprehensive parliamentary-in fact, governmental-inquiry into the Australian Audit Office since the establishment of the Audit Office in 1901. In those 88 years the roles of governments and evaluations by parliaments have changed quite dramatically, as have the responsibilities of the Australian Audit Office. The Committee examined the role of the Australian Audit Office and the Auditor-General in the light of those many complex changes. As Vice-Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I wish to take this opportunity to thank the Government for its commendation for the Committee undertaking this inquiry and the Government's acknowledgment that the Committee's report has been a catalyst for debate and change. I also welcome the fact that in those areas where the Government has agreed to the Committee's recommendations it will seek to implement the changes as soon as practicable and that legislative changes that are required will be taken up in the drafting of the new legislation to replace the existing Audit Act.

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome these responses but a number of us find it very difficult to follow some negative responses and conclusions, particularly the rationale behind the Government's conclusions. A disappointing feature of the Government's response is that a number of statements, issues and conclusions within it are patently wrong. Perhaps I would be a little unkind if I suggested that this document had essentially been written by some officers of the Department of Finance who saw in some of the Committee's wide-ranging recommendations-which not only involve changes to the Australian Audit Office but also directly and indirectly affect the overview functions of the Department of Finance-a lessening of the role of the Department of Finance and that, perhaps, there was not a small element of professional jealousy at the loss of their rights and responsibilities in the future.

If I may be permitted to provide a precis or overview of the Government's response, I suggest that it is not entirely surprising, given the very strong views of the Government on independence and resource allocation not being transferred to the Parliament but being retained by the Executive. This raises the whole question of parliamentary supremacy and the concern that a lot of parliamentarians have about the increasing control of the Executive, particularly over the Parliament and parliamentary officers. I find the Government's reaction not surprising, given that the Government and the Minister for Finance have strident views about financial control through the executive arm of Government. I do not find it surprising therefore that, while lip service is provided in the response to the report over such issues as the independence of the Auditor-General and his office, the Government has rejected the practical means for achieving the meaningful independence that is required under the Act by a democratic parliament. In other words, the Government has failed, while providing lip service acknowledgment to that independence, to provide a meaningful way of achieving that independence; and I believe that is to be regretted.

I am very happy with the Government's acceptance of the replacement of the existing Audit Act by a financial administration Act and an audit Act. Two Acts to replace this single outmoded Act are certainly overdue. I welcome the Government's decision to put into place two new Acts at an early opportunity. I also welcome the revised arrangements concerning the appointment and the term of the Auditor-General, with a fixed seven-year, non-extendable term and the provision of an advisory input by Parliament. But having regard to the way that the Government has emasculated that advisory input by Parliament, one tends to wonder how effective that can be in future. We note the revised arrangements to provide for parliamentary input into the appointment of the independent auditor of the Australian Audit Office.

What surprises me, and I am deeply disappointed, is that on page 4 of the report, when talking about resourcing levels-and these are issues that were frequently canvassed in recent reports of the Auditor-General in his submissions to Parliament-the Government comes to an earnest conclusion that it is disappointed that the Committee did not examine the resource question in that context, because we did precisely that. How it can come to that conclusion certainly baffles me as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The Committee deliberately examined in detail the steps that had already been taken by the Auditor-General to improve the effectiveness of the Australian Audit Office. To that end, we employed the Auditor-General of Canada to make such an evaluation as part of our other evaluations. We also brought over a high official in this area from the New Zealand Audit Office. We did address the fact that significant investment in computing facilities for the Australian Audit Office has been agreed. We did acknowledge the more risk based approach to auditing which has been adopted in recent years by Auditors-General. We did acknowledge that this approach generated greater internal efficiencies within the Audit Office.They are to be applauded.

The flexibility that the Australian Audit Office has to vary existing allocation of its total resources in favour of efficiency auditing by reassessing priorities was one of the most disappointing aspects of the Government's response, apart from this question of independence. I will not canvass that matter again, because I believe it was adequately covered by my colleague Senator Stone. But I do believe that there was a continual blinkered approach by the Government in its failure to acknowledge and provide adequate resourcing levels-despite all those things that the Auditor-General has done and the fact that he has not been able to devote resources to an adequate level of efficiency auditing as a result of the severe constraints that have tended to push his resources more into the fiscal and compliance area-for the minimum obligations that he must perform in order to discharge his statutory duties to the Parliament. So the Government's failure to accept that aspect is very much a disappointing feature of the report.

Another inconsistency in the Government's response is that, while the Government has decided to appoint Mr Sheridan to advise the Australian Auditor-General, it has effectively pre-empted some of his conclusions when the Government itself, on page 5 of its response, acknowledges that there is a need for increased resources. Although the Government does not agree to a 60 per cent increase in resources, it is prepared to allocate $2m per annum on an ongoing basis with $1.33m to be provided for the balance of this financial year in the additional estimates pending a more systematic review of the resourcing question for efficiency audits. While the Government is appointing Mr Sheridan to look at this question of resourcing, workload and efficiency of the Office, to some extent the Government's response is overriding or pre-empting some of his outcomes.

I would not like to end on a pessimistic note. We have certainly turned the first stone. The Government has reacted in a predictable way. In those areas in which it has responded positively, I thank the Government. I look forward to early legislation so that some changes can be made in those areas where it has responded so positively, although it is generally a very positive response by the Government to the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining my colleagues Senator Stone and Senator Watson in commenting on the response of the Government to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report No. 296, I think it is important to draw the attention of the Senate to the title of that report-The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. Embodied in that title is exactly why the Committee made recommendations in an attempt to have a proper scrutiny of the expenditure of public moneys by the executive arm of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, the expenditure of public moneys has to be accountable and the only body to whom that accountability can be made is the Parliament. Inherent in that process has to be the role of the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General is, if you like, the link between the Executive that makes policy and the public sector which then carries out that policy and expends money for and on behalf of the Parliament-money that is appropriated by the Parliament, although the amounts are set by the executive arm of government, but it is the Parliament which appropriates the funds. The Auditor-General is the fundamental link in reporting back to the Parliament to ensure that proper scrutiny can take place. This process is carried out through the Public Accounts Committee and the Estimates committees-and I was interested to read a report by the Ombudsman, who puts forward a very good case as to why he, too, is part of the process of scrutiny-which are tools that the Parliament has at its disposal to ensure that proper accountability is made for the expenditure of public moneys.

I was very interested to read the statement that accompanied the Government response, presented by Senator Walsh. It is interesting to note that on page 2 of the original typescript of his ministerial statement he said:
The Government does not agree, however, with some of the Committee's recommendations dealing with the issues of independence, the resources for the AAO, and the Auditor-General's mandate.

These issues go right to the heart of the substance of the report-The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. The question of independence, which Senator Stone dealt with, is of crucial importance to the role of democracy as we know it. On page 3 of his statement Senator Walsh said:

. . . the Government . . . accepts the fundamental principle that the Auditor-General should be functionally independent from the Executive. Just as importantly, however, the Auditor-General should also be functionally independent from the Parliament.

In making that statement Senator Walsh is dealing with the recommendations that were made by the Public Accounts Committee which were designed to make the Australian Audit Office and the Auditor-General independent of the executive arm of government and accountable to the Parliament. It is not a question of the Auditor-General being functionally independent from the Parliament; it is a question of the Auditor-General being responsible in the accounting process to the Parliament which, in turn, represents the people. That is the only way that accountability can take place. Senator Walsh further stated:
Both the Executive and the Parliament have a legitimate interest in the maintenance of strong and effective audit machinery . . .

We have more than a legitimate interest; we have a fundamental responsibility to the people to carry out that scrutiny. Senator Walsh went on to say, `After all, good government demands good administration'. But he does not add the further point that it also demands good accountability. He further stated:
The current provisions of the Audit Act provide for the statutory independence of the Auditor-General.

So they do, but as we have seen only too often, if one limits the resources of the Auditor-General, one can limit his performance. If we say `We won't give you the resources to properly carry out your task', in fact the Auditor-General is prohibited from carrying out that task. Senator Walsh further stated:
Nothing put forward by the Committee has in any way suggested that these statutory provisions have been ineffective.

That comment puts a slightly different light on what the Committee had to say. The Committee said that it had seen no evidence that the Auditor-General had been prevented from carrying out essential parts of his work. However, the Auditor-General did say that he was precluded from carrying out the efficiency audits which have become such an integral and important part of that accountability process. Overseas experience has shown that independence-and that means a truly financial independence from the executive arm of government-in systems which are similar to ours has become a very important point. Senator Stone dealt very well with the example of the British experience.

When one reads the report and the response of the Government, one sees that the report is a document of some considerable substance, and that the response is perhaps a much lighter document. It certainly does not attempt to deal with many of the issues that were raised in the Committee's report. On page 4 of the response from the Government, and in response to the recommendation of the Committee dealing with the Australian Audit Office's requirement that its appropriations be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Government says that somehow it would be wrong to treat the Audit Office in a way which is different from the way that it treats other parts of government. It says that to do so would place the Australian Audit Office in a unique and perhaps favoured position. The whole contention of the report that was brought down by the Public Accounts Committee is that the Australian Audit Office is in a unique position. It is the link between government expenditure and the Parliament.

In other parts of the Government's response and in Senator Walsh's statement we see reference to the Committee's recommendations concerning the Auditor-General's mandate. Recommendations Nos 19, 20, 21, 22, 23 and 24 deal with the mandate of the Auditor-General. The Government, in its response, says:

The Government is disposed to accept the Committee's recommendations. However, it has decided to give further consideration to this issue after it receives the report of the independent review of the AAO's use of resources, due in March 1990.

This report is to be entitled the Sheridan inquiry. Yet, on page 11, in responses numbered 37 and 38, the Government refers to the new arrangements that it has put in place concerning government business enterprises (GBEs). Although the recommendations dealt with in response No. 35 in fact refer to government business enterprises, responses Nos 37 and 38 tend to contradict response No. 35. Response No. 37 states:
. . . focus of GBE accountability in future is to be on results rather than on processes involved in managerial decision making.

Again we see this artificial distinction which the Executive Government has chosen to make in several of its statements. It has attempted to make a distinction between process and outcome. In my view this is a totally artificial distinction because it is possible to have an outcome which is adjudged to be both successful and improper at the same time. If the process is improper and corrupted, so is the outcome, so it is necessary to look at both matters. If one needs to be reminded of the sorts of things that can occur, one should look at the evidence which is currently being given before the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales dealing with Mr Ross, who has been an employee of the Department of Administrative Services. One will realise that the opportunity for improper behaviour lies well and truly within the Commonwealth public sector. Response No. 38 states:

. . . the Government considers there is little to be gained by subjecting GBEs, whether they are companies or statutory authorities . . . to efficiency audits as the discipline to be efficient is imposed through the focus on targets and related performance measurement.

However, the Government proposes that a Minister may request that the Auditor-General carry out an efficiency audit. There is a contention flowing through both the arrangements applying to GBEs and in some of the responses made to the recommendations in the report that somehow GBEs are now responsive to commercial demands of the marketplace. Until such time as GBEs are totally free of the public sector and become privatised, I think the standards of accountability that apply to the public sector and the private sector remain totally separate. These concerns arise particularly as a result of some recent corporate failures and the activities of some overzealous entrepreneurial corporate executives. Perhaps in the future, might I suggest, the Commission might like to address areas such as the need for identifying needed changes to legislation.

Let me detail some areas that I think should be addressed. Firstly, there is considerable doubt in the legal fraternity as to whether unpaid premium could be claimable in the event of a liquidation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.
