On page 25 of the report of the 107th session of the National Health and Medical Research Council there is a list of some of the designated NHMRC priorities. One of these, of course, is dental health and the impact of change in oral health status on dental education and work force practices and services in Australia, and this includes fluoridation of the water supply. Recently, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Assembly voted to remove the fluoride from the water supply. This was a progressive step, a commonsense move which, unfortunately, has since been rescinded.

The Australian Democrats have consistently opposed the use of the chemical fluoride in Australia. The ACT Assembly seemed to be agreeing with the Democrats' stand and, indeed, with the opinion of over half the residents of Canberra, when it voted to remove the fluoride. However, the troglodytes, the flat earthers, have prevailed and the fluoride is back in the water. This is unfortunate because fluoride is a poison. It is actually a rat poison when used in high concentrations.

Many people who oppose the use of fluoride are called cranks. If so, these cranks include the National Research Council of Canada, the Ministry of the Environment in Quebec, the Danish Agency for International Protection and the Swedish Fluoride Commission. All these agencies questioned the present addition of fluoride to the drinking water. If these be cranks, I suppose we are cranks, too. The fact is that we are now being bombarded with fluoride compounds, from aluminium smelting and other industrial processes, which enter the food and beverage chain. In addition, it is almost impossible to purchase dental health products which do not contain fluoride. Even if one argues that in 1945 or so, when fluoride was first put into the water in the United States, it might have been beneficial, certainly now the situation has changed. We have so much fluoride in our environment.

A scientist at the Australian National University here in Canberra, Dr Mark Diesendorf, has demonstrated that the rate of tooth decay in fluoridation areas does not differ from areas where no fluoride at all is used-and this might be because of the amount of fluoride in our environment. In fact, Brisbane does not use fluoride in its water-and Senator Macklin is agreeing with me on that. Yet the rate of tooth decay in Brisbane is no greater than the rate of tooth decay in Canberra.

It has not been demonstrated that fluoridation increases the health of people. In fact, it can be demonstrated that quite the opposite is the case. Fluoride has a number of known health effects. The symptoms most commonly reported are: headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, sight sensitivity, forgetfulness, belching, wind, stomach pain, lassitude, oppression of chest, lameness of hips and knees, arthritic aches and pains, sleeplesness, itching skin, and sore mouth and gums. These symptoms afflict about one per cent of the population. In Australia that would be about 150,000.

Who benefits from fluoride? First, there is the aluminium industry, because it is able to get rid of a by-product which would be very difficult to dispose of otherwise. The junk food industry benefits. It can advertise that it is all right for people to drink lots of coca-cola and eat lots of sugar because there is fluoride in the water which will prevent cavities.

The obvious conclusion is that fluoride should be placed in drinking water only if it is proven beyond all doubt to be both beneficial and safe. To date this proof has not been forthcoming. The hysterical reaction to this prudent position is puzzling. I can only surmise that it is similar to the situation which arises when a confidence man is apprehended by the police. The crook's victims simply refuse to believe that they have been conned and defend the con man to the bitter end. Is fluoridation in the same category? I wonder.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that remark by my colleague Senator Sanders as regards the sheep husbandry report that was brought down by the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. Senator Sanders, of course, has been part of the Committee for the past four and a bit years, during which time I have been on the Committee. I must admit that we have not always seen eye to eye on all issues, but the sheep husbandry report by the Select Committee on Animal Welfare is a unanimous report. Senator Sanders has already spoken on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possibly the first detailed publication on the welfare of extensive sheep management in Australia, and follows earlier reports on such issues as the live sheep trade. Evidence taken over four years has been compiled into a comprehensive document, including 15 recommendations for the industry and Federal and State governments. Evidence was taken from a wide cross-section of the community, including wool industry representatives, farmers, scientists, animal welfare agencies, animal activist groups, veterinarians and public servants.

The report acknowledges the significance of the sheep and wool industry to Australia, both in terms of the production of an export commodity and as a vital source of meat and fibre domestically. The Committee examined the costs and benefits of various husbandry practices and whether economic consideration ought to outweigh the comfort of the sheep. Issues such as tail docking, marking, mulesing, time of shearing and teeth grinding were all examined as to whether they were essential on economic or welfare grounds. Two issues which raised considerable debate among witnesses before the Committee were mulesing and teeth grinding.

Mulesing is an operation which involves the surgical removal of strips of loose wool-bearing skin from the breach and tail of sheep, mostly merinos. It is done to reduce the incidence of flystrike and as such is in some areas quite widely practised either by the farmer or, more commonly, by contractors experienced in the practice. Much evidence was given of both the effects of flystrike on sheep and the pain suffered in the mulesing operation. It is undoubtedly a sensitive issue and one about which a largely ignorant public could become quite emotional. However, having examined all the evidence both in support of and opposed to the practice of mulesing, the Committee remarked:
Mulesing is an unpleasant practice, one which is generally performed with distaste and one which certainly causes sheep and lambs pain . . .

However, the Committee concluded that, in the absence of effective alternatives, the practice should continue, the argument being that flystrike is infinitely more painful than the mulesing operation, notwithstanding that not every sheep that is mulesed would necessarily have been affected at some time by flystrike.

Alternatives to mulesing, such as a closer monitoring of flocks and selective breeding to reduce loose-skinned breeds, were supported but acknowledged to be limited in their likely application. On the other hand, teeth grinding is not a routine practice in Australia. It involves the mechanical grinding of an older sheep's teeth to increase the productive life of that animal. While the practice of teeth grinding is not supported by either the Australian Veterinary Association or the Farm Animal Welfare Council of the United Kingdom, the Committee did not regard it as either sufficiently widespread or sufficiently appealing to become widespread. It argued that if an otherwise productive sheep can be kept longer by trimming its teeth, the practice is justified, provided it does not cause undue pain to the animal. Other areas covered by the report include chemical shearing or biological defleecing. Those are two areas on which the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has been doing a great deal of work. Research funding in these areas has been cut back quite dramatically by this Government. We have all talked about the cutbacks to the CSIRO.

The Committee has recommended the continuation of research into all alternative methods of conventional shearing on the basis that conventional shearing necessarily involves a certain amount of stress to the sheep. The Committee took evidence on such issues as the effects of climate, yard design and handling techniques. It was acknowledged that geography and weather had a significant impact on welfare. Drought, floods and fire create enormously varying conditions for sheep, and much evidence was taken about the response of sheep to extreme conditions. Recommendations were given for the transport, sale and slaughter of sheep affected by floods, fire and drought. However, the Committee noted that the most significant and vital factor in sheep welfare was the quality of stockmanship. Sheep that were handled roughly and in poorly designed yards and facilities suffered significantly higher stress levels. The Committee supported calls for more training in behaviour based skills in animal handling for the benefit of both the animal and the operator. It also noted the benefit of appropriately designed yards and facilities which reduced stress.

The report has been well received by the industry, which regards it as a balanced and responsible comment on the present state of the industry. The Federal Government is yet to respond to the findings. However, given the Labor Government's insensitive attitude towards research funding generally-which I have already alluded to-and to the CSIRO in particular, cutbacks which have already affected CSIRO sheep research projects are unlikely to be redressed, despite the Committee's call for increased and continuing funding for such projects as the study of flystrike and shearing alternatives.

Through all the deliberations of the Committee into sheep husbandry, we met many people whom I would like to publicly thank for the courtesy they showed us-the people in the robotic shearing area in Adelaide and Western Australia, the persons whose properties we visited, the people who are associated with the industry and the people who gave evidence on behalf of animal welfare groups. I thank all the people from the Secretariat who wrote up the report very much for their efforts on behalf of the Committee. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the luncheon break, I was discussing in this debate on the Appropriation Bills the situation with regard to higher education in Australia and had just quoted from the inaugural lecture given by Professor Manderson in September of this year at the University of Queensland. As I pointed out, in her lecture she quoted from the Brecht play, The Life of Galileo. I cannot resist quoting another passage of that Brecht play which seems highly pertinent to the situation that universities are in today. The curator in the play says:

SPEECH.PARA: If you want money, you must produce something else. For the knowledge which you sell, you can only demand as much as it profits whoever buys it from you . . . Men applaud you in Paris and Prague. But the gentlemen who applaud do not, unfortunately, pay the University of Padua what you cost it.

Brecht went on in that play to posit two options: either oppressive government direction of universities or oppressive market direction. There are other options. Indeed, we are rapidly moving away from Australia's own version of a reasonably balanced stance between public funding from government and public accountability from universities. Part of the present destructive criticism from government comes directly from politicians who have become obsessed with economic growth, performance measurement and value for money and have ignored what was actually happening in teaching, research and service to the community by our higher education institutions.

The Government's proposal to base its research policy on a centrally defined system of earmarked grants and specific contracts is cause for great concern. Under these policies, the lone philosophers who at the turn of the century worked on symbolic logic would not have qualified under the Government's definition of `approved activities'. It was their work, however, that gave rise to the most significant invention of the 1900s, that of the modern computer. As the leader of the newly formed Tuesday Group Professor David Penington has said, `It is impossible to dictate creativity'. Clearly, the concept of limiting research to areas of perceived national need to improve national well-being finds no support in the history of science.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has been quick to criticise universities for their apparent failure to contribute to the development of business. It is my belief, however, that the business world has been slow both to invest in and capitalise on university research. It has been cogently argued that the indirect contribution universities make to business through research findings and the graduating of competent students will continue to be vastly more important than the contribution they may make toward process and product innovations in the business sector.

It seems to me illogical to force universities out of the basic and applied research which has been their great strength into types of applied research and development for which they are not equipped-even if one could be sanguine about the ability of the Minister, advised by the Australian Research Council, to `pick winners' from the multitude of research proposals. The gist of the matter for the majority of academics is that they will be expected to provide scholarly teaching but this will be assumed to require neither research nor time. All this is based on the extremely fatuous distinction between `scholarship' and `research'. Recently when a report from the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled Profile of Australian Science was brought into the Senate, I quoted from it. It states:

It is impractical to allow unrestrained growth in the number of academics who are allowed to conduct research. Unless there is a loosening of the link between teaching and research in universities, any new academic staff (and hence research staff) will be concentrated in areas of growing student demand.

I take great exception to the extraordinary statement that it is the politicians who will set about allowing or not allowing academics to do research. The report then goes on to make the absolutely earth-shattering statement that, since student load had increased by over 14 per cent between 1975 and 1985 and staff had increased by only 4 per cent, more time would be spent on teaching. However, the report then states:
The likely outcome will only be changed if universities learn to teach more efficiently.

No explanation is given about how universities can teach more efficiently. Presumably, they will be asked to stuff more bodies into lecture theatres or have more and more students in tutorials until those tutorials look as much like the lectures as the lectures themselves. After this rather splendid excursion into teaching and learning theory, we come to a discussion of research which asserts that the tradition of teaching and research currently in our universities has a short history. On the contrary, the notion of research linked to teaching has a long and honourable history. An academic is expected to push back the frontiers of his or her speciality. University teaching staffs are expected to write papers for publication in learned journals. Indeed, the report says quite clearly that advancement is dependent on writing papers. Now if this activity is in any way meaningful, then the published papers are the result of something more than simply looking at what everybody else has said. The academic is contributing to the ongoing development of the discipline and to the understanding of the discipline areas by the work published. The academic in publishing papers is engaged in research. However, I point out that the distinction between research and scholarship currently being touted is a politically useful distinction. The former costs money, the latter does not. The former is getting on and doing something, whereas the latter is considered to be merely thinking about one's discipline and, surprise, surprise, that can all be done in one's own time.

As Hugh Stretton has so clearly argued, this teaching/research dichotomy will discourage the basic supply of raw talent by degrading its undergraduate teaching and discouraging its academic recruitment. The end result for the Government will be to replace original and valuable research with more of the second rate ritual publications that the Government itself professes to want to discourage. Surely the goals of higher education in Australia should be to examine the wonder and mystery of the universe in all its facets. When the Government finally gives up trivialising education, it will then have the opportunity to take seriously the proposition that education can make us free and wise and not just rich and smart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with profound regret that I once again find myself in the position of having to use the opportunity afforded me in debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill and cognate Bills to bring to the attention of the Senate the absolutely deplorable conditions of Australia's roads network. I note that during the debate on the appropriations, many other of my colleagues, including Senator Brownhill and Senator McGauran, have also spoken of their concern about this matter on behalf of their constituents. It has been a matter of ongoing concern to me since I first entered the Senate and I find it at best irresponsible of the Government to choose to ignore the repeated calls by motorists and motoring organisations which have been unanimous in their condemnation of the manner in which road funding continues to be ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: Not one member of the Senate would be unaware of the recent horror smash that occurred near Grafton in New South Wales, which caused a tragic loss of 22 lives. Some of those people were so very young. There has been considerable conjecture about the cause of that tragedy and, indeed, about the chances of similar accidents occurring at other places around Australia. Much of that discussion has centred on the shoddy conditions of Australian roads and the Russian roulette that is played by the transport drivers and passenger buses that travel along those routes on a regular basis.

Let me look at the recent record. On 20 October 1989, the tragic bus and heavy vehicle accident at Cowper near Grafton resulted in 22 deaths and three injuries. On 25 October, a semi-trailer sideswiped cars near Bathurst, leaving three dead. On the same day, two semi-trailers collided head-on 30 kilometres south of Goulburn, leaving one dead and two injured. Every evening on television news broadcasts we are subject to the continual reporting of road deaths. Only yesterday I read the road toll report of Australian Associated Press wherein it was stated that the official road toll in the Australian Capital Territory at present stands at 31. At the same time last year it stood at 24.

In 1988, 2,755 fatalities and 30,137 injuries occurred on Australian roads. In the same year, 250 fatal crashes involving heavy vehicles occurred. The Government should take no pride in the fact that road accidents now claim more lives of Australians under 45 years of age than does any other cause of death, including heart disease and cancer.

Several days ago in Tasmania, the Acting Secretary of the Municipal Association of Tasmania, Mr Colin Balmer, claimed that the accident at Cowper highlighted the poor state of many major roads both in Tasmania and nationally. Mr Balmer was moved to compare the road at Grafton with many Tasmanian roads which, he quite correctly pointed out, are unreasonably narrow and do not have adequate shoulders. Because of the negligence of the Federal Government, many Tasmanian roads are now too narrow, unsafe and covered with dangerous potholes.

Local councils in Tasmania and throughout Australia do not have the necessary resources to keep roads under control. Mr Balmer points out that, whilst the Commonwealth has been spending money on the Hume Highway and one or two other national highways-in what I suspect has been purely a vote buying exercise-very little has been spent elsewhere. Comments by municipal associations throughout Australia in support of that claim serve only to mirror Mr Balmer's comments.

Recently-in fact, only this week-I had the opportunity of meeting with members of the Municipal Association of Victoria, who pointed out to me their great concerns about the level of road funding, particularly to local government. Earlier this year, Senator Messner and I had discussions with the President of the Local Government Association of Queensland, Mr Purnell. The No. 1 problem that Mr Purnell cited to us was road funding. When I travel around Australia and talk to local government bodies and motoring organisations in other States, people raise with me concerns about what they regard as the problems that are facing motorists, namely, inadequate funding to maintain the quality of roads in order to reduce accidents. This week, the State Secretary of the Royal Automobile Club of Victoria estimated that 30 per cent of road accidents are attributed to poor roads.

Let me look at the Government's record. During Labor's term of office over seven years, road funding has been cut by 30 per cent in real terms. That has occurred during a time when, through the greed of the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating), the amount of money that is collected through fuel excise has increased dramatically by 532 per cent.

According to the 1989-90 Budget, the amount of money spent on roads will be increased from an actual expenditure of $1,217.2m in 1988-89 to an allocation of $1,333m, which represents an increase of only 2 per cent in real terms-if the Government's projected inflation figure of 7.5 per cent can be believed. When one considers the disastrous record of the Government in holding down inflation, one realises that the increase of 2 per cent in real terms will soon be eroded.

Since formulating the 1983 Budget, Labor not only has increased fuel excise but also has chosen to index it. As a result, fuel excise has risen from 6.155c per litre in March 1983 to 23.15c per litre by August 1989. Disgracefully, the total fuel excise revenue has risen from $970m to $5,645m. Despite that massive fuel excise grab at the expense of the Australian motorist, the Government still returns only 5.5c per litre to road funding. In 1989-90, the users of Australia's roads, including heavy transport vehicles, will contribute $5,645m in fuel excises, compared with $1,333.2m which Labor has decided to allocate for road funding. The situation is even more unacceptable for local government.

In my State of Tasmania local government is responsible for 80 per cent of the roads, yet it receives only 1c of each dollar that is collected in fuel excise. Because I am a former member of local government, I understand the concern of local government. Many local roads are becoming collector roads because of the sprawl and expansion of urban areas and the increase of heavy transport vehicle traffic on those roads.

It has been a matter of public record for some time-nevertheless it warrants repeating-that the amount of funding that is allocated to roads by the present Federal Government in proportion to road usage has never been at such a low level since World War II. It is clear that the cost of our dilapidated road system is borne by all Australians-rich or poor, sick or healthy, young or old. Bad roads are responsible for deaths, injuries and massive property damage. The costs of road crashes are borne not only by the persons who are involved in them but also by the general community. Considerable costs must be borne in assisting the return of those people to good health and assisting them to cope with the after-effects. There is also the substantial cost-either to insurance companies or to individuals-for repairs to damaged property.

Since 1980, approximately 25,000 Australians have died on our roads. That is equivalent to wiping off the face of Australia forever towns such as Devonport, Shepparton, Goulburn or Bathurst. Since 1980, 247,898 Australians have been injured on our roads. Each road fatality has an average cost to the community of approximately $454,000. Each major road injury bears a cost of $92,000. Even a minor injury costs $10,000. That leaves a total overall cost of $5,700m or $350 for every man, woman and child. When that figure is coupled with the total estimated revenue of $5,645m that is to be raised from fuel excise, it is obvious just how much poor roads are impacting on the general Australian economy.

The Bureau of Transport Economics has estimated that each road fatality costs our economy $454,000. For some time, the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA) has been urging the immediate upgrading of our roads to more acceptable standards, which would reduce the number of road accidents by up to 85 per cent. It should be remembered also that poor roads impact across supermarket costs and general commodity bills by increasing the freight component. Increased vehicle maintenance costs and unnecessary delays as well as transit and delivery costs are just some of the other consequences of road accidents.

This poor record of road funding ignores the importance which roads play in Australia's overall transport system. Some 70 per cent of domestic trade is carried on our roads. Between 1982 and 1985 road cargo increased by 25 per cent, and it is likely to double by the year 2000. The number of vehicles on Australia's roads is likely to increase by over 60 per cent by the year 2000.

I believe that it is important for motorists to compare the sorry attitude of the Federal Government with that of the coalition, which has continually stressed the need for road upgrading and road safety to be given a higher priority. We do so because we accept that it is unfair to expect State and local governments to absorb the responsibility, and it is similarly unacceptable to force motorists to place their lives at risk by driving on roads which simply are not safe. We have given an unequivocal commitment to increase the level of road funding and to support this commitment by introducing a new category of economically important roads for Federal funding purposes. I am proud to be part of a coalition which has already given a further undertaking to set aside a specific amount of fuel tax which would be used for road construction and maintenance. We will not be participating in the road funding fiddle occurring at the moment. We will set the amount and stick by it regardless of other commitments. This will allow local and State governments for the first time in May year the luxury of being able to plan for the future knowing full well what road funding will be. Until such time as the Government is prepared to acknowledge the need for increased road funding, it will be seen as just another attack on the small businesses which are dependent upon road transport and rely on it for their lifeblood.

Recently the Federal Government announced a range of new road safety measures which it claimed would help stem the rising tide of road deaths. I believe that these measures have been prompted by the Government's desire to shift the responsibility from where it should lie, and I was interested therefore to read comments of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) whose Director, Robin Brown, claimed that the fitting of speed limiters to all trucks from 1991 and to those caught speeding from January 1990 would be of no assistance in curtailing speeding in built up areas. AFCO has called for the immediate installation of tachographs which register speed travelled and time on the road, and its call has been strongly supported by the NRMA.

Naturally in a broad sense the coalition welcomes any moves, however belated, to decrease road carnage. The community is justified in being angry at the Government because of its complacency. The new measures, however welcome, will be cold comfort for the many thousands of Australian families who are mourning the loss of a loved one killed in a road accident. It is unfortunate that it has taken a tragedy such as that which occurred at Grafton to prompt some action by the Government on roads, and although I cannot claim that any action could have guaranteed that that accident would not have occurred it is, however, abundantly clear that unless road funding receives a higher priority from the Federal Government the likelihood of further tragedies such as the one at Grafton increases.
Australian motorists have received a shoddy deal from the Federal Government for years and the allocation in this Budget does nothing to correct that anomaly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering the Appropriation Bills which will provide the funding for the Government's activities for the next year, we are of course looking at the bare economics of our society. But we are also looking at a lot more than that because in these Bills we can also look at the direction which our society will take because it is in deciding where the priority areas of funding lie that the Government influences the direction that our society will take and even the kind of society that we have. Compassion costs money. A dollar given in one direction must be taken from another, and a government always needs to be aware of short term false economies-that is, short term penny-pinching which can cost more in the long run.

SPEECH.PARA: The other fundamental question that needs to be asked is: do we want a society in which the people serve the economic structures or a society in which the economic structures serve the people? In my remarks on these Appropriation Bills I will address this question in relation to a few issues.

Unfortunately, as far as interest rates are concerned, the best interests of ordinary Australians do not appear to be being met. Deregulation of the banks has not resulted in healthy competition with greater choice for the consumer; in fact, quite the reverse. Home loan interest rates continue to rise. There are those fortunate enough to have loans pegged at 13.5 per cent, which is the level interest rates were at when the banks were deregulated. Those with loans from the big four banks have their loans pegged, after the recent Government initiative, to 17 per cent, which one might call a Clayton's deregulation. Some are in the position of having the opportunity to take out loans at a fixed rate for a limited period. But the rest are caught in a spiral over which they have no control.

A taxi driver here in Canberra told me just the other day that his home loan repayments have risen by more than $250 a month in less than a year. Yet the Australian banks are recording massive profits. They appear to be the most profitable banks in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, with all her current problems after the recent resignation of her Chancellor of the Exchequer, was heard to boast that at least home loan interest rates in the United Kingdom are below those currently in Australia. Small business people and farmers are paying interest rates somewhere around 22 to 25 per cent, and many of these people are going to the wall.

The coalition Opposition supported the Government when it deregulated the banks but both should now consider re-regulating as this appears to be the only way that interest rates can descend to sensible and affordable levels. It is to be regretted that the Government and Opposition have not supported the Australian Democrats initiative to inquire into banks in Australia. It is a scandalous situation that fees on a small bank account should be subsidising the lack of fees or lower fees on very large accounts.

One fiscal measure that will soon attain a level of social justice, as well as economic justice, is a tax on the goldmining industry. Remarkably there is now tripartite support for a tax on the profits on gold. During the Budget debate a year ago, members of the Opposition were vehement in their opposition to taxing the profits of gold. They have changed their mind and I applaud them for that. My one regret is that the present Budget does not advise that that tax should be introduced earlier than January 1991. The two-year plus delay between the announcement of the imposition of the tax on the profits of gold, which was brought in to allow companies time to adjust and make new arrangements, seemed reasonable at the time but since then there has been a flurry of activity and an almost indecent haste to carve out huge open-cut mining pits in order to rip out as much high grade earth as possible before the tax comes in.

I would like to add that the Western Australian Government yesterday released an environmental charter for Western Australia with 10 guiding principles to help maintain life processes and optimise the quality of life. The tenth principle in that charter is that the polluter pays for environmental harm. I look forward, indeed, to reading the legislation to be introduced in the Western Australian Parliament which will enforce in law the polluter pays principle which the Australian Democrats believe should be enforced in law right across Australia.

Another topic which is uppermost in people's minds and certainly in the news media at present is the airline pilots dispute. Indeed, as has been stated in this chamber a number of times, we do seem to have a shambles of a situation. I should not say `dispute' because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has assured us that the dispute is over. However, there do seem to be a lot of other associated topics and unanswered questions with regard to that situation. For example, why is there so much discrepancy between the percentages of places that the Government and the airlines say are available on the current flights and the actual situation which is being experienced by people who have to put up with flights not being available, being cancelled at the last moment or not being able to be booked in advance?

Indeed, another question I would like to ask is: How much is it costing us in increased trade deficit to lease foreign aeroplanes and pilots? What will be the waste in resources to Australia if hundreds of pilots, each of whom has cost in the region of $1m to train, take themselves and their experience overseas? I believe that in some cases we may be paying a foreign airline to have those same pilots fly foreign aeroplanes in Australia. Why is the subsidy going straight to the airlines while those employed in tourism and other downstream industries lose their jobs, their livelihood and their hope for the future? To what extent will this increase our overseas debt? It is to be hoped that the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute will answer these and other questions. They are certainly not addressed in the Appropriation Bills before us now.

There also is a lack of coherent debate about the economics of immigration, despite the fact that there have been two recent major economic studies on immigration. Of course, the Australian Democrats take a different view on immigration from that taken by both the Government and the Opposition. We believe that the main thrust of immigration should now be on family reunion and other humanitarian and compassionate grounds such as our intake of refugees. People who have been accepted as permanent residents or citizens are not mere economic units. They have the right to be joined by members of their closer extended families should circumstances warrant that. Through their added stability and family life, the stability of society is strengthened. Indeed, our present day life is full of various stresses, and a stressed community and stressed individuals can result in anti-social behaviour such as petty crime, even serious crime or drug-related activities, or these people may need assistance from mental or physical health professionals. That, of course, costs society money.

Such activities may also make it difficult or even impossible for the person concerned to be a productive member of society. Therefore, I suggest that our migrant population, no less, of course, than our Australian-born population, must first and foremost be regarded as human beings. Likewise, of course, we have our obligations under covenants to which we are a signatory to accept our fair quota of refugees on a compassionate and humanitarian basis.

The two reports to which I referred previously and which contain critical economic assessments of immigration, have been misunderstood by both the Government and the Opposition. The first of these, The Economic Effects of Immigration, came out in April 1985 and was prepared by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia, which is a private business group. The other was a consultancy report prepared by the Centre for International Economics for the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, that is, CAAIP, which also produced a report recently.

Continuing faith in the economic benefits of immigration has recently been affirmed by both the Government and the Opposition. But at least we are past the stage of importing migrants as mine and factory fodder. I believe that the worst example of this was the Wittenoom story. If we look at the economics of that now, we will see that they are quite horrendous. I refer to the hospital stays, the drugs, the compensation by CSR Ltd and the State Government Insurance Commission in Western Australia. Altogether, there were 6,502 male and 410 female workers in Wittenoom. There were also the families of those workers. In 1986 a report was brought out containing prognostic figures. Up to the end of 1986, there were 94 cases of mesothelioma, 141 cases of lung cancer and 356 successful compensation claims for asbestosis. A prognosis was then made up to the year 2020, and the numbers are quite horrifying. I have mentioned them before in this chamber.

Funding is required for research into the prevention and treatment of these diseases which in the end will save the country money. It appears that adequate funding for this research is simply not forthcoming. This is an extreme example, but it demonstrates well the dangers of regarding people, migrants-any sort of people-as mere economic units. The Western Australian Cabinet documents at the time of the heyday of Wittenoom show very clearly that despite warnings given to them they chose to ignore those warnings and were very concerned with the profits of the time.

The Australian Democrats query the continuing of immigration schemes based strongly on skills and business migration. If it is skills that we need, then surely we have an obligation to upgrade our teaching and training methods and to skill our present population, particularly our out of work population. If it is people that we need, then family reunion and compassionate and humanitarian grounds are surely more advisable. If we are worried about people not being able to settle properly in Australia, then we should be all the more concerned for people to come out to an already existing family structure. Australia as such has no policy as yet on population. That was stated quite recently by Senator Richardson, the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in this chamber. I believe that we have a lot of work to do in this area and we are only at the beginning of a sensible analysis of our immigration policies.

I would also like to refer very briefly to two communities which do not seem to be gaining much benefit from the present Budget. The Australian Democrats believe that funding provided by government to its agencies should seek to act in the best interests of the Australians serviced by those agencies. This has not been the case for the Kandiwal community, that is, the 600 or so Torres Strait Island people who reside in the northern parts of Western Australia, particularly in the Mitchell Plateau region. The Kandiwal community considers that it has been given the run-around by the Aboriginal Development Corporation (ADC) with regard to its move to the Mitchell Plateau and with regard to its proposed joint venture with Western Australian Torres Strait Fishing and Trading Inc.

An agreement was signed between the joint venturers this year to fish for trochus and tropang. In order to get the venture off the ground and in order therefore to provide jobs for the Torres Strait Island people in the northern parts of Western Australia, who are currently receiving funds from the community development employment projects (CDEP) scheme and social security, they were advised by the ADC to apply for funding from it. The community did everything they were asked to do. They applied for a fishing licence. They did their sums on the estimates for the cost of a boat and equipment. They arranged a market. The ADC gave them an undertaking that funding would be available as soon as possible. But I am afraid that the whole story has been a woeful one, because each time they have returned to the ADC they have been told that something else is needed.

Now, and only now, have they been told that they need to do a feasibility study. So they have obtained a written promise of funds for the feasibility study but they are still waiting to know when they will receive the funds and how much they will receive. The mass of paperwork is incredible. There is correspondence with regard to the shareholders. Correspondence has been exchanged with their solicitor. There are handwritten comments by the ADC saying yet again that the criteria are not being met. There are various submissions which they have put in, and also there are letters to the State Minister for Fisheries and the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). These matters must be conducted with propriety but applicants for funding commercial ventures such as this should be given all the information at once and not piecemeal, as appears to have happened on this occasion.

Communities like the Kandiwal community deserve proper and professional incentives and encouragement to become productive Australians. This is an instance, I believe, of a small business venture which could and should get off the ground. In saying this, I refer to remarks made by Senator Crichton-Browne earlier when he was talking about another venture. He said that if it had been headed by Sir Peter Abeles or Rupert Murdoch perhaps it would not have been pushed around in the same way.

Another community I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate is the Baryulgil community in New South Wales, an Aboriginal community, which is still waiting for the recommendations of the 1984 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs as it concerned that community to be implemented. The people's main concern is with regard to the asbestos contamination in the Baryulgil square. They made submissions to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 29 May and 31 July. To date, these have been rejected. In particular, they require a medical service to help the former Baryulgil miners and their dependants with the management and diagnosis of their asbestos caused diseases. They require assistance with a number of functions that they need to carry out in noting the extent to which the ex-miners are diseased and with regard to the health and welfare of the community which remains at Baryulgil. These matters will continue to be raised in this chamber, as they have been already, until they are settled properly.

In conclusion, I refer to environmental matters which I raised during the recent Estimates committee hearings. The special problems faced by the marine and estuaries section of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service are very complex. We are dealing here with the conservation of remote islands such as Ashmore and Cartier reefs and the Ningaloo Reef Marine Park off the north-western coast of Western Australia. There is a concern that the resources available to the National Parks and Wildlife Service do not allow it to respond adequately to the escalating deterioration of the marine and estuarine areas. In Western Australian newspapers recently we have had tales of dolphin deaths and disappearances, the bad situation in Albany's harbour and the threat to abalone fishing off the coast of Western Australia.

In addition to controlling illegal fishing and the killing of seabirds and turtles by Indonesian fishermen, we also need to draw up management plans and carry out other routine tasks. There is a need for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to take the lead in research into major problems that affect the marine environment of Australia. We have had many recent reports of dolphins, turtles and sea lions dying in the nets of shark fishing boats in the Geraldton area; damage to coral and fishing in the Abrolhos; concern at the death and disappearance of dolphins at Shark Bay; and concern at the impact of hovercraft on the dugong population just north of Shark Bay.

I put it to the Government that there is a need for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to receive adequate funding in order to research these marine problems properly. The Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia relies on Commonwealth funds to carry out work on the drupella, the snail that is causing the death of coral in the Ningaloo Reef Marine Park. The extent of the problem is vast, as was admitted during the Estimates committee hearings. It is more than one State can cope with alone. Unless we learn more about the marine environment, the end result is likely to be marine degradation on a scale similar to that which we face on some areas of our land.

Recently the Western Australian Government estimated the cost of cleaning up the pollution at Albany's Princess Royal Harbour and Oyster Harbour at $200m. The cost of cleaning up the Peel Harvey estuarine system is estimated at several million dollars. There is no doubt that a well resourced, expanded marine section of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service could save marine fauna and flora, save State governments many millions of dollars and safeguard important fisheries. We must look ahead in these matters. We are looking at a costly procedure; nonetheless it is not appropriate that we penny-pinch and leave for the generations to come a huge expensive mess to clear up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill and cognate Bills a number of Opposition speakers have canvassed at some length the benefits to Australia of implementing the recently released Peacock economic strategy. It is perfectly appropriate for them to have done so in what has been a very wide ranging debate, but the picture of a rosy nirvana painted by the Opposition speakers is based on very shaky ground indeed and deserves a response. I have read from cover to cover the economic strategy for Australia that has been released by the Opposition. I read it with a great sense of deja vu. It is not a new strategy and it is not full of new ideas. It is certainly not a plan that gives any hope to Australia for better times ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), has told us that a recession is inevitable. There is no doubt that that will be a self-fulfilling prophecy if the Opposition's plan is ever implemented. The Peacock action plan is not a plan for tough times but a plan that will guarantee tough times for Australia. It is a strategy that is built around a fight-inflation-first approach to economic management via high interest rates and a dramatic downturn in economic activity. It is a recipe for simultaneous high unemployment, low investment and widespread social hardship in this country.

My analysis of the Peacock plan is certainly correct because this recipe has been tried before. The Opposition has simply relaunched the economic strategy implemented by Margaret Thatcher in Britain in the early 1980s. Even the rhetoric is the same. Mr Peacock says that his key objective is to bring down inflation. Mrs Thatcher gave absolute priority to controlling inflation. Mr Peacock says that the labour market must be deregulated. Mrs Thatcher said that the labour market must be freed from the distortions of official regulation. Mr Peacock and Dr Hewson have simply adopted the Thatcher approach to economic management.

Life under the Thatcher Government has been pretty ordinary for all but the rich. The Thatcher Government's performance as an economic manager, especially in the early 1980s, has been a disaster. That disaster is now being realised. The social consequences of Thatcherism have been nothing short of tragic. Full scale riots in London, Liverpool, Manchester and Birmingham stand as evidence of the social breakdown of British society under the pressure of high levels of unemployment, especially among the young, and associated poverty.

What of Mrs Thatcher's key aim of cutting inflation? When she won office, inflation in Britain was running at 10.3 per cent, lower than that of the United States of America, France and Italy, and just above the 9.7 per cent Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average. Ten years on, it is over 8 per cent-higher than in any other major industrial national and more than twice the OECD average. The cost of this unsuccessful fight-inflation-first strategy was and is massive unemployment. More than one million people lost their jobs in Great Britain in 1981 under the policies that we are now seeing produced in Australia.

By 1983 the number of unemployed rose to over three million, with most of the jobs being lost in the industrial cities of the north of England. The north of England, where 58 per cent of the population live, was forced to carry 94 per cent of the unemployment. For example, the Thatcher approach saw one-third of all manufacturing establishments in Liverpool close down. Under Thatcherism the working class became the unemployed class or, as the President of the Liberal Party, John Elliott, recently put it, millions of workers became bludgers. There are still one million more people without work now than when she took office in 1979.

Not only did Mrs Thatcher slow economic growth, but output per worker in the 1980s has also been very low-the much vaunted productivity that is going to result, according to the Opposition, from the implementation of these policies that have been canvassed so widely during this debate. In fact, productivity in Great Britain during the 1980s has been lower than in the 1960s and 1970s. The shock of Thatcherist monetarism is illustrated by the fact that manufacturing suffered an absolute fall of 17 per cent in the level of production from the second quarter of 1979 to the first quarter of 1981.

But what about wages-that area in which this policy promoted by the Opposition during this debate is so vulnerable? The Thatcher strategy was to deliberately lift the level of unemployment and, at the same time, launch a full-on assault against the trade union movement to put a brake on wage growth. That is precisely the policy now being promoted by the Opposition. She certainly achieved her objectives of lifting unemployment and embarking on a vicious union bashing campaign. But with what result? Despite three million workers being forced onto unemployment queues and open warfare with the unions, average annual earnings were still running at 7.5 per cent in 1983. Not only did nominal wages continue to grow, but real wages have surged ahead.

Between 1979 and 1988, real wages in the United Kingdom rose by 28 per cent, which is more than double the increase in Japan, West Germany or France. There was a fall in real wages in the United States over the same period. Wage growth is currently running at over 10 per cent. In the light of such evidence, it is difficult to understand how the Opposition can continue to claim that it will achieve a wages outcome in line with productivity increases in a deregulated labour market-especially given that the Opposition is nowhere near as tough as Mrs Thatcher.

What about investment under Thatcherist economics? In the manufacturing sector, net investment was negative for the period 1981-83. The recent recovery in investment levels has only just recovered the ground lost in the early 1980s. In fact, I heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) quite accurately saying in the other place today that industrial growth in Great Britain has only just returned to where it was 10 years ago when Mrs Thatcher took office.

What of Great Britain's external position? This lack of investment has seen no improvement in the competitiveness of the British economy generally and the manufacturing sector in particular. Imports of manufactured goods have averaged about 6 per cent of gross domestic product over the last decade while manufactured exports have remained steady at about 2 per cent of GDP. The result is a growing trade imbalance for Great Britain. This deterioration has become apparent only in recent times because of the declining influence of the income from North Sea oil. In her first years in office, the British Prime Minister enjoyed a free ride on the back of North Sea oil. That free ride is now coming to an end. It appears that she has happily spent the money with no thought for the future.

So the Peacock-Hewson Economic Action Plan has been well and truly market tested by Margaret Thatcher, with the following results: high interest rates; a massive lift in unemployment; high nominal and real wages; continuing high levels of inflation; flat investment growth; little growth in productivity; a deteriorating trade position; and massive social dislocation and hardship. So much for the British economic miracle-all the pain with no gain!

It is difficult to understand why anyone would seek to emulate such a dismal display of economic management and force it on Australians. But that is what the Oppposition is presenting to the Australian people. The Opposition says that it will bring inflation and labour costs down to a level equal with that of our major trading partners. Mrs Thatcher did not. The Opposition says that it will achieve this through freeing up the wages system-that has been said in this debate-but, at the same time, limiting wage increases to productivity increases, through a tight fiscal policy, through micro reform and through a steady monetary policy. These are all the Opposition's words. Mrs Thatcher tried to do this and failed.

The dispute between the domestic airlines and their pilots gives us further insight into how the Opposition's enterprise bargaining wages system would operate. I concede that, under the Opposition, the airlines dispute would have lasted one day. Without the support of an effective industrial relations system, the airlines would have had little option, as they have had no option in the last 30 years, but to have given in immediately to the pilots' demands. The Opposition's industrial relations policy would be a disaster for this country. If I am not believed, look at the response to the policy from the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. (MTIA). It does not want the Opposition's industrial relations policy; neither does anyone else in business or in the trade union movement. The President of that important industry body told the MTIA annual general meeting in Canberra last month:
As far as our industry is concerned, they have made it abundantly clear over the last year or two that they want both award restructuring and an end to confrontation.

That is the industrial relations system that has been put in place by this Government. The president of the MTIA said that the alternative over-award payments extracted factory by factory without anything in return-that is, the Opposition's policy-could not be seriously entertained as an alternative. In reality, that alternative rejected by this key industry group is the industrial relations policy presented by the Opposition.

Consider again the airline pilots dispute, in which the claim was a cost of living catch-up claim. Reference to possible productivity trade-offs came only as an afterthought: it was not injected in fact until a fortnight after the dispute had started, when the pilots realised that the industrial relations game had changed and they were not getting their own way. The fact remains that, under the Opposition, the pilots would have picked up 29.9 per cent quick as a flash and we would have faced an across the board wages break-out, followed closely by a recession and massive unemployment-indeed, the recession that the shadow Treasurer is predicting.

Employers do not want open warfare with the union movement. They want an effective wages system that provides for change over time, for the restructuring of work practices and for improved productivity. As with their fight-inflation-first strategy, there is no need to guess what would happen to wages under a coalition government. We already know: a wages break-out followed by a massive hike in unemployment. We all remember 1981, when the conservatives last tried the free bargaining approach. There was an 18 per cent blow-out in wages and unemployment went through the roof: 650,000 people were thrown out of work in this country. As a result, hundreds of thousands of families suffered. If one forgets the rhetoric and looks at the record of the conservatives when they were in office, when they had the chance to help Australian families-indeed, when they had the responsibility to help Australian families-one sees that they did nothing. They slashed family income by throwing hundreds of thousands of breadwinners out of work.

What of the tight fiscal policy we were promised by the Opposition for months before the release of its economic policy? I cannot find it in the document; it has not materialised yet. It simply is not there. It has been the Australian Labor Party in government that has done all the hard work in cutting back government spending year after year. Now we have the shadow Treasurer, based on his own figures, cutting spending by a further paltry $140m and claiming credit for the lot. Costings of the Opposition policy undertaken by the Department of Finance-not by the Government-show that the coalition numbers are out by at least $835m, which is a 31 per cent shortfall. I personally think that is a conservative figure, because I understand the real world of the unemployed. I understand the way in which the criteria in the Department of Social Security operate.

A real chill was sent down my spine when I heard Dr Hewson commenting on these estimates by the Department of Finance about the number of people who will in fact go on the special benefit after they are thrown on the scrap heap. It was chilling stuff indeed. What Dr Hewson said is burnt on my brain. He said that the discretion allowed to departmental officers in assessing which unemployed people are eligible for special benefit-that is, a group of Australians that currently number only about 25,000; it is the end of the road, the last piece of government assistance that can be offered to people in desperate circumstances-is a wide discretion and that his government will ensure that it is rigorously exercised. In other words, a coalition government will not assess unemployed people in desperate circumstances on those circumstances; it will simply assess them on whether the 50 per cent figure-people who will be transferred to special benefit-has been reached. Once that figure has been reached, everyone else will be cut off. It is a pretty chilling prospect.

The fiscal policy outlined by the Opposition would be weaker than the Government's by at least $700m. I predict that the Department of Finance estimate that 80 per cent of the unemployed would go on to special benefits is probably low. There are doubts about the Opposition figures in other areas, such as the contracting out of government services and the benefits to flow from the privatisation of government authorities. But what about the alternative approach-the one followed by this Government over roughly the same period? This Government, unlike Mrs Thatcher and this Opposition, with its Economic Action Plan, has successfully attacked both inflation and unemployment at the same time. Instead of destroying millions of jobs in pursuit of a lower inflation rate, we have created 1.6 million jobs, 90 per cent of them in the private sector, and over 50 per cent of them going to women. At the same time we have brought down inflation. We have combined wage restraint, through the accord with the trade union movement and the cooperation of Australian workers, with a more efficient economy to lift business profits and generate huge levels of investment-the lifeblood of any economy.

Mrs Thatcher drove private investment in Great Britain into the ground. Private investment in Australia has averaged over 10 per cent in every year that the Australian Labor Party has been in office. The investment boom currently being enjoyed by Australia has been documented by none other than the shadow Treasurer and Access Economics, the consultants hired by the Opposition to cost its so-called tax policies. They got their figures wrong on the tax policy but they were dead right on the level of investment growth in Australia. Access Economics has identified $90 billion worth of investment projects across most sectors of the Australian economy. Fifty-four per cent of these are already under construction or are committed.

We are already reaping the benefits of this investment boom in the manufacturing sector. According to the Federal Bureau of Industry Economics, the number of manufacturing establishments jumped by 10 per cent in the year to June 1988. The real value of construction work in factory building lifted by 13 per cent in 1987-88 and by a further 9 per cent in the last financial year. The corresponding growth over the previous decade was 2.6 per cent per year. Manufacturing employment was up by 92,000 or 8 per cent over the two years to May 1989, compared to a significant decline in manufacturing employment before 1983. Manufactured exports also continued to grow at an impressive rate. In the September quarter trade figures, the number of manufactured exports was 20 per cent higher than for the same period last year.

The coalition's Economic Action Plan offers the following: a lift in interest rates to about 30 per cent; a massive jump in unemployment, a point confirmed by Senator Chaney in today's Australian; a recession, or, as Senator Chaney puts it, a situation of considerable economic stress; strong unions enjoying big wage increases-the pilots' claim for 30 per cent is a good benchmark; low income workers not in strategic industries getting nothing-those, of course, who do not end up unemployed; and a collapse in private sector investment as profits collapse. As I have already pointed out, 90 per cent of the 1.6 million jobs created by this Government in six years have been in the private sector. There would be no talk of a general pay rise, and Senator Chaney has made it clear that this industry-by-industry policy might mean some workers getting nothing.
`There's a real risk that (the economy) would be in hideous shape and we would face massive unemployment growth,' says Senator Chaney.

That, of course, is confirmed by the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, in a little bit of kindergarten economics that he indulged in not so long ago when he talked about Australia's overseas debt. Dr Hewson said, not once but 10 times-that is how many times I read his comment in the press-that he divided Australia's overseas debt into the number of jobs that he conceded this Government has created in the last six years, 1.6 million, which worked out at $70,000 per job. The Opposition will use unemployment as a weapon to bring down inflation, just as the Thatcher Government did, with the same tragic results in Australia that we have seen previously, and which Great Britain has experienced in the last 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't really believe in all this, do you?

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of the 1980s are in countries like United Kingdom and the United States in order to get inflation there have been unemployment offsets, that's my point.
Dr Hewson replied:

No, I don't think that it necessarily applies in Australia, and I think if you move decisively and quickly you can avoid any significant effect, over and above what is already in the pipeline, on unemployment.
He then offered his reason for saying that. He said:
Because we are moving across the board into my different sort of world and I'm asking you to accept the fact that there is a different world apart from the one you think about and live in all day.

Of course, the world that that journalist thought about and lived in all day is called the real world. Dr Hewson said that his policies are created in some kind of fantasy land of his own creation, in which inflation, wages and unemployment are all going to drop simultaneously while productivity and investment increase at the same time. It is not an economic plan which offers a recipe for any future hope for Australia. It is a fantasy land created by Dr Hewson, the result of which in the real world would be the complete destruction of both the economic and social fabric of this country.

Mr President, the primary purpose of this Bill is to amend various Commonwealth Acts as a consequence of provisions of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989 (the `Amendment Act') which amends the Migration Act 1958 (the `Principal Act'). These consequential amendments are in addition to those matters in Schedule 6 of the Amendment Act.

The Bill also makes a number of other minor amendments to the Amendment Act. These amendments are made to the Amendment Act rather than to the Principal Act so as to avoid any difficulty which might otherwise arise with the operation of the renumbering provisions of the Amendment Act. The amendments will commence immediately before the commencement of the Amendment Act itself.

The majority of the amendments either update terminology, make slight changes in wording or correct internal references within the Amendment Act. It is inevitable in the case of legislation as complex as the Amendment Act that some minor corrections will be necessary. Several amendments merit brief comment.

The Bill provides that regulations may be made that will prescribe matters to be considered in the making of decisions concerning discretionary deportation orders, the revocation of those orders and the requirement that an illegal entrant depart Australia. In addition, regulations may be made which specify procedures to be followed in determining the liability of an illegal entrant to mandatory deportation.

During the passage of the Amendment Act concerns were expressed by the Opposition that it was possible under its provisions that a person recognised by Australia as a refugee could unintentionally be expelled by being deported or by being required to depart.
I gave assurances that this would not be allowed to occur.

To ensure that those legitimate concerns by the Opposition are put to rest and my assurances are kept, a provision is made for the procedures and the criteria for the exercise of the powers of expulsion to be prescribed in the regulations.

The regulations will also reaffirm the essential feature of the Amendment Act, namely the separation of processes of selection (that is, the grant of visas and entry permits) from the processes of expulsion (that is, the exercise of the powers of deportation and the requirement to depart).

The Bill also reinserts provisions allowing for regulations imposing fees for English language tests as previously provided for in the Migration Act. These provisions were previously inadvertently omitted.

To further streamline passenger processing at airports it is necessary to establish a regime whereby visas can be endorsed to recognise a person as being a person who without the endorsement would become an illegal entrant upon entry. Such persons are typically those who have been deported from Australia or another country, who are suffering from a prescribed disease or physical or mental condition, or who have been imprisoned for more than one year as a result of criminal convictions. Without this regime valuable resources are wasted in confirming the endorsement of the overseas post, and in the issuing of a specially endorsed entry permit which merely duplicates the information contained on the visas.

Another amendment is necessary as a result of the regulation drafting necessary to complement the Amendment Act. To ensure the proper operation of the regulations relating to the points system, it is necessary to ensure the regulation making power is sufficiently broad.

An amendment is also necessary to ensure that non-migrant visas can be issued over the counter upon application, and not be delayed by the general requirement to be imposed on pooled applications for migrant entry to notify of any material changes of circumstances since the time of application.

Lastly, the Bill establishes that certain proof provisions apply in criminal deportation proceedings in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as well as in proceedings in a court of the Immigration Review Tribunal.
