TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills before the Senate are the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. All of these Bills effectively result from Budget announcements. The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 will formally impose tax payable for the 1989-90 year and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, the following financial year. The rates to be applied are those announced in the Government's economic statement in April this year. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 deals effectively with measures which will require major employers, that is, employers with a requirement to remit pay as you earn deductions of more than $5m per annum, to remit those PAYE tax deductions twice each month instead of monthly as at present. The Bill also changes the conditions under which the quarterly provisional tax payments are to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to formally maintain the present basic rate of Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent for the 1989-90 year and, until Parliament otherwise provides, for the following financial year. The Bill also makes various changes to the exemption thresholds of the levy. In the main, the coalition does not oppose these Bills. On the contrary, the coalition supports the moves to relieve some of the provisional tax burden on low and middle income earners, in particular through the lifting of the threshold for the general exemption from the quarterly instalment system of paying provisional tax from $5,000 to $8,000. Also, importantly, there is a lowering of the so-called provisional tax uplift factor from last year's 12 per cent rate to 10 per cent.

The major provision contained in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 is the move now to require twice monthly-rather than once a month-instalments of tax deducted from employees' salaries and wages to be remitted to the Australian Taxation Office in those cases where the employers' total deduction of such PAYE instalments exceeds $5m per annum. While this proposal is not opposed in general, the coalition has reservations about some of the motivations of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), or the Government, in bringing the measure forward in the 1989-90 Budget and also as to one of its consequences.

Honourable senators will recall that this change, announced by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech, will result in bringing forward into the current financial year, 1989-90, in effect a fortnight's extra PAYE instalments, which otherwise would not have been payable until 1991. The result of that is to increase the revenues for the Government in this year alone by an estimated $550m.

Businesses are already suffering under the cripplingly high commercial interest rates of between 20 and 25 per cent. The fact that businesses will now have to remit their PAYE instalment deductions twice a month instead of monthly will simply mean that the level of their working capital and hence their interest payments will be increased somewhat as a consequence. Admittedly, this relates to fairly large businesses. As we all know, the really horrific burdens caused by the Government's high interest rate policy are not being borne particularly by big businesses but by the 750,000 small businesses in this country which are not paying interest of 20.5 per cent on their overdraft-that being the prime rate now being imposed by most of our major banks-but which are paying interest rates of 22 per cent, 23 per cent, and up to 25 per cent in some cases.

I have to say that this sort of innovative accounting which we have seen from the Treasurer in this respect in this year's Budget is not singular; indeed, one might almost say that it is a hallmark of Mr Keating. As I have said here on previous occasions, in this year's Budget, through the use of this innovative accounting and some other similar devices, by shunting and pushing revenue payments out of last year and into this year, and out of next year and into this year, the Treasurer has produced a $9.1 billion surplus, when on what one might call normal timing bases the surplus would probably have been in the order of $6.5 billion. The difference is significant because it is on that $9.1 billion surplus that the Treasurer's reputation for tightening fiscal policy this financial year rests, whereas if one makes these appropriate adjustments one finds that actually, if anything, fiscal policy has been somewhat relaxed this year; at best it has been maintained.

On a more specific point, dealing with the new PAYE payment scheme, I foreshadow that my colleague Senator Watson will move a committee stage amendment to exempt public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities from the requirements to make these PAYE remittances twice monthly in cases where such bodies have an instalment deduction total of more than $5m annually. We take the view-which Senator Watson will explain at more length-that in all probability the Government did not intend to bring these bodies within the ambit of this measure. However, because of sloppy drafting it seems that that will occur. However, my colleague will further explain that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another unintended consequence.

—Another unintended consequence, as Senator Michael Baume quite rightly points out. Before turning to the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, I refer to the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989. I foreshadow this amendment now, for the information of honourable senators, and it is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of the motion, add: ``, but the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the Government's record high tax burden has inflicted considerable pain on Australians, who face little incentive to work, to invest and to save,

(ii) even after the tax cuts following the wage/tax deal announced in the April 1989 Economic Statement, the Hawke/Keating Government remains the highest taxing government in the post-War history of Australia, and

(iii) the wage/tax deal has proven to be a disaster for the economic management of Australia with the current account deficit blowing out in the first three months of the financial year and inflation increasing to 8.3 per cent in the 12 months ended September 1989; and
(b) considers that the Government should urgently adopt the economic policies detailed in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan to stop Australia's ride down the Argentine road''.

The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 reflects the taxation aspects of the Government's wage-tax trade-off deal. That deal has proved to be a disaster for the Australian economy. The fact that it has proved to be a disaster particularly goes to the question of the Treasurer's economic credibility. Honourable senators will recall that when the Treasurer originally raised in the Budget of 1988 the prospect of a wage-tax trade-off, he indicated at that time-and is on the public record as doing so-that he would be seeking a zero wages growth outcome as a trade-off for the tax cuts he was contemplating.

What do we actually have instead? Well, of course, we got the tax cuts on 1 July this year. They have had the effect of increasing to that degree the purchasing power of Australian consumers and no doubt of adding to the continuing long-running saga of what the Treasurer used to call-although I think he no longer uses the phrase quite so freely-our overheated economy.

On top of that we will be seeing in Australia in 1989-90 wages growth roughly twice that of the average-I repeat, the average-of our major trading partners. If one compares our situation with that of the more successful among our major trading partners, one finds that that comparison is even more adverse to Australia. Even the Budget forecast for average earnings growth this financial year is 7 per cent which, if I may say so, is a long way from zero. Current Australian Bureau of Statistics data suggest that earnings growth is running ahead of that figure, probably around 8 per cent which, again, is a long way from zero.

The fact is that our Treasurer today no longer has any credibility. That fact is nowhere more strikingly evidenced than by his behaviour in the House of Representatives yesterday when, in a desperate attempt to stave off the Opposition attack on the indiscreet-to use a kindly word-remarks of the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, he indulged in one of the most serious defamations under parliamentary privilege that it has ever been my sad lot to witness from a senior Minister of the Crown. In that debate, Mr Keating accused my colleague Dr Hewson, the shadow Treasurer, by name, of having conspired with Mr John Elliott to backdate the Opposition's proposal to remove the capital gains tax to 19 September 1985 in order that Mr Elliott should be able to make some capital gains on shares which he had acquired as a result of some transactions between a company called Harlin Holdings and Elders-IXL. I do not want to go into the detail of that matter as it is a subject with which the Senate is regularly bored by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. It would, therefore, be well known to all honourable senators.

I want to concentrate on the behaviour of this senior Minister of the Crown yesterday in the House of Representatives. He made that accusation under parliamentary privilege. He claimed to know the particular circumstances in which this came about-claiming to know, for example, that there had been a telephone call from Mr Elliott to Dr Hewson-and made all sorts of other totally unsubstantiated and totally fabricated allegations. In fact, it is a matter of public record that the Opposition's proposal to repeal the capital gains tax and to do so from the date in question-from 19 September 1985-was first announced on 10 May 1988. At that time the then Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition made a joint statement in which the timing was outlined. That statement said:
These provisions will apply to assets acquired after 19 September 1985 and disposed of after the date of the election of the Liberal and National Party Government.
I particularly want to draw Senator Walsh's attention to that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —What fact?
—The fact that I just quoted. That statement was repeated, in identical words, in the document Future Directions, which was released as long ago as December last year. Again it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions will apply to assets acquired after 19 September 1985 and disposed of after the date of election of the Liberal and National Government.

That is the key point which bears upon the respectability, or, alternatively, the disgracefulness, of the behaviour of the Treasurer yesterday in the House of Representatives when he alleged that the setting of the effective date of repeal of this measure, as announced by the Opposition in its Economic Action Plan on 12 October last, was due to the conspiracy which he alleged between Mr John Elliott and Dr Hewson. In fact, it is a matter of record that the share transactions from which the Treasurer was alleging Mr Elliott will benefit as a result of that backdating occurred only this year, in 1989, and were not even spoken of prior to that time. In other words, the Treasurer was saying yesterday that there was a conspiracy to put the date of 19 September 1985 on this proposal so that Mr John Elliott could benefit from a share transaction which had occurred this year, when the date and every other detail of the proposal had been made public as long ago as 10 May 1988.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I know you are a fair-minded person. I put this to you: What do you think would have been the appropriate behaviour of any member of this Parliament, whether in the Senate or in the House of Representatives, who made in either this chamber or the other place a statement that was not only clearly unsubstantiated but also obviously false, a statement that could not possibly be true? What do honourable senators think would be the appropriate form of action by a member or a senator when it was pointed out that such a defamatory and slanderous statement had been made? Does the Senate not agree with me that the only honourable course open to the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in these circumstances would have been to get up in the House of Representatives today to acknowledge that his statement yesterday was totally wrong, totally unsubstantiated? At best, he could probably have said that he had been told this and that he believed it at the time. He should make a full and appropriate apology. He should behave like a man, not like the coward that he has today proved himself to be by refusing to follow that honourable course.

Let me return to the economic aspects of this matter. A major failure of Mr Keating's economic policies has been in the area of inflation. In his 1988 Budget Speech he said that inflation would fall to 3 or 4 per cent this financial year. But, as we know, inflation is running at 8.3 per cent for the 12 months ended September with no prospect-not even the Minister for Finance will claim that there is any prospect-of a fall to 3 per cent by June next year, which was the Treasurer's claim only 15 months ago. After that record, one would have thought that the Government would give away the wage-tax trade-off idea as a bad joke. That is about the kindest description one can apply to it. Not a bit of it. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald the Social Security Minister, Mr Brian Howe, was reported by Margot Kingston as saying:
In April this year you got the largest tax cuts in history. Massive. $5.8 billion . . .
Mr Howe is reported as having gone on to say:
And probably in a tax-wage trade-off next year you will get something of the same order. All paid for.

TALK.START.PARA: —He may well be right.

—He may very well be right, except in respect of the last part of the claim. If there is such a tax-wage trade-off it will not all be paid for. I can guarantee that. This Government will not do what the Opposition has done-detail the spending cuts that will be required to pay for the tax cuts which Mr Howe was broaching the possibility of as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday. The fact is that the cat is out of the bag. Despite statements by the Treasurer yesterday that Mr Howe was `not correct', some more digging by the Sydney Morning Herald in the course of yesterday has produced a different perspective. The article on the front page of today's edition states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating was angered by Mr Howe's remarks. Staffers in both men's offices conferred yesterday morning on what stance to take, deciding on the line-
honourable senators should mark the word `line'; it is what the public gets told instead of the truth-

that the Government had not yet considered next year's trade-off. This form of words ruled out official discussions but not unofficial discussions between Mr Keating, Mr Howe, and the ACTU secretary, Mr Bill Kelty.
But let us not be guided by mere hearsay, retailed through even a reliable reporter. The article goes on to quote an Australian Council of Trade Unions official. It states:
One ACTU official said of Mr Howe's comments: `I think it's right but it's a bit premature.'

Indeed, more than the one ACTU official can be quoted. The comment of no less an ACTU official than Mr Bill Kelty, Secretary of the ACTU, is also reported in the same Sydney Morning Herald article. It states:
The ACTU secretary, Mr Bill Kelty, would not comment directly on Mr Howe's revelation but said it was already agreed that there would be a wage-tax agreement next year.

As we all know, what Mr Kelty says goes as far as the Government is concerned: that is it; there will be a wage-tax agreement next year. It only remains now for us to have the parameters put on it. No doubt the Government will get around to that in the period before Christmas Eve. Despite the Treasurer's remarks that Mr Howe was not correct yesterday, the Social Security Minister reaffirmed his story during Question Time in the House of Representatives yesterday. Again, I quote the newspaper report of what he said. It states:
Under sustained Opposition questioning, Mr Howe said his statement was `essentially to the fact that the Government this year has delivered a very substantial package which was in fact paid for.'
That last claim is not, of course, quite true, but I pass that point by. The article continues:
`The Government has not as yet given consideration to any package for next year . . .

That is true. I am prepared to believe that the Government has not yet formally given any consideration to it in the sense of a formal Cabinet submission from the Treasurer or whoever would be the responsible Minister or Ministers going to the Cabinet or the Cabinet committee. Mr Howe's quote from the article continues:
. . . but the approach would not be dissimilar to what has already been delivered this year . . .

The question of where the money will come from remains. How will next year's tax cuts be funded? On its part, the Opposition on 12 October this year detailed the tax cuts it will propose immediately following its election at the next Federal election. It detailed also the spending cuts which will be made in order to pay for them so as not to reduce the Budget surplus and relax fiscal policy. Where will the Government's spending cuts fall? Let us assume that Mr Howe and Mr Kelty are correct and that a tax-wage trade-off deal will be done again some time over the Christmas-New Year period. If we set aside that part of any such tax cuts which merely involves returning to taxpayers the proceeds of bracket creep during the current financial year, how-I asked this of the Minister for Finance at Question Time yesterday-would the remaining roughly $3.5 billion of such tax cuts be financed, that is, assuming that it was of about the same order as Mr Howe nominated; that is, of $5.8 billion in total, roughly $2.25 billion represents the return from bracket creep. How would the other $3.5 billion be financed? What would the spending cuts be to finance that? I did not get a satisfactory answer from Senator Walsh yesterday; I do not expect to get a satisfactory answer today. Will the cuts come from the 200 programs that Senator Walsh had in mind a year or so ago and of which he said:
. . . can't be justified by social justice, equity, or economic efficiency grounds, and the reasons we haven't abandoned them is because we don't have the political courage to do so.

The Government has not abandoned those 200 programs because it does not have the political courage to do so. Alternatively, will the cuts come from the 13 high real growth programs identified again by Senator Walsh in one of his more disarmingly frank moments in a speech given in August 1987? Senator Walsh then identified age pensions: invalid pensions; repatriation hospitals; education allowances; children's services; including child-care programs; war widows' pensions; service pensions; secondary school funds; training programs; home and community care programs; pharmaceuticals-perhaps the Government is already well advanced in cutting that area-the Commonwealth superannuation scheme; and Commonwealth rental payments. Those were the 13 high real growth programs identified by the Minister for Finance at that time. Are they to be the areas where the Government's axe will fall when it comes to finance the tax part of the wage-tax trade-off deal which Mr Howe was blathering about on Monday of this week, as reported in yesterday morning's Sydney Morning Herald?

If the Government fails, as it basically failed to do for this year's wage-tax trade-off, to introduce spending cuts to offset its tax cuts, it will only worsen the economic mess it has already led Australia into, a mess which has presented Australia with at the last date, 30 June, net foreign debts of $108 billion compared with a figure of $23 billion when the Government took office. That is a rise of $85 billion during the course of only 6 1/4 years, to say nothing of the growing level of foreign ownership in this country which has raised Australia's total foreign investment liability position, what we might call the national balance sheet, to a debit position of $137 billion. That is the kind of legacy which this failed Government which no longer has any answers will leave to what is now the Opposition and, I regret to say, to our children when it finally summons the courage to go to the polls some time next year and lets the Australian people record a judgment about its performance. I move:
At the end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(ii) even after the tax cuts following the wage/tax deal announced in the April 1989 Economic Statement, the Hawke/Keating Government remains the highest taxing government in the post-War history of Australia, and

(iii) the wage/tax deal has proven to be a disaster for the economic management of Australia with the current account deficit blowing out in the first three months of the financial year and inflation increasing to 8.3 per cent in the 12 months ended September 1989; and
(b) considers that the Government should urgently adopt the economic policies detailed in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan to stop Australia's ride down the Argentine road''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills which we are debating this evening comprises three Bills: the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989; the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989; and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. It is to the third of those Bills that I will address most of my remarks. Before I do so, I would like to say a few things regarding the general taxation measures which are covered in the other two Bills, particularly because from time to time one hears a great deal spoken about the notion of shifting the taxation burden away from a tax on income toward a tax on consumption. The Government has looked at it and the Opposition from time to time has certainly suggested it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to put on the record some remarks in relation to consumption tax. First of all, I make the point that I believe that taxation should be seen not only as an instrument for the raising of government revenue but also quite clearly and explicitly as an instrument for the implementation of social policy. When one says this, very often hands are raised in dismay. Indeed, several years ago when I attempted to amend an income tax Bill in relation to the abolition of the claimability as a tax deduction of money spent on tobacco advertising, the Minister who was in the chamber at that time made that very point. I point out that we already do that. The sliding scale for income tax addresses very much the question of inequity in terms of wages. The system of tax on income is a social instrument which addresses the problem of inequity in terms of wages. Taxes are placed on things such as alcohol and tobacco. I believe that is a clear recognition that the consumption of those items is damaging to human health and that it is seen as desirable that, through a price adjustment mechanism, an increase in the price of those items be made by way of taxation. To some extent that is effective in reducing the consumption of those drugs that are damaging to society.

I recall that, in the 1960s, the conservation movement had a very active program for many years. It objected to the ability of land owners to claim as an income tax deduction the cost of clearing their land. No doubt that was adopted in the early days as a desirable practice to encourage the clearance of land. As the years went by and we saw the damage that was occurring to land as a consequence of its clearance, a great deal of effort was put into turning around that situation. Indeed, during 1972 to 1975, the Whitlam Government scaled down the ability of people to claim land clearance as a tax deduction. Incentives are now built into many systems to provide for the planting of trees and for the protection of uncleared land. It seems that, perhaps covertly and not explicitly, for a very long time we have accepted that the tax system should be used for the implementation of social policy as well as an instrument for the raising of revenue. This should be done far more explicitly and far more overtly. We should recognise it as a useful instrument to move in new directions.

I turn now to the subject of consumption tax, which is usually qualified by the term `broad based'. When one consumes goods and services, one is consuming in those goods and services a moiety which relates to the resources component of those goods and services, as well as a moiety that relates to the labour input to those goods and services. If we were to consider a consumption tax intelligently, we would have to attempt to discriminate between a tax on the labour component and a tax on the resource component of those goods and services.

As we tax income, it is quite clear that the feedback mechanisms which naturally operate in all natural systems, including the economy, tend to increase the cost of wages. At school I learnt Le Chatelier's principle that if, to a system in equilibrium, a constraint is applied, the system will shift to modify the effect of the constraint. Therefore, if one finds that highly paid executives are being taxed very heavily, strong pressure is applied to push up their wages so that their net wage after tax remains the sort of wage that those executives wish to take home. If one finds that the Government then moves to raise the tax even further, there is a tendency to build into the wage structure a great number of fringe benefits, such as free cars, school fees for children, houses, travel and a great number of other things. As the Government then seeks to remove those options by way of taxation, the system shifts even further and claims are made for increased wages to make up for the loss of those benefits. To the extent that one taxes wages, the wage structure will shift in ways that are really counterproductive, bearing in mind the direction in which we would wish to move society, namely, a direction in which there is a high level of employment and a lower level of the consumption of resources, particularly non-renewable resources.

If one considers a consumption tax, one should be seeking to discriminate between the labour component and the resource component and should be seeking to place a tax on the resource component of goods and services, particularly the non-renewable resource component. If the Government or the Opposition choose to move in that direction, that would have considerable benefits to the extent that it would remove the tax component from wages. As a result, wages could be lowered by the same sorts of feedback mechanisms that I have indicated, which should lead to an increase in employment and to a conservation of those resources because we would be moving more to a situation in which the resource content of goods and services was more expensive to use and the labour content was less expensive to use. Therefore, one would tend to use resources more conservatively and one would tend to use labour more intensively because it was cheaper. That is precisely the situation into which we need to move, bearing in mind that we need to move towards a more sustainable and less resource intensive economy.

Another considerable advantage would be that the tax on the resource component could be a tax that is made at source. For instance, if Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd chose to take X-thousand tonnes of lead out of the ground at Broken Hill, there could be a tax on that at source, which would be easy to collect. The increased cost of that lead because of that tax would flow through to all the goods and services that used that lead. Honourable senators are aware that lead goes into making lead batteries and the alkyl leads that are used in fuel. It would feed through into transport costs and so on but not into the labour component of those goods and services.

If one chose to go down that road of introducing a consumption tax, one would need a review not only of the tax system but also a complementary and simultaneous review of the wage structure. Advantages would flow in terms of reduced tax on wages and, therefore, reduced wages, so that while the net wage might remain the same the wages which employers would have to pay would fall.

I make those remarks in order to get them onto the record in view of the way in which governments in the past-particularly the Liberal-National Party governments-have spoken about a resource tax. I make a plea that, if either of the major parties is considering introducing a consumption tax, it gives consideration to a selective consumption tax in which the tax is placed on the resource component and not on the labour component of goods and services.

I turn to the third Bill, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989, which really is a very brief Bill. It is similar in outline to Bills which have been passed ever since the Medicare levy was first instituted. It merely seeks to continue the application of the levy for a further period, and to continue it at the 1 1/4 per cent rate but at the same time to adjust upwards the minimum incomes on which the levy would be paid. The income thresholds will be adjusted so that there will be no levy paid by people on low incomes; that is, individuals whose taxable income does not exceed $10,330; married, including de facto, couples the sum of whose taxable income does not exceed $17,400; and sole parents where their taxable income does not exceed $17,400. For each dependent child or student maintained by a married couple, the threshold for the payment of the levy is to be increased by $2,100. The Australian Democrats have no objection to that. It seems to be a fairly straightforward machinery Bill which simply implements the sorts of adjustments which have been carried out in previous years. However, while we support the Medicare system and observe that it has brought considerable benefits to the Australian population, we are still greatly concerned that the Government is, this very day, implementing a process of considerable damage to health care in this country through its impact on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and specifically through its altered program of remuneration for pharmacists. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats now move the following second reading motion:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate-

(a) notes and condemns the Government's 23 per cent reduction in pharmacists' prescription fees from 1.11.89 because of the adverse effect this will have on the continued provision of high quality pharmaceutical services;

(b) refuses to accept the Government's claim that it cannot defeat the inequitable Remuneration Tribunal determination despite having rejected another Remuneration Tribunal determination in this session of Parliament; and
(c) condemns the Government for attacking a most respected profession, so further weakening its important contribution to the supply of comprehensive health care''.

Just as the Medicare system is an integral part of the health care system in this country, so too are the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the part played by pharmacists in the implementation of that scheme. Pharmacists are an integral part of health care in this country. We cannot stress too strongly our abhorrence at what the Government is doing to the pharmacists, damaging that very important part of the health care system. Accordingly, I commend to the Senate our second reading attachment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a package of three related Bills: the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. I wish to address my remarks principally to the Income Tax Assessment Bill, and I wish particularly to speak to the amendment that I will move in the Committee of the Whole. I wish to insert after proposed section 221ec (9) a new proposed subsection stating that the new section does not apply to a public hospital, a public benevolent institution or a public university. This not only provides revenue relief but also provides administrative savings to public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities. While the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was concerned that corporations could be using Government pay as you earn (PAYE) group tax funds for companies or private purposes, the Opposition amendment acknowledges that there are some groups of employers which do not fall into this category.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale for our amendment is that these groups-public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities-actually utilise public funds for community purposes. That rationale cannot be disputed. It is a concept that the Government cannot refute. The Opposition might well be criticised for not extending the so-called exemptions to include non-profit organisations such as non-profitable hospitals. Clearly, to do so would be to defy the logic of the rationale behind the exclusions that we are seeking so that this section 221ec will not apply to public hospitals, public benevolent institutions or public universities. For that reason we have received the Australian Democrats' support, and we seek the Government's support. I think that if the Government thinks about this seriously it will support the amendment that I propose to move in the committee stage of the Bill.

The essential feature is that these public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities utilise public funds for community services. They operate on deficit financing, and they operate on overdraft type arrangements. Without this amendment, these public bodies would be incurring extra interest costs which would be detrimental to their welfare. After all, the rationale for the Treasurer's change is that public funds are involved. With the passage of this Bill, those groups of employers with an annual PAYE remittance which exceeds $5m, which includes companies that are members of a wholly-owned group with annual remittances exceeding $5m, will be required to remit twice monthly. Under the Opposition's amendment, they will revert to the old scheme of paying their remittances monthly.

The first flaw in the Government's legislation-and it is a very real flaw-is the inconsistency in the period in which the remittances must be made. Of course, we do not address that in our amendment. I am saying that the legislation is basically flawed because of its inconsistency in the period in which remittances must be made. However, a group employer which pays its employees on the 14th day of the month gets only seven days to make the remittance, as it must be paid by the 21st of the month according to the legislation before us today. However, a group employer which pays its employees on the 15th of the month-only one day later-has 22 days, as payment is not due on such payments until the 7th of the following month.

In its present form, which has not been properly thought out, this amendment Bill serves only to encourage businesses to pay their employees once a month, preferably on the 15th, with their PAYE remittances due on the 7th of the next month. Thus, for astute companies the revenue gain will be minimal. As a result, the projected savings will not be there, as the Treasurer has indicated.

Let me put to the Government a far more equitable arrangement if it wants to proceed down this track. The Government might like to subsequently put some amendments forward. A more equitable arrangement would be for payment to fall due either seven or 14 days after pay day for those group employers who will be affected by this legislation. That was the logical way to go. That is the way in which the Government would have picked up its money. But it is going to forfeit that right by the clumsy way in which it put its legislation before the Parliament today. It should not be for the Opposition to tell the Government how to collect more money or how to get its legislation right.

As stated earlier, the intention of the Government in introducing this twice-monthly remittance of PAYE tax was to prevent companies from utilising funds owed to the Government for company or for private purposes. They are the words of the Treasurer. The Government has estimated that this change to twice-monthly payments will result in a revenue gain of $550m. In addition, it predicts that the outlays on Commonwealth public debt interest will be reduced by $20m in 1989-90, and $70m in subsequent years. But what the Government has failed to consider in this amendment Bill is the negative cash flow implications for publicly funded bodies such as hospitals, universities and other public benevolent institutions.

It is estimated that at least 70 of Australia's public hospitals would qualify as group employers with annual PAYE tax remittances in excess of $5m and thus be required to make twice-monthly payments. Under our amendment, the payments would be made only once a month. Had it not been for the Opposition and the Democrats, 70 public hospitals are likely to be affected-typically those with a bed capacity of 500 or more patients and an operating budget in the vicinity of $60m.

From my point of view, the hospitals face two financial problems if the amending Bill is enacted without the Opposition amendments. Firstly, the majority of hospitals operate under deficit financing arrangements, that is, they are always in the red, with funding from State governments being in arrears rather than in advance. Therefore, most are faced with making interest payments on their overdraft, at interest rates which are currently running at between 20.25 per cent and 24.75 per cent. Should they now be expected to make twice-monthly remittances of PAYE tax, this will disrupt their planned cash flows and place them further into debt. The hospitals will be required to pay this increased debt. It is not a debt that they can transfer to the government funding body for payment by it.

Thus, the enacting of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill as proposed by the Government, without the Opposition amendments, would place an unnecessary and unjustified financial pressure on public hospitals. I would suggest that the hospitals do not need this added financial and administrative pressure when they are being constantly hounded to maintain high bed capacity, high staffing levels and the best medical technology and service which is available.

The second financial problem which this amendment Bill causes for hospitals is that, whilst funding is forthcoming from government sources to cover most of the hospitals' costs, public hospitals also rely on donations and bequests from individuals. In many instances the government funding covers only a quarter of the money required by hospitals for equipment replacement and does not supply funds for refurbishment. Thus, hospitals make up the shortfall by building up funds consisting of donations and bequests from individuals and utilising the interest that these funds earn to purchase vital items of equipment and also to refurbish hospital wards.

Should the amendment Bill be enacted without amendments and consequently hospitals are faced with higher interest Bills on their overdrafts, then the fear is that, instead of being able to utilise the interest earned from donations to replace and upgrade vital equipment, these hospitals would instead be forced to use the interest to pay off their debts. As an ex-nurse, Madam Acting Deputy President, you would appreciate the situation. In the event of this occurring, I would expect that people would be less willing to make donations to hospitals. Giving towards a piece of high-technology medical equipment is considered a far more worthy cause than giving money to cover an overdraft on an interest bill.

Such a situation need not arise if the Opposition's amendment is passed, which I am assured will happen because the Opposition has the support of the Australian Democrats. We only hope that your Government, Madam Acting Deputy President, will see the light and, in the other House, effect the necessary amendment that we are putting through here tonight. That situation need not arise if the Opposition's amendment is adopted.

As to the second part of the legislation before the Senate, I believe that, while this reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor to 10 per cent is welcome, there really is no justification in there being an uplift factor with a percentage that is greater than the projected rate of inflation. May I further state that those clauses in this Bill which deal with provisional tax not only lack a degree of justice from the point of offsets, but also from the point of view of taxpayers are written in such a complicated way that tax reform for most people is still a long way off, because there cannot be tax reform without simplicity. It is an abrogation of taxpayers' rights if they cannot understand the meanings of the words in the Act. This Bill is a further illustration of the Government's convoluted attempt to patch up an unsatisfactory Act which is becoming less and less understood by people who have to comply with the tax rules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing today three Bills: the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. Two of these Bills set provisional tax rates, and the third Bill sets the Medicare levies for 1989-90. One is a complex Bill, raising the threshold for exemption from quarterly provision tax from $5,000 to $8,000 and requiring that from December 1989 instalments of pay as you earn tax deductions by companies with total instalment deductions of over $5m be deducted twice monthly. This will produce a one-off revenue increase of $50m in 1989-90 and reductions in public debt interest of $70m in subsequent years. Therefore, these are significant revenue incomes and savings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats see few problems with these specific measures. What we do find worrying, however, is the general attitude of both Government and Opposition in terms of taxation policy, misgivings which, of course, we raise on every possible occasion in discussing probably one of the most vital of social issues, namely, taxation.

There is the problem of burgeoning private sector debt, which we see as possibly one of the most significant problems to have confronted the Australian economy in the post-war period. It is-and has been for decades-the major component of our foreign debt, encouraged by a taxation system for companies which is amongst the most generous in the world and which has led as a consequence to a plethora of debt based rather than equity based financing systems in Australia. Taxation policy could be used to make it a less attractive prospect for Australian companies to borrow overseas to finance company takeovers. We have witnessed in this country in the past few years numerous incidents of companies going offshore to borrow and thereby increasing our foreign debt, bringing that debt acquired capital onshore and then using it for all sorts of purposes.

The most extraordinary example was when Bond went offshore and borrowed $1,300m. The average taxpayer somehow or other has to feel guilty about this extraordinary overseas debt, of which on this particular occasion $1,300m was brought onshore by Mr Bond. He used it for the exotic purpose of purchasing Mr Packer's media empire at what is now realised to have been probably three or four times its real value. Mr Bond wrote that off against his tax through negative gearing. The two effects are that we as Australian taxpayers are expected to feel guilty about this enormous foreign debt and, of course, we have to pick up the financial burdens of trying to come to grips with these sorts of strategies. As I say, taxation policy could be used to make it a much less attractive prospect for Australian companies to borrow overseas for this sort of activity. In a recent article in the Age newspaper it was stated:
The influential Standard and Poor's credit rating agency . . . lowered Australia's long-term debt rating from AA-plus to AA.

It said that the downgrading, which affects $10.4 billion in direct and guaranteed debt, reflects Australia's sharply higher current account deficit, prospects for protracted external adjustment, and increasingly heavy foreign debt burden. Importantly, it went on to say:

Australia's net external debt rose to 200 per cent of total exports in June. Standard and Poor's said lower Commonwealth external debt was more than offset by rapidly growing private-sector borrowings.
It continued:
. . . the rating agency said Australia's growing foreign interest payments would slow the process of stabilising the external debt burden.

The article placed the responsibility for that very squarely on the shoulders of the private sector in this country. In other words, it said that the private sector had to come to grips with resolving the problems of this extraordinary level of external indebtedness. An analogy has been used often by the Australian Democrats in this place in discussing the strategic options that are open to us in resolving this issue. It is a simple analogy and one which can be understood by most Australians. As is the situation confronting any ordinary Australian family, when things get a bit tight economically three major options can be looked at to resolve the problem. The Australian family in tight economic circumstances has the option to earn more, spend less or go into increased debt. They are the three options which are open to ordinary Australian individuals, families, companies or, indeed, the Australian nation. They are the most obvious options. A short term option is available to them: they can sell off everything that they own, including those things that are making money for them, and hope, like Mr Micawber, that something will show up in due course to get us out of the deep hole that we are digging for ourselves by pursuing that strategy.

In Australia the government of the day has chosen the second option-namely, to cut expenditure. The business sector in Australia has chosen the third option-namely, to go into increasing debt-subsidised, I might add, by the taxpayer because tax concessions are available to them if they move towards debt and away from equity financing. In other words, of the three options available, the Government is pursuing the second, namely, to expand less, while the companies generally are pursuing the third-namely, to go into increased debt-and relatively few of us have been able to pursue the first option of earning more because of Australia's relative disadvantages in terms of overseas earnings.

Worse, however, than all of this is the fact that both the Government and the Opposition are currently leaning more and more towards what must be the most shortsighted of the options. They are adopting as a viable part of their strategy a fourth option-selling off whatever they can to raise short term funds. The recent current account figures are a clear indication that the Government's strategies are failing. Yet, in considering how similar the strategies of both Government and Opposition are in relation to these questions, it is a matter of pace rather than strategic choice.

No attention is paid to the problems facing mortgage holders. In this respect Australia remains significantly different from similar countries which place a high value on home ownership-namely, the United States of America and the United Kingdom. Australia still does not offer targeted tax relief to people who are paying off a mortgage in order to buy their own homes. In Australia we limit that benefit to only those people who are investing in the market. What is worse, we allow them not only a tax benefit but also a negatively geared tax benefit so that they can achieve double the benefit they would otherwise receive. As a consequence they are able to compete for borrowings at a beneficial rate because they know that, although they are borrowing at 18 per cent or 19 per cent, when that is written off against their tax liability they may be borrowing at a fairly attractive real borrowing rate of about 11 or 12 per cent. They could also afford to borrow more, thereby feeling able to bid more at auction or to pay more for homes and more for investments. Generally this is pushing the prices of these sorts of borrowings higher and higher.

We already have a government which sets its priorities in favour of those who are able to look after themselves. Nothing would change with the advent of a coalition government. It might be a little more in favour with those who can look after themselves. Certainly if the Opposition's tax policy can be believed it has no sympathy for the weakest in our society. The Australian Democrats are saying that we see fundamental flaws in tax policy as pursued by the Government or as would be pursued by the alternative Government. In 1988, for example, the Government, with the enthusiastic support of the Opposition, offered a $2 billion benefit to Australian companies, some of the biggest of which were already paying no tax. It offered this by cutting further company tax rates. A 20 per cent tax rate cut was given to Australia's companies by cutting the company tax rate from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar at a time when some of the biggest companies in the country were working the system, to an extent that no ordinary family or small business could do, so that they were paying virtually no tax at all.

This means that in coming years these companies will be in a negative tax bracket and the government-that is, the taxpayers-will return to them large amounts of money. In this year's Budget all that the Government could offer to the pensioners, for instance, was a $2 a week increase. This goes only some small way to helping them catch up on some of the fairly disastrous 1986 budgetary decisions, which also went through with the support of the Liberal and National parties-namely, the delay in consumer price index increases for pensioners, the discounting of the ex-servicemen's pension increases, telling 45-year-old women on class B pensions that once their youngest child reached the age of 16 years they had to get a job or go on unemployment benefit, and cutting Austudy for 15-year-olds in their last two years of schooling. None of these decisions hurt those on high incomes; all of them significantly disadvantage the worst off in the country.

So what we are citing is that the advantaged are benefiting under the tax policies of this Government, and will continue to benefit should there be a change of government, whereas, on the other hand, this and recent Budgets have done little to redress some striking imbalances which resulted from the dramatic reductions in government expenditures, albeit to achieve the first balanced Budget in recent years. But those who suffered to achieve that were, of course, the disadvantaged in the community.

The fact is that we in Australia spend less on social welfare as a percentage of gross domestic product than any other industrialised nation and have a lower tax than almost any of them. In addition, Australia's wage system and its system of other benefits to workers are less than those in most other Western countries.

In our haste to achieve a bigger surplus, we forget that a surplus is achieved at somebody's expense. Either somebody pays more in tax or somebody else gets less of a particular service so that the Government can cut expenditure. While everybody is always happy to point out who should be paying more tax or who does not deserve a particular service, nobody-or at least very few people-is prepared to make that sacrifice himself. So by urging a government to produce a bigger surplus, as many in the business community have, people are in effect leaving it up to the Government to decide where the money will come from. Of course, in the last few years it has come from cuts to social security, health and education-areas that impact most significantly on people in lower income areas.

As I have said, the real problem is that Australian businesses are actually encouraged by the taxation system to borrow huge amounts of money from overseas. The Government is then forced to address the problem of huge overseas indebtedness by reducing expenditure at home. It does this in turn by attacking those who are least able to defend themselves, namely, the economically and socially disadvantaged in the community.

As Standard and Poor's has pointed out, this is a very significant factor in our increasing foreign debt and, hence, in our increasing current account deficit. To make matters worse, the interest paid on those foreign borrowings is tax deductable. Once again, therefore, the taxation system is weighted in favour of the advantaged or the corporate of the community rather than the disadvantaged and the individuals in the community.

I conclude by simply commenting that the Australian Democrats see considerable disadvantage in the structure of the taxation system as it has been put in place by recent Budgets. We see no foreseeable positive change favouring the disadvantaged in the Australian community in the policies that have been forthcoming from the Opposition in recent weeks and months. We simply cite the fact that, even though we are not opposing these tax Bills, which are machinery Bills to implement budgetary measures, we do not inherently identify with the strategies and structures which are implied by them. Indeed, as has been cited by Senator Watson, it may be argued that some of the provisions are impacting to the great disadvantage of small business people. The Australian Democrats are firmly of the opinion that the small business sector has borne the brunt of government policy excessively in this country, not only in recent years but also in recent decades.

We identify with the amendment proposed by Senator Watson, which simply reverts to an exemption which had been granted under previous tax policies to hospitals, benevolent organisations and universities in not imposing upon them an unnecessary requirement to meet twice monthly group tax payments. We cite that exemption as having been appropriate in the past. We have not had a reasonable explanation from the Treasury as to why that exemption should be removed.

We cite the fact that many aspects of these machinery Bills are to enhance the cash flow of government and to disadvantage the cash flow of business. In that respect, we do not identify with the Bills in principle but, because we are opposed to the interference with budgetary Bills, at this stage the Democrats will support them. We will also support the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Watson. My colleague Senator Coulter has foreshadowed a second reading attachment which will be moved at the end of the second reading stage.
